Subject: Matt's Weekly Memo -- February 4
Message:
Click here to view this email in your browser 
￼

 
Matt's Weekly Memo
 
  
Dear Lindsey,
 
Last week, I announced that five first responder agencies in Northeastern Pennsylvania will receive nearly $57,000 to buy more personal protective equipment (PPE) and essential supplies.
 
I often think of the men and women who serve in our fire companies and their families as I continue to push for more support for our safety infrastructure and local governments during this crisis. I consider it my duty to fight for them and ensure our first responders have what they need to keep themselves and our communities safe. 
  
 
Protecting Workers
 
  
Northeastern Pennsylvania's working class tradition is a longstanding one, going back to our coal-mining forbears. Putting workers first has always been a priority of mine, and I believe these efforts are more important than ever amid COVID-19. Over the past few weeks, I'm proud that the federal government is taking steps I have been calling for to strengthen workplace safety standards, especially those in frontline industries whose workers never stopped clocking in since the pandemic began. This includes people who are still mining coal for a living. That's why I reintroduced the COVID-19 Mine Worker Protection Act this week.
 
This is a bill supported by both Democrats and Republicans that would implement responsible safety guidance and deliver personal protective equipment so that miners can continue to work, stay healthy and provide for their families during this health crisis.
  
 
Supporting a Fair Wage
 
  
It's been more than a decade since we've raised the federal minimum wage, and as a result, there is not one place in America where a full-time worker making $7.25 per hour can afford rent, food and other essentials.
 
That's why I am co-sponsoring the Raise the Wage Act to gradually raise the federal minimum wage to $15 by 2025.
 
This will make a real impact in Northeastern Pennsylvanians' lives. Raising the wage will help 101,000 workers in the Eighth Congressional District -- boosting the average annual pay for a third of our workforce by $3,700. It's time we raise the wage and give thousands of workers a fair shot. 
  
￼
Source: Economic Policy Institute
  
 
Housing & Food Assistance
 
  
Emergency relief remains available for folks impacted by the pandemic. Here are two resources available to you: 
	•	If you are struggling to pay rent or utilities, the Rental Assistance Program can provide up to 12 months of aid.
Rental Assistance FAQ
  
	•	The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) has expanded eligibility and increased benefits for individials experiencing food insecurity. 
SNAP Application
  
 
NEPA COVID -19 Vaccine Dashboard
 
  
￼
Source: Pennsylvania Department of Health
  
Be safe and well, 

￼

Subject: USDA Seeks Applications to Support Business Development and Create Jobs in Rural America
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  
February 4, 2021
CONTACT:
James Hogge 231-944-7633


USDA Seeks Applications to Support Business Development and Create Jobs in Rural America

Washington - The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) today announced that it is accepting applications to support economic development and create jobs in rural America. 

USDA is making this funding available under the Rural Business Development Grant program for eligible entities to support business opportunity and enterprise projects in rural communities. Eligible entities are rural towns, communities, state agencies, authorities, nonprofits, federally-recognized tribes, institutes of higher education and cooperatives. 

The funding may be used to establish business support centers or to finance job training and leadership development in rural areas. Projects must be consistent with any local and area-wide community and economic development strategic plans, support other economic development activities in the project area, and be consistent with any Rural Development state strategic plan. Funding for enterprise projects must be used to finance or develop small and emerging businesses in rural areas. 

This year, USDA anticipates that part of the funding will be set aside for federally-recognized Native American tribes, Rural Empowerment Zone/Enterprise Communities/Rural Economic Area Partnerships, and Strategic Economic and Community Development (SECD) projects. USDA also anticipates a set-aside of funding for projects located in Persistent Poverty areas, including those of Native Americans.

Eligible applicants for the set-aside funds must demonstrate that at least 75 percent of the benefits of an approved grant will assist beneficiaries in the designated areas. Applications must be submitted to the nearest USDA office by 4:30 p.m. local time on March 31, 2021. For additional information, see page 8610 of the Feb. 4, 2021, Federal Register.
bergman.house.gov  
###

Member of Congress

Upcoming Tele-Town Hall
I'll be hosting a telephone town hall on Tuesday, February 23rd starting at 6:30 PM. This is a great opportunity to receive a live update from Congress on the major issues important to you and your family. I'll also be taking as many questions from callers as time permits.  There is no cost to participate, and it's easy to register. Simply click here or the button below to RSVP, and we'll call you directly when the event begins at 6:30 PM on Tuesday, February 23rd.

￼

Click Here to RSVP

Important Vaccine Update
On Tuesday, SC Governor Henry McMaster announced that South Carolinians aged 65 and older will be able to schedule appointments for the COVID-19 vaccine beginning Monday, February 8th. (Previously, the age group was 70 and older.)  SC DHEC has a website to help locate vaccine providers in our state.  Additionally, it has established a care line to call for questions about the COVID-19 vaccines or to help find a provider. That phone number is toll free: (866) 365-8110.  Important: Appointments to receive the COVID-19 vaccine cannot be made on the SC DHEC website or by calling the SC DHEC phone number listed above.  These two SC DHEC resources will only help locate providers near you that may be offering the vaccine. You then will need to take additional steps to create an appointment, depending on that provider's policies.  On a related note, my office has received a significant number of calls about the availability and distribution policies of the COVID-19 vaccine, particularly the requirement of most providers that you must register online with an email address just to make an appointment. I am extremely concerned for those in our state who do not have easy access to the internet and who are finding it very difficult to locate a provider that will accept appointments over the phone.   State and local officials have advised if you know someone who may need assistance creating an email address and scheduling a vaccine appointment online, that you please considering reaching out to offer them help. 
Search SC DHEC for Vaccine Providers

Watch My Recent Forum on Vaccines
I recently hosted a very informative radio forum on the COVID-19 vaccines, which included an expert from SC DHEC as well as a medical doctor who specializes in infectious diseases. You can find a replay of this program, along with a list of each question that was asked, on my website or Facebook page.

￼

Watch Vaccine Forum Online

Supporting Term Limits
I believe term limits should apply to every single person serving in Congress, including me. That’s why I’ve proposed an amendment to our Constitution that would limit the number of terms someone could serve in the House or Senate.
Read More About This Effort

Efforts to Save Parris Island
Parris Island has significant importance to South Carolina, our military, and our nation. For over 100 years, it has been the preeminent training base for U.S. Marine Corps recruits. With recent news about a possible closure, I've co-sponsored legislation in the House to prevent this from happening.
Read About the Save Parris Island Act

My Pro-Life Legislation
Even though the 117th Congress officially began just a few weeks ago, I've already sponsored or co-sponsored more than 60 bills in the House of Representatives. Last month, I placed a heavy emphasis on pro-life legislation, signing my name to over 20 bills to protect the lives of unborn children.
Read More About This Effort

Resources from the Library of Congress
Did you know that the Library of Congress has a very large collection of educational resources available online at no cost? With a wide variety of topics from science and technology to history and literature, I think you'll be surprised at how much content is available. Click here or the button below to see what the Library of Congress has to offer. On their website, it's easy to search by categories depending on your interests.
Visit Library of Congress Online

Do you need assistance with the government?
If you or someone you know needs assistance with any branch of the federal government, my congressional office in Rock Hill is here to help. Whether it's the IRS, Social Security, immigration, passports, veterans’ affairs, or anything else related to the federal government, please give us a call at (803) 327-1114.
 Meanwhile, if you have questions about legislation in Congress, my office in Washington, D.C. can answer those. Last year, we responded to over 29,000 inquiries from constituents about bills and policies. You can reach my D.C. office at (202) 225-5501.  The most important job I have in Congress is to help folks here at home in South Carolina. Please don't hesitate to call my offices at the numbers listed above. You can also reply to this email or click the button below to contact me online anytime.
Contact My Office
You can also like my Facebook page to stay up to date on my work for you in Congress.
Visit My Facebook Page

Subject: Espaillat, Education Leaders To Hold Weekly Remote Learning Support Workshops for NYC Parents & Caregivers
Message:
￼ 
  

PRESS RELEASE
For Immediate Release
February 4, 2021


Espaillat, Education Leaders To Hold Weekly Remote Learning Support Workshops for NYC Parents & Caregivers 

Register here: 
http://bit.ly/3pxAlzp


WASHINGTON, DC - Starting in February, Representative Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) will host live and asynchronous workshops to support parents and caregivers navigating the new world of remote learning.

These workshops will be held on a weekly basis, starting Thursday, February 4th at 5:00pm with recordings of the sessions being made available for asynchronous participants. 

Each week, these sessions will be led by Division Leaders from the New York City Department of Education, starting the first session with Dorothy Sanabria, Director for Teaching and Learning for the Manhattan Borough Office, following introductory remarks from Rep. Espaillat. These sessions will cover a range of topics, ranging from navigating remote learning for students with disabilities, multilingual learners, and more. 

Please see the complete calendar and this week’s specific training session below:

Available Sessions:

￼

Thursday, February 4, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Teaching and Learning: “Supporting Families in Navigating Remote Learning”

Thursday, February 25, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Special Education: “Supporting Families in Navigating Remote Learning for Students with Disabilities”

Tuesday, March 9, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Multilingual Learners: “Supporting Families in Navigating Remote Learning for Multilingual Learners”

Tuesday, March 23, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Student Services: “Supporting Families with Stress Management during Remote Learning”

Thursday, April 15, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Teaching and Learning: “Supporting Families in Fostering Student Independence during Remote Learning”

Thursday, April 29, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Special Education: “Supporting Families of Students with a Disability in Fostering Student Independence during Remote Learning”

Wednesday, May 12, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Student Services: “Supporting Families by Strengthening Coping Skills through Mindfulness”

FIRST SESSION

Thursday, February 4, 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — Division of Teaching and Learning: “Supporting Families in Navigating Remote Learning”

￼


WHO: 
* Representative Adriano Espaillat (NY-13)
* Marisol Rosales, Manhattan Executive Superintendent
* Division Leaders from the New York City Department of Education

WHAT: Remote Learning Support Workshops for NYC Parents & Caregivers

WHEN: Starting Thursday, February 4, 2021, continuing on a weekly basis. Multiple live and asynchronous sessions available.

WHERE: Register here: http://bit.ly/3pxAlzp

For more information or questions regarding registering contact either Betzaida Sanchez (Betzaida.Sanchez@mail.house.gov) or Cynthia Rodriguez (Cynthia.Rodriguez@mail.house.gov) or call 212-497-5959 for assistance.

# # #

Representative Espaillat is the first Dominican American to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives and his congressional district includes Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill and the north-west Bronx. First elected to Congress in 2016, Representative Espaillat is serving his third term in Congress. Representative Espaillat currently serves as a member of the influential U.S. House Committee on Appropriations responsible for funding the federal government’s vital activities. He is also a member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus (CHC), where he serves as the Second Vice Chair and is a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, where he serves as Deputy Whip. Representative Espaillat also currently serves as a Senior Whip of the Democratic Caucus. To find out more about Rep. Espaillat, visit online at https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Media inquiries: Candace Person at Candace.Person@mail.house.gov



Espaillat y líderes en educación realizarán talleres semanales de apoyo en el aprendizaje remoto para padres & cuidadores de NYC

Regístrese:
http://bit.ly/3pxAlzp


WASHINGTON, DC – A partir de febrero, el congresista Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) encabezará talleres en vivo y asincrónicos para ayudar a los padres y cuidadores a navegar por este nuevo mundo del aprendizaje remoto.

Estos talleres se llevarán a cabo semanalmente, a partir del jueves, 4 de febrero de 2021, a las 5:00 pm, y las grabaciones de las sesiones estarán disponibles para los participantes que no se hayan conectado de manera simultánea.

Cada semana, estas sesiones serán dirigidas por Líderes de División del Departamento de Educación de la Ciudad de Nueva York, comenzando la primera sesión con Dorothy Sanabria, directora de Enseñanza y Aprendizaje de la Oficina del Condado de Manhattan, luego de los comentarios introductorios del Rep. Espaillat. Estas sesiones cubrirán una variedad de temas, que van desde la navegación por el aprendizaje remoto para estudiantes con discapacidades, estudiantes multilingües y más.

Por favor vea el Calendario de Sesiones completo y la Sesión específica de esta semana debajo:

Sesiones Disponibles:

￼

Jueves, 4 de febrero de 2021, 5:00-6:30 p.m. — División de Enseñanza y Aprendizaje: "Apoyo a las familias en la navegación por el aprendizaje remoto".  Jueves, 25 de febrero de 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — División de Educación Especial: “Apoyo a las familias en la navegación por el aprendizaje remoto para estudiantes con discapacidades”.  Martes, 9 de marzo de 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — División de Estudiantes Multilingües: "Apoyo a las familias en la navegación por el aprendizaje remoto para estudiantes multilingües".  Martes, 23 de marzo de 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — División de Servicios Estudiantiles: "Apoyo a las familias con el manejo del estrés durante el aprendizaje remoto".  Jueves, 15 de abril de 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — División de Enseñanza y Aprendizaje: "Apoyo a las familias para fomentar la independencia de los estudiantes durante el aprendizaje remoto".  Jueves, 29 de abril de 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — División de Educación Especial: “Apoyo a las familias de estudiantes con discapacidades para fomentar la independencia de los estudiantes durante el aprendizaje remoto”.  Miércoles, 12 de mayo de 2021, 5:00-6:30PM — División de Servicios Estudiantiles: “Apoyo a las familias mediante el fortalecimiento de las habilidades de enfrentar situaciones a través de la atención plena”. 
PRIMERA SESION
Jueves, 4 de febrero de 2021, 5:00-6:30 p.m. — División de Enseñanza y Aprendizaje: "Apoyo a las familias en la navegación por el aprendizaje remoto"
￼

Quiénes:
* Congresista Adriano Espaillat (NY-13)
* Marisol Rosales, superintendente Ejecutiva de Manhattan

Para obtener más información o preguntas sobre el registro, comuníquese con Betzaida Sánchez (Betzaida.Sanchez@mail.house.gov) o Cynthia Rodríguez (Cynthia.Rodriguez@mail.house.gov) o llame al 212-497-5959.
# # #

El congresista Espaillat es el primer domínico-estadounidense en servir en la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos y su distrito congresual incluye las comunidades de Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill y el noroeste del Bronx. Elegido por primera vez al Congreso en 2016, el congresista Espaillat cumple su tercer mandato en el Congreso. El congresista Espaillat actualmente se desempeña como miembro del influyente Comité de Apropiaciones de la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos, responsable de financiar las actividades vitales del Gobierno federal. También es miembro del Caucus Hispano del Congreso (CHC), donde se desempeña como segundo vicepresidente y es miembro del Caucus Progresista del Congreso, donde se desempeña como subcoordinador (Deputy Whip). El congresista Espaillat también se desempeña actualmente como coordinador sénior del Caucus Demócrata. Para obtener más información sobre el congresista Espaillat, visite su portal en línea en https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Subject: The Hern Roundup: A busy start to the new year
Message:
￼
Dear Friend,
We're just one month into 2021 and there's already so much to share. The new year kicked off the start of the 117th Congress, welcoming the largest group of Republican women and the most diverse freshman class to the House in history.  I did attend the inauguration of President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris on January 20th. Although there will not be much we agree on, I felt it was my duty as a Member of Congress to witness the peaceful transfer of power.   Biden's speech was full of flowery promises of healing and calls for unity, but he betrayed the American people mere hours later when he issued nearly 20 executive orders on his first night in office. Not only is this wildly unprecedented, but almost every one of his orders resulted in the layoffs of thousands of Americans. Biden says he's waging a war on poverty, but the result looks much more like a war on prosperity.   In spite of all the whiplash-inducing events in our capital, there's a lot I've been working on both at home and in DC. 
￼
Rep. Hern takes the oath of office on January 3, 2021

Veteran of the Month

"So others may live" is the essence of the veteran spirit in America. All our veterans deserve our respect and appreciation because they have put everything on the line to protect us. I am pleased to honor Terry Hill as my January Veteran of the Month. Terry served in the U.S. Army as a Medical Evacuation Pilot and flew Black Hawk helicopters to rescue soldiers on their worst day. A stellar career in the Army marked by several commendations, awards, and honors helped make Terry a wonderful leader on the battlefield and at home. 

Not only did Terry come home and start a successful small business after his military career, but her started the RAGFriday Foundation, with the motto "so others may live." The non-profit organization offers veterans support and job training to help transition into civilian life. Sometimes that transition involves the help of a service dog, like Jonsey, who serves Terry diligently every day. 

￼
Rep. Hern honors Terry Hill as January's Veteran of the Month


Military Academy Nominations

Nominating young patriots to our prestigious military service academies is one of my favorite parts of being a Member of Congress. I was pleased to call two individuals and let them know that I am nominating them for service at West Point and the Naval Academy. Congratulations to Mr. Vincent and Mr. Gilcrest for putting in countless hours of study, physical education, community service, and meeting a list of benchmarks to be accepted into these coveted spots. I look forward to seeing these young men grow and become a part of the next generation of great American leaders. 

For more information about nominations to our nation's military academies, visit Hern.house.gov. 


New Committee Assignments  Earlier this month, I was nominated to serve on the House Committee on Ways and Means. This is a huge honor, as Ways and Means is one of the oldest committees in the House and considered one of the most powerful, as it handles all trade and tax policy and deals with complex legislative issues like healthcare and Social Security.   It's been nearly 20 years since an Oklahoman sat on Ways and Means, so I am proud to serve our state in this role.   

Conversations with Constituents  I was glad to engage in numerous Zoom calls this month with local Chambers of Commerce in our district to discuss several important topics for small businesses, including the successful Paycheck Protection Program (PPP).   Ensuring that our small businesses are equipped with the information and resources they need to continue operating in this difficult time has been a priority for me. My goal is to see our small businesses here at home not only recover from 2020, but flourish in 2021. I am committed to doing everything I can to help make that happen, and I am always happy to provide information directly to my constituents.   If you have any questions regarding the Paycheck Protection Program or any other COVID relief, please call my office at (918) 935-3222.  
￼
Rep. Hern addresses the Coweta Chamber of Commerce on Zoom

Roadmap to Congressional Reform  Earlier this month, I introduced the Roadmap to Congressional Reform, a bill package addressing everything from term limits to earmarks and lobbying.   The Roadmap to Reform includes eight separate measures to reform what I believe to be some of the worst practices in Congress.  



Constitutional Term Limits
Members of Congress come to DC for the best job of their lives and never leave - we need to make sure our government is by the people, of the people, and working for the people.  No Budget, No Pay  If Congress can't pass a budget by April 15, as required by the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, Congress shouldn't get paid. Our most basic Constitutional responsibility is to write a budget and fund the government. We haven't completed the whole process since 1997. If we can't do that, we should not earn a paycheck.  No Budget, No Recess  If Congress can't pass a budget, we shouldn't be allowed to go home. Funding the government is an incredibly important responsibility, if we have not accomplished a budget by April 15, or fully appropriated funds by August 1, Congress should not be allowed to recess.  Stop the Revolving Door  It is a privilege to represent your community and serve them in Congress. Members shouldn't be motivated to run for office because of potentially lucrative contracts as a lobbyist following their time on Capitol Hill.  Congressional Foreign Lobbying Ban  Similarly, Members who represent their community and work for the betterment of America should not leave Congress and register as a foreign agent.  Read the Bills  All too often, Members of Congress are given hundreds - or even thousands - of pages of bill text with mere moments to read it before the vote is called. There is no possible way of knowing what is included in the bill if Members don't have adequate time to read it. This bill requires bill text to be published for a full week before a vote so Members can fully understand what they're voting on.  Earmark Elimination  Earmarks for special interests is one of the slimy practices that make Americans feel cut off from their elected officials. We must root out even the appearance of corruption in government. We cannot allow this practice to ever return to Congress.  Allowing Members to Opt Out of the Federal Employees Retirement System  Members of Congress are automatically opted into a federal pension system, giving thousands of former legislators a pension for life. We currently spend over $35 million a year on Congressional pensions alone. We should have the option to opt out of this so those tax dollars can be spent on programs to help Americans. 



We are hitting the ground running in February ready to fight for American workers, defend our values, defeat this virus, and get America back to the greatest economy in our history. 


Please let me know if there's anything my office can help you with, call us at (202) 225-2211 in DC or (918) 935-3222 in Tulsa. As always, I keep everything up-to-date at Hern.house.gov and on my Facebook page, so you know what's happening whether I'm in our nation's capitol or at work in Oklahoma.  



Sincerely,

Kevin Hern
Member of Congress

Subject: Bergman, Case Lead Bipartisan Effort To Address National Debt
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:   February 4, 2021
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-944-7633


Bergman, Case Lead Bipartisan Effort To Address National Debt

Washington - Today, Rep. Jack Bergman (R-MI) and Rep. Ed Case (D-HI) sent a letter to President Joe Biden, urging him to address the growing national debt by establishing a modern-day Grace Commission to root out government waste and inefficiencies.  Rep. Bergman’s bipartisan letter was co-signed by 34 Members of Congress. It features the formal support of advocacy groups including: Americans for Tax Reform, Digital Liberty, Citizens Against Government Waste, National Taxpayers Union, Americans for Prosperity, FreedomWorks, Taxpayers Protection Alliance, and Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.   
In the letter, the bipartisan Members asked that President Biden take action with respect to the looming debt crisis by forming a federal advisory committee composed of private sector citizens, funded by the private sector at no cost to taxpayers, and tasked with reporting on opportunities to cut waste and improve efficiency in the federal government.   This idea is not new - as President Reagan convened a President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control in 1982 for this same purpose. The committee became known as the “Grace Commission” and issued a report with thousands of recommendations on reforms which together could result in significant cost savings at the federal level.  The Members noted in part, “America expects that its government can multitask, working to mitigate multiple economic catastrophes current and future generations may be forced to confront. We are confident private citizens from across our Nation stand ready to assist you in forming regulatory and legislative recommendations to make our government more cost efficient.”
You can read the full letter here  Council for Citizens Against Government Waste (CCAGW) President Tom Schatz said, “As the nation continues to grapple with the economic effects of a global pandemic, and the federal government may spend up to $5.7 trillion on COVID-19 relief, it is more critical than ever for federal agencies to reduce unnecessary costs and eliminate mismanagement of the taxpayers’ money.  CCAGW supports the efforts of Reps. Jack Bergman, Ed Case and other members of Congress to urge President Biden to convene a new President’s Private Sector Survey on Cost Control.  Implementation of the commission’s recommendations would help to create a more effective and efficient federal government." 
Grover G. Norquist, President, Americans for Tax Reform stated, "The 'Grace Commission' in the 1980s was a great example of common sense, bi-partisanship and public service by Americans from all walks of life.  It is a model of what works.  Success is always worth repeating."
“National Taxpayers Union is proud to support this bipartisan letter urging President Biden to create a 21st century “Grace Commission.” As the nation’s debt rapidly approaches $30 trillion, our elected officials must do everything in their power to address this significant problem. Ensuring taxpayer dollars are used effectively and not wasted, as this letter proposes, must be the priority as we begin tackling the nation’s habit of spending beyond its means,” said the National Taxpayers Union.  FreedomWorks President Adam Brandon stated, "We applaud Representatives Bergman and Case for asking President Biden to set up a commission similar to former President Reagan's Grace Commission, which gave recommendations on bettering the operations of the Executive Branch. They are absolutely correct to cite the national debt as a primary reason why this commission is necessary. Now more than ever, it is critical that our federal government leave no area untouched in looking for ways to address our national debt, no matter how small. We look forward to President Biden answering this call."
“We commend Representatives Bergman and Case for looking to the American people for ideas to improve the federal government’s operations. An engaged public can help both executive branch officials and Congress reduce governmental waste and improve efficiency,” said Maya MacGuineas, President of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. 
"With a debt of more than $27 trillion, it is imperative that a new Grace Commission be established so taxpayers know where their hard-earned dollars are being spent. We applaud Rep. Bergman for this letter, which every member of Congress should support,” said David Williams, President of Taxpayers Protection Alliance.

bergman.house.gov  
###
 
 
 
￼

Subject: Last Night's Vaccine Town Hall
Message:
Thanks for joining us!
￼ 
  Dear Lindsey, 
For those who may not know, I take time to personally call back some of the thousands of community members who contact us every week. These calls provide me an invaluable perspective into what is top of mind for our community. What I noticed this past month in particular is a sharp increase in questions about vaccines: the FDA approval process, safety and efficacy guidelines, our Commonwealth's distribution plan, and more.  In response, I brought together three subject matter experts for a telephone town hall to address your vaccine questions and provide helpful updates for Berks and Chester counties. Our guests were Dr. Benjamin Abella, Attending Physician and Vice Chair of the Department of Emergency Medicine at Penn Medicine, Jeanne Casner, Director of the Chester County Department of Health, and Andrew Sharp, Deputy Secretary for Intergovernmental Affairs in the Governor's office.   Over 1,000 of you joined us for last night's event, and I wanted to thank you for your thoughtful questions. If you did not get to ask your question live due to the high volume of callers, we will be calling you in the next 48 hours to follow up. I'm sending this short note to share the full audio recording of the event and additional resources for those who are interested. If you only have time to skim this message, please note that VA-enrolled veterans 70 and older can now sign up for vaccine appointments at the Coatesville VA. Details below.
 .  .  .

Vaccine Telephone Town Hall

Last Night: Community Town Hall to Discuss Covid Vaccine Distribution
￼
Vaccines are one of the most effective tools we have to contain this virus. I encourage all Pennsylvanians to get the vaccine when it is made available to you. In Congress, I’m working to secure aid for states and localities so that they can more quickly distribute vaccines. 

But even with the vaccine, we must continue to practice social distancing and wear masks to most effectively and efficiently contain and beat this virus. Below is some information about the current state of vaccine distribution in our Commonwealth: 

	•	Pennsylvania is currently in group 1A of the vaccination phase. This includes health care workers, residents of long-term care facilities, persons ages 16-64 with high-risk conditions, and folks 65 and older. An exhaustive list of those who fit under 1A can be found on PA’s vaccine site. 
	•	Those that wish to be vaccinated can pre-register for vaccination on the Chester County vaccination site. Anyone who works or resides in Chester County may pre-register even if they don’t meet the current group criteria. Once you pre-register, you will receive notifications as appointments become available for the COVID-19 vaccine. This will also keep folks updated on the current group phase. 
	•	Constituents living in Berks County can visit the Berks vaccine site to find vaccine providers within the county.
	•	The Coatesville VA is now opening up vaccine appointments to VA-enrolled veterans 70 and older. There are two ways to place interested veterans on the vaccine appointment list: (1) Call 610-384-7711 extension 5705 (or 5706) or (2) Click on this link and scroll to the paragraph where you must sign up to the 'Keep Me Informed' tool for more information. Since the age was just lowered, the official update on the website regarding the age change is forthcoming.
	•	Please contact the PA Dept. of Health if you do not have access to a computer or smartphone at 1-877-724-3258 for more information on scheduling a vaccine appointment. Only folks who fit under the 1A group are being vaccinated at this time, therefore they are the only ones who can schedule vaccination appointments.
To say it has been a difficult year would be an understatement. As a country, we find ourselves in the midst of two crises – a public health and an economic crisis. In order to rebuild our economy, we must do everything in our power to crush this virus. Again, I want to ensure that our office continues to be a source of accurate information during these trying times. Please continue to engage with us and let us know how we can be helpful.
.  .  .

We want to hear from you. Please stay in touch and let us know what you thought of this e-newsletter. As always, we invite you to call one of our offices or message us through our contact form. Feel free to pass this update along to friends of our community so they can keep in touch too. 

Respectfully,
￼
￼

Subject: Espaillat Appointed to House Committee on Education & Labor During 117th Congress
Message:
￼ 
  

PRESS RELEASE
For Immediate Release
February 4, 2021


REPRESENTATIVE ADRIANO ESPAILLAT APPOINTED TO SERVE ON THE HOUSE COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND LABOR DURING THE 117TH CONGRESS 

Speaker Nancy Pelosi Announces New Committee Appointments, Selects Espaillat for Education and Labor Based on Expertise and Experience


WASHINGTON, DC – Representative Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) released the following statement on his appointment by Speaker Nancy Pelosi and approval by the House Democratic Caucus to serve once again on the distinguished House Committee on Education and Labor for the 117th Congress. This appointment comes in addition to Espaillat’s earlier appointment to serve on the powerful Appropriations Committee: 

“Thank you Speaker Pelosi, the House Democratic Caucus, and Education and Labor Committee Chairman Bobby Scott for the privilege to serve on the Education and Labor Committee, marking my second tenure on this distinguish committee,” said Rep. Espaillat (NY-13). “This committee is truly special to me as it was once chaired by the first representative of New York’s 13th Congressional district – the Honorable Congressman Adam Clayton Powell Jr., – and has a very special place in my heart and to the constituents of my district. Under the leadership of Chairman Scott, the official portrait of Congressman Powell was hung in the committee’s hearing room, enshrining his legacy and the impact on our nation, and I was honored to participate in the unveiling ceremony.

“Chairman Scott has never wavered in his conviction and commitment to equity in education and civil rights for all students and workers in this county, and I look forward to working closely with him once again to ensure educational and workforce opportunities thrive while ensuring equity in our education system, supporting and protecting America’s workforce, and expanding access to high-quality and affordable health care that has brought me back to this committee. I am ready to continue my work and look forward to building on the progress the Education and Labor Committee has created for communities around the nation.”

# # # 

Representative Espaillat is the first Dominican American to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives and his congressional district includes Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill and the north-west Bronx. First elected to Congress in 2016, Representative Espaillat is serving his third term in Congress. Representative Espaillat currently serves as a member of the influential U.S. House Committee on Appropriations responsible for funding the federal government’s vital activities. He is also a member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus (CHC), where he serves as the Second Vice Chair and is a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, where he serves as Deputy Whip. Representative Espaillat also currently serves as a Senior Whip of the Democratic Caucus. To find out more about Rep. Espaillat, visit online at https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Media inquiries: Candace Person at Candace.Person@mail.house.gov



DESIGNAN AL CONGRESISTA ADRIANO ESPAILLAT PARA SERVIR EN EL COMITÉ DE EDUCACIÓN Y TRABAJO DE LA CÁMARA DURANTE EL CONGRESO 117º

La líder Nancy Pelosi anunció nuevos nombramientos de comités y seleccionó a Espaillat para Educación y Trabajo en función de su experiencia y conocimientos 


WASHINGTON, DC – El congresista Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) emitió la siguiente declaración sobre su designación realizada por la líder Nancy Pelosi y la aprobación del Caucus Demócrata de la Cámara para servir una vez más en el distinguido Comité de Educación y Trabajo de la Cámara para el Congreso 117º. Esta designación se suma a la anterior de Espaillat para formar parte del poderoso Comité de Apropiaciones: 

“Gracias a la líder Pelosi, al Comité Demócrata de la Cámara de Representantes y al presidente del Comité de Educación y Trabajo, Bobby Scott, por otorgarme el privilegio de servir en el Comité de Educación y Trabajo, que marca mi segundo mandato en este distinguido comité”, dijo el Rep. Espaillat (NY-13). “Este comité es realmente especial para mí, ya que una vez estuvo presidido por el primer representante del distrito congresual 13 de Nueva York, el Honorable congresista Adam Clayton Powell Jr., y tiene un lugar muy especial en mi corazón y para los constituyentes de mi distrito. Bajo el liderazgo del presidente Scott, el retrato oficial del congresista Powell se colgó en la sala de audiencias del comité, preservando su legado y su impacto en nuestra nación, y tuve el honor de participar en la ceremonia de inauguración.

“El presidente Scott nunca ha titubeado en su convicción y compromiso con la equidad en la educación y los derechos civiles para todos los estudiantes y trabajadores en esta nación, y espero trabajar de cerca con él una vez más para asegurar que las oportunidades educativas y laborales prosperen mientras garantizamos la equidad en nuestra sistema educativo, apoyando y protegiendo la fuerza laboral de Estados Unidos, y ampliando el acceso a servicios de salud asequibles y de alta calidad, lo que me ha devuelto a este comité. Estoy listo para continuar mi trabajo y espero seguir avanzando sobre la base del progreso que el Comité de Educación y Trabajo ha creado para las comunidades de todo el país”.

# # #

El congresista Espaillat es el primer domínico-estadounidense en servir en la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos y su distrito congresual incluye las comunidades de Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill y el noroeste del Bronx. Elegido por primera vez al Congreso en 2016, el congresista Espaillat cumple su tercer mandato en el Congreso. El congresista Espaillat actualmente se desempeña como miembro del influyente Comité de Apropiaciones de la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos, responsable de financiar las actividades vitales del Gobierno federal. También es miembro del Caucus Hispano del Congreso (CHC), donde se desempeña como segundo vicepresidente y es miembro del Caucus Progresista del Congreso, donde se desempeña como subcoordinador (Deputy Whip). El congresista Espaillat también se desempeña actualmente como coordinador sénior del Caucus Demócrata. Para obtener más información sobre el congresista Espaillat, visite su portal en línea en https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Preguntas de los medios: Candace Randle Person a Candace.Person@mail.house.gov

Dear Lindsey Cormack,

With the second Senate impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump beginning next week, I wanted to provide an opportunity to preview this historic event and answer your questions with Walter Dellinger, former Solicitor General under President Clinton and an impeachment scholar.  I will be hosting a Facebook Live event for the impeachment trial preview on Monday, February 8, 2021 at 4:30 p.m. You can join on Monday by tuning in at facebook.com/RepDavidEPrice. 
Do you have a question about the impeachment of former President Donald Trump? Enter it here. 
The House of Representatives, in a bipartisan vote, passed one article of impeachment against former President Donald Trump on January 13, 2021. The House managers released a trial brief last week, charging former President Trump with incitement of insurrection for his role in the events prior to and on January 6, 2021. The former President’s legal team will have the opportunity to respond on Monday, February 8th, and the trial will begin Tuesday, February 9th.  
I hope you can join Walter Dellinger and me on Monday, February 8th at 4:30 p.m. on Facebook Live for a preview of former President Trump’s impeachment trial. 
Sincerely, 
￼
David Price
Member of Congress

Subject: Honoring a Fallen Hero
Message:
￼ 
Honoring a Fallen Hero
Dear Friends,
It is with a heavy heart that we mourn the death of a true American hero this week. On January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick was on the frontlines defending the U.S. Capitol from rioters. Like dozens of fellow officers, Sicknick sustained serious injury during the riot, possibly being struck on the head with a fire extinguisher by a still unknown assailant. He later collapsed and was rushed the hospital before tragically dying on January 7.
All Americans should honor the ultimate sacrifice made by Brian Sicknick. He bravely laid his life down to protect his fellow officers, Members of Congress, staffers and support personnel in the Capitol on January 6. My family and I continue to pray for the loved ones he left behind, and all law enforcement injured during the riot.
￼
Photo courtesy of Reuters
Let us never forget that the brave men and women of the U.S. Capitol Police – and all law enforcement agencies across the country – put their lives on the line each and every day to protect and serve their communities. We honor their service and I deeply appreciate the selflessness and valor they exhibit on our behalf.
Law enforcement is still investigating Sicknick’s death – and all violent activity that occurred at the Capitol on January 6. If you have information that could contribute to their investigation, please visit the FBI’s tip line website here.

Virtual Veterans Claims Clinic 
The Atlanta Regional Office of Veterans Affairs will be hosting a Virtual Veterans Claims Clinic on Thursday, February 18, 2021. Veterans, their families, and their survivors will get the chance to speak with representatives from Atlanta’s Regional Office about any new or existing claims. Please be aware that all who would like to participate must make an appointment. Appointments can be made by calling 404-929-3100. More details can be found at https://www.benefits.va.gov/atlanta/. 
Please keep in mind that my staff includes dedicated caseworkers in my district offices ready and eager to assist you deal with the Department of Veterans Affairs. If we can be of any assistance to you, please give us a call at Monroe at 770-207-1776, or Greensboro at 762-445-1776.

Always be Prepared
It’s always a good time to make sure you and your loved ones are prepared for any eventuality. We never know when the next hurricane, tornado, flood, or even snowstorm may be around the corner!
No matter what happens, it’s important that our families are protected in case things go south. Staying informed on upcoming weather conditions and having a communications plan can help you and your family stay safe in what could be an otherwise dangerous situation. 
￼
Photo courtesy of Ready Georgia
NOAA Weather Radios are a great way to track weather conditions and any incoming storms. Your family can set up a communications plan using this handy form on Ready Georgia. My wife, DeeDee, and I have a plan and it’s my hope that you all stay safe and do the same.
Sincerely,

￼
FOLLOW US

During a debate on the House floor today, Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-TX) slammed Democrats for the dangerous precedent they would be setting should they vote to expel Rep. Subject: Helping Our Neighbors Recover From Disaster
Message:
￼

President Joe Biden has officially approved the Emergency Disaster Declaration for Malden and Pine City. Assistance for these communities is on the way so that the families impacted by these wildfires can finally begin to rebuild. The devastation experienced by communities in Eastern Washington during the 2020 wildfire season has left individuals, families, and businesses struggling to piece their lives back together. When I visited Malden and Pine City days after the fire, the devastation took my breath away. The city hall, post office, and fire station were gone. Homes and surrounding farmlands were destroyed.  

The biggest fear I heard when I visited was that after the speeches were over and the news cameras were gone, politicians would forget about Malden. I have worked tirelessly since that visit to make sure that didn’t happen and to push to get these communities the relief they so desperately need.

Governor Jay Inslee transmitted a request for a major disaster declaration for the state, as well as public assistance for Whitman County. I urged both Presidents Trump and Biden to approve this request, and today we received great news that it has finally been approved.
￼

This support is long overdue and I applaud the Biden administration for taking action to approve Governor Inslee’s Disaster Declaration Request. I will continue leading the effort to ensure federal resources reach these communities without delay.

If you or a loved one has been impacted by these wildfires and are in need of assistance, please do not hesitate to reach out to my office.
￼

Extreme environmentalists are threatening our dams and way of life in Eastern Washington again. Do you support breaching the Lower Snake River dams? 
Select one
No, the dams are critical for agriculture and clean energy.
Select
￼
Yes, the dams are unnecessary and should be removed.
Select
￼
Unsure or undecided.
Select
￼
￼

With a new year comes new questions that need answers. It is always important to me to hear what’s on your mind as I work to get results that matter most to the people of Eastern Washington. I would love to hear what questions are on your mind as we look ahead to 2021 and the new challenges we will work to overcome together. 
Submit a Question
￼
￼

With the stroke of a pen, President Joe Biden has officially canceled the Keystone XL pipeline. For this week’s breakdown, I want to focus on why this was the wrong decision to make and how it impacts energy independence in America. 

What is the Keystone XL Pipeline? The Keystone XL Pipeline is an expansion of an already existing pipeline system that stretches thousands of miles from Canada to Oklahoma. This pipeline system was designed to allow the safe transport of oil from Canada and North Dakota to refineries in the Midwest and Texas, where it is processed and refined into petroleum products like gasoline. Part of the Keystone XL, which connects Oklahoma to the Gulf Coast of Texas, is already up and running. The second part, which would connect Canada to Kansas, needs a presidential permit in order to move forward. President Trump issued this permit, but President Biden cancelled it on his first day in office.   

Why is it so important? The short answer? Energy independence, global leadership, and national security. The construction of the Keystone XL Pipeline allows the United States to break free from relying on forgeign countries like China, Russia, and Saudi Arabia for energy sources, and it allows us to supply energy to our global allies. So, not only does the Keystone XL help keep energy prices low at home, but it also helps prevent hostile foreign actors from gaining more power. The importance of U.S. energy independence, global leadership, and national security is something we should all agree on, and it’s something we should be building on, not tearing down.   

What is the economic impact?hat is the economic impact? President Biden’s decision to cancel the Keystone XL Pipeline reportedly has resulted in the immediate elimination of more than 1,000 jobs. Experts predict that this project would have created more than 11,000 American jobs and generated more than $1.6 million in wages. The less Americans working, the more our economy struggles. America must lead on energy and show the world that we can develop it safely while creating opportunities for American families and businesses. 

What does its cancelation mean for Eastern Washington? Individuals, families, and businesses continue to struggle due to the economic hardship brought on by the coronavirus pandemic. The last thing our community needs is a unilateral decision that drives up energy prices, makes it more difficult to put food on the table, and threatens our national security. That’s why I support legislation like the Keystone XL Pipeline Construction and Jobs Act to make sure we continue to lead on this issue, keeping energy costs low for Eastern Washington families and promoting American-led energy innovation. 

￼
￼

This week, the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on our efforts to ramp up vaccine distribution across the country. While the development and approval of several COVID-19 vaccines in less than a year is one of the greatest achievements in American history and modern science, our work is far from over. 

Our committee is leading the charge to oversee and ramp up vaccine distribution with the goal of vaccinating as many Americans as quickly as possible. Together, we can save lives, get our economy back and schools back open, and get our lives back to normal.
￼

	•	Hearing on COVID-19 Vaccines Across America – As Lead Republican on the Energy and Commerce Committee, I attended a hearing on America’s efforts to ramp up vaccine distribution and get as many Americans vaccinated as possible. President Biden said we are at war with the coronavirus, and I agree. We must come together to defeat this virus and get our lives back to normal. 
	•	Hearing on Ramping Up COVID-19 Vaccines, Testing, and Medical Supply Chain – Also this week on the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health was a hearing to find new, innovative ways to build on the success of Operation Warp Speed and improve the medical supply chain all across America. This is a serious challenge we must face head on in order to end this pandemic once and for all. 
	•	Hearing on Protecting Americans From Scams During the Pandemic – Finally, the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Commerce held a hearing today on making sure Americans consumers are safe from scams during the ongoing pandemic. I was happy to invite Traci Pronto to testify about the work Spokane Community Oriented Policing Services is doing to counter these scams. Traci shared how COVID has isolated too many in Spokane, putting them at a higher risk of falling prey to scammers. If you or a loved one have been scammed, I encourage you to contact Spokane COPS by clicking here. 
￼

I recently had the privilege of speaking with members of the 141st Security Forces Squadron at Fairchild Air Force Base. These brave servicemen and servicewomen have worked tirelessly to defend our nation’s capital, and continue working hard to respond to the ongoing pandemic. I hope you’ll join me in extending our sincere thanks for their service and sacrifice. Click here to view more photos. 
￼
￼ ‌ ￼ ‌ ￼ ‌ 
￼

Cathy McMorris Rodgers | 1035 Longworth HOB, Washington, DC 20515

Subject: A quick update
Message:
￼
Dear Friend,
 
I can’t tell you how grateful my family and I are for all of the well wishes we’ve received since I tested positive for COVID-19 last week.
 
Since then, I’ve been quarantining away from my husband and our two girls, and I’m so glad to be able to tell you that as of yesterday, they are still COVID-free. I’ve been feeling many of the typical minor symptoms – body aches, headaches and dizziness, and fatigue – but I recognize how fortunate I am to just be dealing with these less severe effects from the virus.
 
As I mentioned to you last week, I remain hard at work to deliver for our district, and I wanted to take a moment to fill you in on what we’ve been able to get done since I last emailed.
 
One step closer to COVID relief
 
There’s no question that folks right here in our community, across our Commonwealth, and around our country are in desperate need of more relief. For most, those $600 payments were spent weeks ago, unemployment benefits are just weeks from expiring, and affording their kids’ next meal is a constant worry.
 
We took action in the House this week to set up the process to make sure we can get a COVID-19 relief package – a bold one – through the Senate without Mitch McConnell being able to hold it up. We’re working overtime to get that package passed and signed into law by President Biden without any lapses in benefits and with robust investments in vaccine distribution to get shots into arms as soon as possible.
 
There’s no question that we’d rather this package have bipartisan support and that those conversations are ongoing, but I want you to know that nothing will deter us from getting a package that meets this moment across the finish line. If passing more direct payments, extended unemployment benefits, and additional housing and food assistance requires us to go it alone, we’re prepared to do so.
 
In the meantime, my office continues to be a resource to anyone in the Third District who thinks we can be helpful accessing the relief or benefits they’re owed. If we can be helpful, please give us a call at 978-459-0101 or email us at Rep.LoriTrahan@mail.house.gov.
 
Jobs, jobs, jobs
 
Later today, the House will take up and pass the National Apprenticeship Act of 2021, bipartisan legislation that will invest more than $3.5 billion over the next five years to create nearly one million new apprenticeship opportunities for American workers.
 
I’m pleased to report this landmark legislation includes my bill to ensure that small businesses and their workers are able to reap the rewards of these highly lucrative jobs programs.
 
Apprenticeships are one of the most successful ways to jumpstart our economy and get folks back to work. 94 percent of workers who complete a registered apprenticeship are employed at the conclusion of their programs and they earn an average of more than $70,000 annually. But less one percent of workers nationwide have completed an apprenticeship.
 
I’ll vote this afternoon using the House’s proxy voting system to finally change that.
 
Stay safe, wear a mask
 
I know I’ve become a broken record at this point, but I wouldn’t be doing my job both as your representative and as a mom if I didn’t say once again how important it is to continue following the guidelines on social distancing and gatherings.
 
We’re seeing cases start to go down right now, and that’s a testament to how well the vaccines are working already. But we still have a ways to go until we crush this virus, and each of us has an important role to play in making sure we get there as soon as possible.
 
So please, keep wearing that mask, maintaining a safe social distance from others, and staying home whenever you can. We’re all in this together.
 
Warm Regards,
 

￼
  
Lori Trahan
Member of Congress
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
 
P.S. Due to the ongoing public health crisis, my offices will continue to be physically closed. However, my staff and I are teleworking full time and can be reached via phone at 978-459-0101 or by email at Rep.LoriTrahan@mail.house.gov.

Subject: HouseWatch Alert Week of February 5, 2021
Message:
￼

￼
  
Dear Friend:
 
I can’t wait to cheer on the Buccaneers this Sunday in our hometown Super Bowl! Please stay safe while we root on the Bucs to victory.
 
Wednesday, I paid respects to US Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick on behalf of our community. President Biden and Vice President Harris honored Officer Sicknick as well. I felt the weight of the pall that remains over the Capitol and the country as I prayed for Officer Sicknick in the Capitol Rotunda a few weeks after the violent attack at the heart of our democracy. He and the other officers who stood in the breach that day are true heroes.
 
As the COVID-19 pandemic rages on, I am focused on working with President Biden to accelerate vaccine distribution and deliver aid home to support our neighbors in need. We must use every tool at our disposal to crush COVID-19, keep families afloat and help children return to school safely. The Congress will pass a budget resolution this week to clear a path for President Biden’s American Rescue Plan. We must come together to deliver emergency aid to carry us through both the health and related economic crises. Read more about the American Rescue Plan here.
 
I am particularly concerned that Florida failed to plan ahead for vaccine distribution in an equitable way especially for hard-hit communities of color and those without access to a Publix or appointments. This week, I wrote President Biden regarding my concerns with Gov. DeSantis’ disjointed rollout. I am thankful that the Biden Administration has a national strategy – it’s critical that we leave no one behind.
 
My team is working hard to compile the most up-to-date information on vaccines in Tampa and Hillsborough County, and you can access that information here.
  
 
My Committees
 
  
￼
Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health held a hearing entitled "Road to Recovery: Ramping Up COVID-19 Vaccines, Testing, and Medical Supply Chain." In Florida, we have seen a troubling pattern of withholding and censoring data regarding nursing home infections and deaths, overall mortality data and more. Now is the time to increase transparency and strengthen our public health infrastructure, and I’m working in Congress to do so. 
  
￼
The Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Commerce held an important hearing entitled "Safeguarding American Consumers: Fighting Fraud and Scams During the Pandemic." Bad actors continue to try and scam our neighbors throughout the pandemic, and we must take serious action to protect seniors and families and hold fraudsters accountable. 
 
If you believe you have received a solicitation that is a scam, report it to Hillsborough County - Consumer and Veterans Services or the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services by filing a consumer complaint. Call at 1-800-HELP-FLA or 1-800-FL-AYUDA for Spanish speakers, or file a complaint online at FloridaConsumerHelp.com.
  
 
Votes This Week
 
  
￼
H.R. 447 – National Apprenticeship Act of 2021 amends the National Apprenticeship Act to invest in our workforce by prioritizing skills training and increasing access to trade schools. It will connect our Tampa neighbors to better jobs and better wages, as apprenticeship opportunities are direct pathways to high-paying, stable jobs that you can raise a family on. 
  
￼
H.Con.Res. 11 – Establishing the congressional budget for the U.S. Government for fiscal year 2021 and setting forth the appropriate budgetary levels for fiscal years 2022 through 2030: Passage of this resolution will allow for House Democrats to take decisive action and pass the American Rescue Plan to send aid home to families, small businesses, schools, hospitals, and more. It’s critical to crushing the coronavirus, saving lives and livelihoods, and getting our economy back on track.
  
￼
H.Res. 72 –  Removing a certain Member from certain standing committees of the House of Representatives: I support removing Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene from the Education Committee after her harassment of a student victim of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in Parkland, FL came to light. In any other workplace, if someone threatened coworkers, espoused dangerous conspiracy theories and cheered on QAnon, they would be terminated entirely.
  
Thank you to all of our neighbors who joined my telephone town hall yesterday with local experts to answer your questions on COVID-19 and resources available to you. If you missed Wednesday's event, you can watch it here.
 
As always, my office is here to help you at 813-871-2817. Stay safe and healthy. Let’s go Bucs!
  
Sincerely,
￼
  
Kathy Castor
Member of Congress

￼

Subject: February 2021 Squeal Award: Public Health Preparedness Budget a Piggy Bank for Bureaucrats
Message:
￼ 
  

Home  |  Make’ Em Squeal  |  Email Joni  



February 2021 Squeal Award: Public Health Preparedness Budget a Piggy Bank for Bureaucrats  Ernst cracks down on illegal raids of the nation’s pandemic fund  
How does spending millions of dollars on office furniture moves and legal services help stop a global pandemic?   It doesn’t. In fact, it leaves us less prepared.     These are just two of the questionable, and illegal, ways the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) – the agency charged with protecting our nation from public health emergencies – misspent taxpayer dollars during the decade leading up to the coronavirus pandemic. 
This was no accident, folks. The culprits knowingly wasted your tax dollars then misled Congress about it.   Due to a whistleblower, the scheme was uncovered in which a high level official at HHS regularly raided the budget of the department that is in charge of developing public health countermeasures, like vaccines. Bureaucrats were abusing this department as a type of piggy bank to pay for other, unrelated purposes, like news subscriptions and salaries for employees who did not even work in the department!    We aren’t talking about a few dollars here and there, folks. This was a “widespread and well-known” scheme involving tens, possibly hundreds of millions of dollars over a decade, according to a report by the U.S. Office of Special Counsel.    Another name for it is “criminal.” In fact, the HHS Office of Inspector General determined this misuse of funds is a flagrant violation of federal law 

￼
For lying to Congress, misspending millions of taxpayer dollars, and putting the health of Americans at risk, I am awarding my February 2021 Squeal Award to the criminal bureaucrats who got caught stealing from us taxpayers.   I am also introducing the Federal Actors Lying Should be Eliminated (FALSE) Act to fire federal employees who knowingly misspend taxpayer money and falsify information provided to Congress and taxpayers about how your hard earned dollars are being spent.   Washington needs to understand once and for all, it is not just how much you spend, BUT HOW YOU SPEND IT! In the Senate, I’ll continue fighting to ensure transparency, accountability, and results for every dollar Washington takes and spends.

Do you have an example of government waste or inefficiencies that I should take a look at? Send me an email by clicking here. 
Thank you! 
￼

Subject: The Stewart Standard: A Congressional Update
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼
ABOUT  |   CONTACT  |   SERVICES  |   NEWS  |   LEGISLATION  |   ISSUES  |   RESOURCES 
  
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
  
February 5, 2021 
Dear Lindsey,  With forty executive orders in his first ten days, President Joe Biden is undertaking an effort to drastically change the country with the wave of a magic wand – or at least a pen. Rejoining the Paris Accord, canceling the Keystone XL pipeline permit, stopping construction of the border wall, and granting citizenship to millions of illegal aliens, endangers our national security, kills American jobs, and makes us more dependent on our foreign adversaries.
 
Congress must reclaim the power to legislate. The Legislative Branch is designed to make broad policy decisions through deliberation and legislation, with clear checks and balances in place. 
  
￼
  
See what I've been up to below. 
  
 
Mitigating the Threat of China 
 
  
This week, I joined a bipartisan call asking the Senate to hold Governor Raimondo’s confirmation until the Biden Administration gives a clear and direct answer on whether they plan to keep Huawei on the Commerce Department’s Entity List. 
  
￼
  
 
Honoring Ghost Army Veterans 
 
  
This week I introduced the Ghost Army Congressional Gold Medal Act. This bipartisan legislation honors two top-secret WWII U.S. Army units that specialized in tactical deceptions with the Congressional Gold Medal. [ABC 4 News]
 
Using inflatable tanks, mannequins, and decoys, the Ghost Army is credited with saving tens of thousands of lives. Their extraordinary accomplishments and techniques were so groundbreaking that they remained classified for more than 40 years. This bill brings long-overdue recognition and appreciation to these soldiers and their families by awarding them with the Congressional Gold Medal, Congress's highest expression of national appreciation. [KUTV 2 News]
 
Of the 1,100 soldiers that served in this elite unit during WWII, only 11 are still alive today. Among them is 102-year-old Utahn Staff Sergeant Stanley Nance. I joined Lee Lonsberry on KSL Newsradio to discuss my legislation and my efforts to honor these heroes. Click here to listen to the full segment. 
  
￼
  
 
Safe from the Start Act 
 
  
This week I introduced the Safe from the Start Act. This bipartisan bill builds on those values by ensuring children and women across the world are protected from gender-based violence. [KUTV 2 News]
 
America will always defend and support the most vulnerable—at home & abroad. In times of crisis & conflict, Americans continuously step up & show compassion through leading humanitarian efforts. This bill builds on those values by ensuring children and women across the world are protected from gender-based violence.
  
￼
  
 
Western Caucus Vice Chair
 
  
I’m honored to serve on the Executive Committee of the Congressional Western Caucus. With a district mostly composed of rural counties, the issues that this Caucus focuses on directly affect the daily life of my constituents.
 
There’s no organization in Washington, D.C. that works harder on public lands, natural resources, and rural issues. I look forward to working with my colleagues to bring home wins to Utah and the West.
  
￼
  
 
Zion National Receives Federal Transit Grant
 
  
This is great news for our state, the local tourism industry, and the millions who come from across the world to experience Zion National Park. This has been years in the making and I am proud to have worked with local leaders to make this a reality. Click here to learn more. 
  
￼
Click here to keep reading.

Subject: Baldwin Introduces Bill to Protect Workers’ Right to Organize and Make our Economy Work for Everyone
Message:
￼ 


  
Dear Lindsey, 
Today, Senator Baldwin, a member of the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP), helped introduce the Protecting the Right to Organize (PRO) Act, comprehensive labor legislation to protect workers’ right to stand together and bargain for fairer wages, better benefits, and safer workplaces. 
“In Wisconsin and across the country we have seen powerful, corporate special interests, and the politicians that they fund, attack workers’ rights and undermine our labor laws. The result has been a shrinking middle class, rising income inequality, and more economic insecurity for working families,” said Senator Baldwin. “This legislation takes bold action to respect and reward the hard work of the men and women in labor by protecting and strengthening workers’ rights. The PRO Act takes a stand for workers so they can stand together for fair pay, a safe workplace, quality health care, and the dignity of a secure retirement they worked hard to earn.” 
The pandemic has made it clearer than ever that our economy is benefitting the biggest corporations and wealthiest individuals, while failing workers, and in particular women and workers of color. While wages are stagnant for the bottom 50 percent of workers, the top one percent of earners have seen their wages grow by 205 percent. This worsening income inequality has the deepest impact on women and workers of color, who disproportionately have jobs with lower wages and fewer, if any, benefits.  Unions are critical to increasing wages and addressing growing income inequality—with studies showing that union members earn on average 19 percent more than those with similar education, occupation, and experience in a non-union workplace. The PRO Act would reverse years of attacks on unions and restore fairness to the economy by strengthening the federal laws that protect workers’ rights to join a union and bargain for higher wages and better benefits.  
Specifically, the PRO Act would protect the right to organize and collectively bargain by: 
	•	Bolstering remedies and punishing violations of workers’ rights through authorizing meaningful penalties for employers that violate workers’ rights, strengthening support for workers who suffer retaliation for exercising their rights, and authorizing a private right of action for violation of workers’ rights.
	•	Strengthening workers’ right to join together and negotiate for better working conditions by enhancing workers’ right to support secondary boycotts, ensuring workers can collect “fair share” fees, modernizing the union election process, and facilitating initial collective bargaining agreements.
	•	Restoring fairness to an economy rigged against workers by closing loopholes that allow employers to misclassify their employees as supervisors and independent contractors and increasing transparency in labor-management relations.
Read more about Senator Baldwin's PRO Act and how her bill will protect Wisconsin workers’ right to organize and make our economy work for everyone here. 


￼ ￼  ￼  ￼
