Subject: Rep. Grothman Newsletter- Tucson Sector
Message:
￼

 
Tuscon Sector
 
U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) divides our Southern border into nine distinct sectors across the four states that border Mexico by land: Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California. Last Saturday, I returned to Wisconsin after visiting our Southern border in the Tucson Sector of Arizona for two days. This was my first trip to our Southern border this year, but I have been several times in the past. I was able to talk to CBP agents and local law enforcement on the ground, whose insight and firsthand experience at the border is invaluable. I was also able to see the border wall system, including the parts that are not yet finished. We call it the border wall system because it is not just a wall, it is also equipped with sensors, cameras and other technology that assists our agent in their job.
 
The Tucson sector is one of the busiest sectors in the country in terms of illegal immigrant apprehensions and marijuana seizures. In 2006, 33 years into his U.S. Senate career, then-Senator Joe Biden said a fence was needed at our Southern border to stop "tons" of drugs from Mexico. President Trump improved upon this idea and built a border wall system. We still have drugs, arms and immigrants coming illegally into our country from Mexico, so why has now-President Biden changed his mind about securing our border? His ideas are antithetical to the real-world operations at our border and the needs of the agents patrolling it. I will not stop fighting for a secure border and hope that President Biden will realize that the actual situation at our Southern border is vastly different from the reports laid on his desk by Washington bureaucrats.
 
Nonetheless, the recent sweeping changes out of the Biden White House have made our border less safe. The President has, in his first two weeks on the job, ended construction of the border wall system, ended the Migrant Protection Protocols and has begun a crusade to pause Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) deportation of illegal immigrants who already have criminal convictions. I oppose all of these ideas, not because of partisan politics, but because they go against what every CBP agent, ICE agent and local law enforcement officer I speak with at the border tells me is helpful to them. I summed up some of my most recent findings from this trip in this video from a section of the wall that will, for now, remain incomplete.
  
 
￼
 
  
 
Immigration Bill
 
Speaking of immigration, this week, I introduced a bill that will require an individual to be a U.S. citizen in order to receive welfare benefits, such as Medicare, Medicaid and food stamps. According to data from the Census Bureau, it is estimated that my legislation would save taxpayers $60 billion in its first year.
 
This bill will help to encourage more hard-working immigrants to come to America, while discouraging those who only seek to come here to take advantage of our welfare state. A study published in 2015 shows that both legal and illegal immigrant households take advantage of the welfare system far more than native-born households. Moreover, Politifact confirms that half of immigrant families receive some form of welfare.
 
In general, the welfare system in America started with good intentions, but it is in need of a major overhaul. We need to clean it up so those who really do need help get it, but those who are able to work are encouraged to. America is a beacon of prosperity throughout the world not because of our generous welfare system, but by how many jobs we provide for those looking for a better life for their family and themselves.
 
Many of President Biden's unilateral, partisan executive actions have made our borders less safe. He has also promoted amnesty for 11 million illegal immigrants, many of whom would use their new legal status to apply for additional welfare benefits. Now that we have a President whose priorities do not lie with the safety and security of our Southern border, we must ensure America’s welfare safety net does not become a magnet for illegal immigration. I want to give every immigrant a hand-up instead of a hand-out so they too can share the dignity that comes with an honest day’s work, just like my ancestors had when they came to this country.
  
￼
  
 
National Apprenticeship Act
 
In November, the House passed the National Apprenticeship Act. Since the bill was passed in the 116th Congress and was not signed into law, it had to be re-introduced to the 117th Congress.
 
On Friday, we voted on this bill. I again voted no because the bill was not substantially changed and it will not go far enough to help Wisconsin workers. While there were some good provisions in this bill and the name sounds nice, this bill is inadequate for workers and businesses because it recognizes certain apprenticeships and not others. In particular, many apprenticeships used by the construction industry were intentionally left out by the bill's authors. It is not the job of Congress to pick winners and losers, which is what this bill would do.
 
What Congressional leaders, like Speaker Pelosi, need to do is return to regular order and allow we members of the Committee on Education and Labor to hold hearings on the best ways to expand apprenticeships nationwide. The bill that passed today did not have any hearings and was not "marked up" in committee, which means our input as a Committee was denied, which should draw the ire of Republicans and Democrats alike.
 
The only formal public discussion on this bill was the mandatory debate held on the House floor on Friday, just hours before it was passed. You can watch my speech clicking here or on the picture below.
  
 
￼
 
  
 
Weekly Roundup
 
I joined this letter because President Biden is making our border less safe with his executive actions and we members of the House Oversight and Reform Committee need to know what conversations he had with cabinet officials before his decision to halt construction of the border wall system.
  
￼
  
Click above to view the full letter
  
￼
  
Click above to view the full letter
  
￼
  
Click above for more information
  
￼
  
Click above for more information
  
I was glad to have a virtual meeting with the Wisconsin Bankers Association to discuss the Paycheck Protection Program and what Congress can do to further help local communities and the banks that serve them.
  
￼
  
 
Contact Me
 
As your Congressman, I’m here to serve you. If you have any questions please don’t hesitate to reach out to my offices in Fond du Lac and Washington. If you enjoyed this newsletter be sure to forward it to your family and friends so they can stay informed on what I’m doing in Washington and the Sixth District. 
 
You can also stay up-to-the-minute by following me on Facebook (Congressman Glenn Grothman), Twitter (@RepGrothman) and Instagram (@RepGlennGrothman).
  
Sincerely,
￼
  
Glenn Grothman
Member of Congress

Subject: Updates from my first month in office
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website  |  View Online 
￼

 
Dear Friend,
 
This past Wednesday marked the one-month anniversary of my swearing-in to serve the 53rd District in Congress. While my first month didn't start the way I expected – with insurrectionists attacking the U.S. Capitol on my fourth day in office – it is an honor to serve you and all of my constituents.
 
Below are highlights and updates from this past month. Going forward, my team and I will be sending out weekly newsletters to share important updates from San Diego and Washington, D.C. If you know other community members who would enjoy or benefit from these newsletters, please forward this message and encourage them to subscribe at sarajacobs.house.gov. 
 
 
￼
 
 
Committees
 
I am honored to serve on three prestigious House committees: the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, the House Armed Services Committee, and the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee.
 
The House Committee on Foreign Affairs has jurisdiction over foreign assistance, national security developments affecting foreign policy, war powers and the deployment and use of the U.S. Armed Forces, peacekeeping and sanctions, and arms control and disarmament issues. I am proud to serve on the Subcommittee on International Development, International Organizations, and Global Corporate Social Impact and the Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, and Global Human Rights.
 
The House Armed Services Committee has jurisdiction over defense policy, ongoing military operations, the organization and reform of the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy, security cooperation, and humanitarian assistance activities. I am proud to serve on the Subcommittee on Military Personnel and the Subcommittee on Seapower and Projection Force.
 
The House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee acts on behalf of the Democratic caucus to determine membership and leadership of legislative committees and develop the House Majority’s policy priorities. I serve as the Freshman Representative on that committee, having been unanimously nominated by my freshman colleagues and appointed by Speaker Nancy Pelosi.
 
 
Legislation
 
Since entering Congress, I have co-sponsored 24 pieces of legislation, 10 of which have strong bipartisan support. Those bills and resolutions include:
 
	•	H.Con.Res.9 - Honoring the life and legacy of United States Capitol Police Officer Brian D. Sicknick, who was killed defending the Capitol and our democracy on January 6.
	•	H.R. 7 - The Paycheck Fairness Act, addressing gender-based pay disparities and mandating equal pay for equal work.
	•	H.R. 305 - To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Officer Eugene Goodman, whose quick thinking drew insurrectionists away from the Senate Chamber during the January 6 attack on the Capitol.
	•	H.R. 447 - The National Apprenticeship Act, creating one million additional apprenticeship opportunities over the next five years. This bill was originally introduced by my predecessor, Congresswoman Susan Davis.
	•	H.R. 695 - The USPS Fairness Act, repealing the requirement that the United States Postal Service must prepay future retirement benefits for 75 years. The existing requirement, which was enacted by Congress in 2006, is one of the leading causes of the Postal Service's financial difficulties.
 
On January 13, I gave my first speech on the House floor in favor of H.Res. 24, impeaching President Donald Trump for high crimes and misdemeanors. Political violence must always be met with accountability — because without accountability, more violence will follow. That's what I learned during my service at the State Department and the United Nations, and it's what is necessary to protect our democracy.
 
 
￼
 
On February 1, Congresswoman Nikema Williams and I introduced legislation - H.Res. 83 - to censure and condemn Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene and call for her resignation. Congresswoman Greene has repeatedly expressed her support for assassinating elected leaders and has spread harmful conspiracy theories that denigrate the victims of 9/11, the Sandy Hook and Parkland school shootings, and the California wildfires. She has repeatedly made threats against other Members of Congress and is unfit to serve.
 
 
Letters
 
This month, I also joined my colleagues in signing on to more than a dozen letters sent to Congressional leadership and the Biden Administration to make our priorities for the early days of the 117th Congress known. Those include:
	•	With Congressman Ruben Gallego, a letter to then-Acting Secretary of Defense Christopher Miller encouraging an investigation to identify any current members of the military who participated in the attack on the Capitol and to hold them accountable to the highest level under the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ). 
	•	With the Democratic Women's Caucus, a letter to President Biden encouraging the inclusion of $100 billion in reconciliation packages to not only stabilize child care for families and early educators, but also lay the groundwork for moving toward universal child care and early learning.
	•	With Congressmen Peters, Vargas, and Levin, a letter to President Biden requesting that he direct the Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs to share actionable data on vaccinations with San Diego County and the State of California to ensure servicemembers, veterans, and civilian employees are counted in our total vaccination data.
	•	With Congressman Raul Ruiz, a letter to Speaker Pelosi and Budget Committee Chairman John Yarmuth urging the inclusion of a pathway to citizenship for essential immigrant workers and their families, Dreamers, and TPS holders in the COVID-19 reconciliation recovery package given that essential immigrant workers have been key to the health and safety of all Americans during the pandemic.
 
COVID Relief
 
This week, Congress voted to pass H.Con.Res. 11, the fiscal year 2021 budget resolution — a key tool to accelerate the passage of another COVID relief bill. Passing the budget ensures that Congress can act quickly and decisively in the weeks to come to deliver the robust relief that American families, workers, and small businesses need to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and rebuild our economy.
 
In anticipation of that work, I visited a number of small businesses and non-profits with the Equality Business Alliance to hear what they need in the next COVID relief bill. 
 
 
￼
￼
 
I visited the UCSD Health Vaccination Super Station at Petco Park, the Rady Children’s Community Vaccination Clinic, and the Sharp/Chula Vista Super Vaccination Site to talk about how we can accelerate vaccine distribution. 
 
I also had the opportunity to visit a child care provider in Chula Vista and saw firsthand how providers are keeping San Diego kids active and safe.
 
Finally, I met with representatives of PATH San Diego, the San Diego River Foundation, and Kaiser to talk more about our region's homelessness crisis and their work to help people experiencing homelessness who live along the San Diego River. It will be vitally important that our vulnerable populations also receive support in the next relief bill and that our federal response is committed to ending homelessness.
 
 
￼
￼
 
 
￼
 
We're Here to Help
 
My team and I have been hard at work serving our community. If you need assistance with any of the federal agencies, our office may be able to help. While we can't guarantee a favorable outcome, we will do our best to help you receive a fair and timely response.
 
Click here if you need help with a federal agency
 
You can also call our San Diego office directly at (619) 280-5353.
 
Lastly, please encourage your family and neighbors to subscribe to my newsletter, so I can provide them with timely updates. For news throughout the week, you can also follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram at @RepSaraJacobs.
 
Thank you for the honor of serving you.
 
Warmly,

￼
  
Sara Jacobs
Member of Congress

Subject: Nehls Newsletter
Message:
￼
￼
￼


Dear Lindsey,

I wanted to take a moment to share with you a recap of what happened in the month of January in Texas' 22nd District and the United States House.

Peaceful Transition of Power
On January 21, 2021, we witnessed another peaceful transition of power from President Trump to now President Biden. I'm forever grateful for President Trump's service to our nation and all he did to restore the American dream. 

My Freshman Committee Assignments
I was proud to receive both of my committee assignments which will provide me the opportunity to focus on pivotal issues we all care about like highway development, flood mitigation, and taking care of our veterans.
	•	House Committee on Transportation & Infrastructure
	•	House Committee on Veterans' Affairs

Biden's Executive Overreach
President Trump and President Obama in their first 30 days issued 27 executive orders COMBINED. Since taking office on January 21, 2021, President Biden has exceeded President Obama and President Trump combined issuing over 28 executive orders. Many of these are job crippling, government growing orders. He has issued numerous orders that attack our hardworking oil and gas workers at a time when our economy is struggling due to COVID-19. We should be focused on putting Americans back to work, not out of work. I will stand strong in Congress and support our American workers. 

District Office is Open
Our new district office is open! The office is located at 1117 FM 359, Ste 210, Richmond, TX 77406. Come by anytime Monday through Friday 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM and we'll be happy to serve you anyway we can. 

What do you think?
With the start of a new Congress and Administration, I want to hear what your priority is. Please participate in the survey included in this email.
 
Follow my Facebook and Twitter accounts for updates. It's an honor to represent you and the great state of Texas in the United States House of Representatives.  
What issue matters most to you?
By selecting one of the below options you are agreeing to opt-in to receiving Rep. Nehls' Newsletter.
Economy/Taxes 
COVID-19 Response 
Border Security/Illegal Immigration 

Sincerely,

Troy Nehls
Member of Congress

Subject: Invite: Let’s Talk About Monthly Relief for Families
Message:
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT SUZAN  |   HOW CAN I HELP?  |   NEWSROOM  |   ISSUES  |   CONTACT 
INVITE: LET’S TALK ABOUT MONTHLY RELIEF FOR FAMILIES
Dear friend, 
Since the pandemic began, poverty in the U.S. has risen sharply. We need proven solutions to tackle this crisis and help rebuild the middle class, which is why I am fighting for a plan that would give families up to $300 per month per child to help buy groceries, pay for rent, and afford other essentials. I am hopeful that my colleagues in Congress will include key provisions of my proposal in President Biden’s COVID-19 relief bill. 
Curious? Have questions? On Monday at 4 pm PT, I will be talking to Elyssa Schmier from MomsRising about how this plan will help families during the pandemic and the long-term plan to lift millions of children out of poverty.
EVENT PAGE
￼
I hope to see you there!  As always, I am here to help you. If you need assistance at this difficult time, please do not hesitate to contact my Kirkland office at (425) 485-0085. For more updates on what I’m doing for WA-01, you can follow me on social media at the links above.
Stay safe and stay healthy, 
Suzan

Message:

￼

Dear Friend,

I have always kept one motto in my heart as I approach the job of being your representative: Put people before politics. Unfortunately, what we are seeing from the Leaders of the Democratic party is the exact opposite; it is all politics.

This week, Washington Democrats made clear that for all President Biden’s talk of unifying the country, these words were all hat and no cattle. In their first chance to show the country how we can work together, Democrats chose to pass a Budget Resolution that will only go to rescue or reward their political allies in blue state capitals across the country. The plan will ram down billions of dollars in bailouts they have proposed for state governments that have locked down their local economies, told main street to board up, and left families struggling even more to make ends meet. This is wrong...KEEP READING HERE

WHAT'S GREAT IN THE 8TH 

￼

COVID-19 vaccines have arrived in Southern Missouri and several counties have started vaccinating those that are eligible. Please consult CDC.gov/coronavirus for eligibility requirements and check HERE for updates on vaccination sites near you. 

￼

James and Doug Bieller were recognized for their soybean, corn, and wheat farm which has been in their family for over 100 years. Part of what makes Southern Missouri so great are successful family farms like the Bieller's.

￼

The Kennett Police Department held a pinning ceremony to reward several of their officers with a promotion for their hard work and dedication. Congratulations to all awarded officers, and thank you Kennett PD for your continued investment in the safety of our communities.

￼

Area high schools gathered at the St. Vincent De Paul Parish in Perryville for the first annual March for Life Day on Friday. Pro-life activist and musician Tony Melendez gave the keynote address, where he spoke about his life and sang for the group.



 IN CASE YOU MISSED IT

￼
 
I had the opportunity to join John McArdle from the Washington Journal to discuss the outlandish so-called 2021 budget that Congressional Democrats pushed throught the House this week. 

￼

This week I spoke on the House floor in opposition of the blank check Democrat's wrote to fund their progressive wish-list. Their plan for 2021 would dedicate trillions to additional stimulus and further bailout state governments that have forced small businesses to close down, have kept children out of schools and citizens out of their houses of worship.

￼

I was joined by Rep. Jim Jordan and Rep. Tim Burchett on NewsMax TV to discuss Nancy Pelosi and her party trivializing the needs of Americans to pursue a purely political agenda. 

 
 LEGISLATIVE UPDATE

H.Con. Res. 11: A $1.9 trillion budget that Mr. Biden and my democrat colleagues intend to use bailing out leftist run cities and states that have suffered under irresponsible leadership.
PASSED, REP. SMITH VOTED NO.

H.R. 447: Expands the size of government and requires businesses to follow one-size-fits-all federal standards for registered apprenticeships. 
PASSED, REP. SMITH VOTED NO.

Subject: Update on COVID Spending Proposals
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼
Update on COVID 
Spending Proposals
Congress has spent an unprecedented amount of taxpayer money - approximately $4 trillion - on COVID-19 relief aid. The staggering amount is on par with the size of the entire annual federal budget and is equal to about a quarter of our entire annual economy. Moreover, billions of authorized aid remains unspent.
The economy has rebounded well since last April. The unemployment rate has fallen by more than half of what it was then and savings and disposable income rates are currently at or near record high levels. Another round of stimulus checks and other aid will not address the biggest problem facing Americans - concerns about traveling, socializing, and dining out during the pandemic. Getting the vaccine into peoples' arms as quickly as possible does. This is what the federal government must be focused on. Once we've made significant progress on this goal, then Congress can revisit what pockets of the economy still require assistance.
I hope you will take a few minutes to watch the floor speech I delivered this week about the next steps I think Congress should take when it comes to another COVID relief package.
￼
￼
Celebrating Catholic Schools
As a Catholic school parent and graduate, I know firsthand the great work they do. Not only do Catholic schools provide students with an exceptional education, but they help students build a foundation of values. This past year, they've faced unprecedented challenges due to COVID-19, but they've stepped up to provide students with a safe, flexible, and high-quality learning experience. I was proud to support a resolution this week to designate January 31-February 6 National Catholic Schools Week. 
￼
￼
Update on COVID-19
In the past few weeks, Pennsylvania and the rest of the country have experienced a concerning jump in new COVID-19 cases. While vaccines are now available, the threat of this virus is still very real.
It remains important that people continue to follow CDC recommendations: adhere to social distancing guidelines, wash your hands often, and wear a mask if you are heading out. Remember: my mask protects you and your mask protects me.
According to the Pennsylvania Department of Health, across the state as of Friday, February 5, 2021:
	•	Over 16% of all hospital beds were available (pre-COVID, approximately 36.82% of hospital beds were typically available)
	•	Over 73% of ventilators were available
	•	Over 19% of Intensive Care Unit (ICU) beds were available (pre-COVID, approximately 32.6% of ICU beds were typically available)
As of that date, positive cases in Pennsylvania reached 861,674, roughly a 0.5% increase from the prior day, and more than 3,678,224 tests had come back negative. This means just over 81% of Pennsylvanians tested for COVID-19 had a result that came back negative.

For more detailed information about resources available to you, visit the COVID-19 resource page on my website.

Futher Information:

The Centers for Disease Control provides updates on the virus and safety information for the public and healthcare professionals here.

The Pennsylvania Department of Health provides information on the virus and safety precautions here.

I encourage all Pennsylvanians to take this situation very seriously and observe the recommendations developed by the CDC.

Subject: The Budget
Message:
￼ 
  

THE BUDGET

This week, Democrats passed a budget to trigger a process called reconciliation. Reconciliation allows Democrats to pass President Biden's wasteful $1.9 trillion stimulus plan on partisan lines. Americans and small businesses need help as we continue to battle the COVID-19 pandemic, but there is still $1 trillion left from previous stimulus bills Congress has passed. 

In this episode of Buddy's Briefing, we explain the reconciliation process and more. 

￼

Click here for this episode of Buddy's Briefing


HONORING A HERO
Also this week, we honored Officer Brian Sicknick as he laid in honor in the U.S. Capitol. He will forever be remembered as a hero and his sacrifice will never be forgotten. 

￼
We continue to pray for his family, friends and colleagues.

FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CCXCVIII

Monday, February 1, 2021:   I’m in our Savannah office this morning as I have the opportunity to meet with representatives from Skalar Pharma, LLC, an American pharmaceutical company that manufactures active pharmaceutical ingredients (API). 
￼
Rep. Carter meeting with Skalar Pharma, LLC. 
Next, I have a call with our new White House liaison who happens to be from Georgia and has a home on St. Simons Island in our district.  After a great introductory call, I join an Energy and Commerce (E&C) GOP Health Subcommittee virtual call where we discuss issues we want to bring up in the subcommittee this year.  Afterwards, I join in on our daily all-staff conference call before heading out to Nightingale Homecare, Infusion and Pharmacy Services in Savannah where they are administering the COVID19 vaccine. 
￼
Rep. Carter visits Nightingale Homecare, Infusion and Pharmacy Services
Nightingale offers personal support, skilled nursing and respite care and is currently administering both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines to patients throughout South Georgia.  This family owned business originated in Savannah and is providing a great service during this pandemic with the vaccine administration.  Afterwards, I head to Waycross in Ware County where I attend the visitation services for Mr. Burton Carter, who passed away last week.  Mr. Carter, a long time Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) employee, served on the Ware County Board of Commissioners and was actively involved in the community.  

Tuesday, February 2, 2021:  I am happy to join my good friends, Butch Hubbard and Bob Morgan, on the World Famous Butch and Bob show on WIFO in Jesup this morning as we discuss issues in Washington including impeachment and the executive orders that President Joe Biden has issued in his first full week in office.  Afterwards, I head to Richmond Hill in Bryan County where I attend the visitation service for Will Ingram, a veteran of our military who was a civilian engineer at Fort Stewart.  Next, I have a phone conference with E&C Oversight and Investigations (O&I) Subcommittee GOP members to discuss today's hearing on vaccine distribution and administration in the states before heading to Hinesville in Liberty County where I meet with my good friend, Hinesville Mayor Allen Brown, as he brings me up to date on all the good things happening in the area.  Next, I join in on the virtual meeting of the E&C O&I Subcommittee.  Although I do not serve on this subcommittee, I am allowed to waive on to this hearing to ask questions of the expert panel in regards to the distribution and administration of the COVID-19 vaccine.  Later, I head to the airport for my flight to Washington and, once I am at the Capitol, I have a Whip Team conference call before heading to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the week.  

Wednesday, February 3, 2021:   I head to the Capitol Rotunda first thing this morning where I pay my respects to Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick, who was killed during the riots at the Capitol on January 6th. 
￼
Rep. Carter pays respects to Officer Brian Sicknick
After this very emotional visit, I head to the Cannon House Office Building where I attend the organizing meeting for the Budget Committee.  Each of the major committees in Congress have a representative on the Budget Committee and I have been appointed to represent the E&C Committee.  I am excited for this opportunity.  Next, I head back to my office where I join in on our daily all-staff conference call before logging in on an E&C Health Subcommittee hearing on ramping up COVID-19 vaccines, testing and the medical supply chain.  A link to my questions during the hearing can be found here. 
￼
Rep. Carter speaks on the Budget Resolution
After joining in on a Morehouse School of Medicine town hall virtual meeting where we discuss cannabinoid and endocannabinoid research, I head to a conservative Republican Study Committee meeting before heading to the House Chamber where I speak on the budget that is being debated now.  A link to my comments can be found here.  Next, I head to the Longworth House Office Building where I record a public service announcement (PSA) video assuring people that the COVID-19 vaccine is both safe and effective before heading to what turns out to be a four-hour long GOP Conference meeting.  During the marathon conference we break for about 30 minutes and head to the House Chamber where we have our first and only vote series of the day. 
￼
Rep. Carter films a PSA encouraging Americans to get the COVID-19 vaccine
After the conference, I head back to my office where I have the honor of virtually joining the University of Georgia College Republicans as I am the guest speaker at their monthly meeting. 

Thursday, February 4, 2021:  We have our organizational meeting for the Doctor’s Caucus this morning and this session we elect as our co-chairs, Rep. Andy Harris (R-MD), an anesthesiologist, and Rep. Brad Wenstrup (R-OH), a podiatrist.  Our numbers in the Doctor’s Caucus have grown significantly this session and we have been successful in placing our members on key committees in Congress.  Afterwards, I head to the House Chamber where I pay tribute to Dr. Karla Sapp, Ken Griner, Sen. Mack Mattingly, and Stephen Tootle.  A link to my tributes can be found here, here, here and here.  Once back in my office, I have a virtual call with representatives from the National District Attorneys Association before having a Facetime call with Ryan Beamon, a student at Savannah Country Day School (SCDS) as I surprise him with the news that he has received an appointment to the U.S. Military Academy.  After our weekly Georgia delegation lunch, I join in on an E&C Consumer Protection and Commerce (CPAC) Subcommittee meeting where we discuss fighting fraud and scams during the pandemic.  A link to my questions can be found here. 
￼
Rep. Carter hosts a telephone town hall with special guest Rep. Jason Smith
Next, I head to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the day and, after working in my office, head back to the House Chamber for more votes.  Once back in my office, I have a phone conference with Dr. Chris Shuren with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to discuss the status of over the counter hearing aid regulations.  Afterwards, I have a Telephone Town Hall with my special guest, Rep. Jason Smith (R-MO), who is the Ranking Member of the Budget Committee, before heading back to the House Chamber for our third and final vote series of the day.

Friday, February 5, 2021:  I’m on the radio early this morning as I join my good friend, Bill Edwards, on Newstalk 1290 in Savannah as we discuss yesterday's action by the Democratic majority to strip my Georgia colleague, Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, of her committee assignments due to social posts and comments she made prior to her being elected to Congress.  Afterwards, I head to an E&C GOP full committee planning session before heading to the House Chamber where I speak in opposition to the National Apprenticeship Act. 
￼
Rep. Carter speaks on the National Apprenticeship Act
A link to my comments can be found here. Next, I head to the Capitol grounds overlooking the National Mall where I film this week’s edition of Buddy’s Briefing before heading back to the office where I join in on our daily all-staff conference call.  Next, I have a virtual interview with Gray TV to discuss the budget process and how the Democrats are using budget reconciliation to pass the next COVID-19 relief package before heading to the House Chamber for our first of 6 votes today.  In between the votes, I head back to my office where I have a virtual interview with WTOC-TV in Savannah to discuss the budget process and actions taken to strip Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) of her committee assignments.  Once our vote series is completed, I head to the airport for my return trip home. 

VOTES IN THE HOUSE THIS WEEK

Click here for this week's vote sheet in the House.

Subject: COVID-19 Vaccine Updates, Other Important News.   Plus, Go Bucs!
Message:
February 7, 2021
 

Dear Neighbor, 
 
Today is the big day! Best of luck to our very own Tampa Bay Buccaneers as they compete in the first ever Hometown Super Bowl! I know many of us are looking forward to an exciting evening for our favorite team and our community. I predict a big Bucs’ win!
 
Unfortunately, I am not so optimistic about the American people continuing to win under this new administration. Our country has serious problems and remains deeply divided. We need to come together and find areas of agreement rather than continuing to stoke political division. However, since taking office, President Biden has unilaterally taken 42 Executive actions on highly controversial issues which further divide our nation. This is far more than his recent predecessors in either party. 
 

Now, he and Congressional Democrats are contemplating the use of a special budget procedural maneuver to avoid having to negotiate with Republicans on another new stimulus package. While more targeted relief measures may indeed be needed to improve vaccine distribution and help those who are still struggling to recover from the pandemic, there has not even been a serious discussion about how much of the billions of dollars of federal funding already allocated has yet to be dispersed. Consider these important figures:

First Pandemic Supplemental - $8 billion 
Families First Coronavirus Response Act-$192 billion 
CARES Act- $1.72 trillion 
Paycheck Protection Program and Health-$483 billion 
Consolidated Appropriations Act FY 2021- $1,043 trillion 
Proposed New Biden Stimulus - $1.9 trillion
Higher Debt Interest from 5 previous and 1 proposed pandemic relief measure- $400 billion 
Total Allocated and Proposed Measures- $5,747 trillion 
Total Amount of Previously Allocated Funds Already Dispersed - ? 

We have not examined which prior relief programs are working and those which are not reaching targeted goals. For example, I am a strong supporter of public education. We have allocated billions of funding to help students safely return to the classroom and yet more than half of the states in our country have not reopened in-person learning sites. In Florida, we followed the science and school has been back in session all year. The science said it was relatively safe to have students and teachers return to the classroom, with appropriate safeguards in place, especially when weighed against the very real socio-emotional and educational concerns associated with not re-opening in person learning opportunities. We have seen very few problems with COVID-19 transmission in our classrooms, but the burden of managing that process and paying for those safeguards has largely fallen to state and local governments. We have not seen a large influx of federal funding to support the safeguards that were necessary to re-open classrooms, even though billions of dollars have been allocated. It is logical to ask where the allocated funds have gone and why we need to appropriate $170 billion more for education through this new stimulus proposal, especially if there are not imminent plans to follow the science and immediately re-open schools throughout the country.  

Last week, I joined my colleagues on the Energy and Commerce Committee to officially request this type of information of the Biden Administration. Informed decision-making is critical for ensuring that any future legislative measures will meet the needs that exist. Instead of asking these important questions, the relief measure being pushed quickly through Congress ushers in long-standing Democratic priorities such as bailing out local and state governments for non-pandemic expenses, raising the federal minimum wage, and extending federal unemployment benefits through the end of 2021.    

The actions taken during the past two weeks do not reflect a commitment to heal the nation and find common ground.  I remain focused on working across party lines to find common sense solutions that will help all Americans during this difficult time.
 
Please continue reading for some important information. 
 

Vaccinating Seniors and Strengthening our Medical Supply Chain
    
I know that the vaccination distribution process continues to be confusing and frustrating for many local seniors. Currently, it is important to realize that seniors have a few primary options for getting a vaccination. If they live in Pasco, they can register through the Pasco health department's CDR system and then log in to try to obtain an appointment once those slots are released on Sundays at 2:00 p.m. They can also pre-register through the state's new process, reserve their space in line for a vaccine and be notified when a dose is available. I was relieved to see Pinellas County announce improvements to its vaccination process. Hopefully these changes will make it easier for seniors. Additionally, Publix locations in Pasco and Pinellas are now offering seniors the COVID-19 vaccine. You can learn more about how to register through Publix here. I am continuing to share your feedback with the state and local officials who have jurisdiction over this process and believe it will continue to improve. 

As noted in this local news report, I am glad to see that the state of Florida received more than 300,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccine last week- a more than 40,000 increase from our previous weekly allocation from the federal government. I will continue to advocate for additional doses for Florida, and for an expansion of the federal pharmacy program.  

As part of the federal effort to expand access to the COVID-19 vaccine and after months of groundwork, the CDC has activated the Federal Retail Pharmacy Program. While additional details are still being finalized, an initial one million doses of vaccine will be sent to participating pharmacies around the nation on February 11th. Participating pharmacies in Florida include: Publix; Walmart and Southeastern Grocers. This program will run in tandem with the Pharmacy Partnership for Long-Term Care Program, a program used to prioritize vaccination of seniors in long-term care facilities. It is separate from the allocation each state is receiving from the federal government for distribution. These state allocations are currently being distributed through a variety of locations including: local health departments, state sites, and Publix. I will continue to support all efforts to increase circulation of the vaccine to Floridians and will share more information when it becomes available.

Many constituents have asked how people under 65 with severe medical conditions can sign up for COVID-19 vaccination. Here is some limited information. Once more information is available, I will share it. 

During last week’s Health Subcommittee hearing, I discussed the work being done to improve seniors’ access to a COVID-19 vaccine and the fact that our state needs more doses for distribution. I also highlighted the need to modernize our nation’s emergency supply chain to ensure we are less dependent on foreign governments during future emergencies. Click here to listen to my exchange with panelists.  
 
 

Consumer Protection Connection
 
During this week’s kick off meeting of the Consumer Protection and Commerce Subcommittee, we examined the scams that bad actors have used during the COVID pandemic to exploit seniors and other vulnerable populations. During my remarks, I highlighted the disgusting example in Pasco County in which someone made a fake Eventbrite account to sell phony vaccine appointments to seniors. We must do all we can to educate vulnerable populations about these duplicitous scams, put safeguards in place to protect the public, and prosecute those who perpetrate these crimes. Click here to listen to my remarks. 
Sadly, this local news report highlights how scammers are seeking to exploit vulnerable populations desperate to obtain a COVID-19 vaccine. Remember, by law, all COVID-19 vaccines are to be made available free of charge, without co-payments or deductibles, including for those who are uninsured. 

Additionally, this story serves as a good reminder that exploitation often comes from unexpected sources. Remember, nursing home and ALF providers are not legally allowed to take seniors’ stimulus checks. Any incidence of theft should be reported to the Florida Attorney General’s office.  
 
 

Fighting Childhood Cancer
 
Pediatric cancer remains the number one disease that leads to the death of American children. While survival rates have improved for some types of pediatric cancers, thousands of children are lost to cancer each year and many more encounter life threatening complications related to harsh chemotherapies. Children have significantly fewer treatment options than adults and oftentimes must rely on treatment regimens developed for adults because pediatric-specific treatments simply do not exist for many pediatric cancers and rare diseases. 
 
The Gabriella Miller Kids First Pediatric Research Program at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) is working to facilitate a better understanding of pediatric cancers and holds the promise for the development of better treatments and possible cures. As a longtime advocate for children and rare disease patients, I was proud to co-author bipartisan legislation last week which will provide a new funding source for this successful program.  

Specifically, our new bill will redirect penalties levied against pharmaceutical, cosmetic, supplement, and medical device companies by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for violating the Foreign Corrupt Practice Act (FCPA) towards the Kids First program. In recent years, hundreds of millions of dollars in penalties have been levied against these companies, and the Gabriella Miller Kids First Research Act 2.0 will help channel those funds directly to critical medical research focused on children. 
 
 

Facilitating Economic Recovery

Right now, we should be focused on helping Americans get back to work, rebuild their businesses, and safely send their children back to school.  I am disappointed to see so many Executive Actions taking us in the opposite direction. 
 

However, we are seeing some encouraging signs for our local economy. For example, I am glad to see projections that our local housing market will continue to remain strong this year.  
 

Additionally, the recent announcement of Moffitt’s new research facility in Pasco County is another exciting economic development opportunity for our entire region. Moffitt's expansion project is expected to support 14,500 new jobs and will help the hospital continue critical research as it seeks to prevent and cure cancer. 
 
 

Protecting our Children 
 
There is no higher priority than keeping our children safe. By providing high quality screening and prevention training to school staff and peers, we can identify threats before they materialize, and ensure that those who are at risk get the mental health treatment they need. I have seen first-hand how effective these programs can be when I visited a high school in Pinellas which has already implemented these best practices. Sadly, some communities in my district are among those with the highest suicide rates in our state, and the pandemic has only exacerbated the problem. With training like this, we can help reverse that troubling trend, which is why my colleagues and I re-introduced the STAND-UP Act last week. Click here to learn more.  
 
 

Helping our Heroes

Veteran unemployment rates have been disproportionately high throughout the pandemic. I am hosting a Veteran Employment Fair later this month in order to connect Veterans, Guard and Reserve members and spouses of Veterans and active duty personnel with available positions in our community. Please feel free to share this information as appropriate. 
 
 

Community Concentration 

My team recently had the opportunity to participate in a briefing on Human Trafficking which featured speakers from the FBI, U.S. Attorney’s Office- Middle District and Department of Homeland Security. These agencies are working in a coordinated manner to identify cases and support victims. Unfortunately, studies have shown that human trafficking rates historically spike when cities host large-scale events. As we prepare to host today’s Super Bowl, we can all do our part to remain alert and report any suspicious activity to law enforcement. 
 

My team had the privilege of participating in the recent graduation of the Pasco County Housing Authority’s Self Sufficiency Program. Every program graduate was able to leverage the skills learned to realize the dream of home ownership. Congratulations to each of these families and best wishes for your continued success.﻿
 

Additionally, my team enjoyed participating in the Grand Opening of HD Real Estate Company with the North Tampa Bay Chamber last week. Congratulations to owner Ray Hendricks and best wishes on his continued success. 
 
 

Constituent Corner

I recently received this message from a constituent in my district. 

On Friday January 22nd, we sent a letter requesting the Congressman’s assistance with resolving a delay in our son’s security clearance. Our son called us the following Tuesday to report that he’d been given his clearance! Not even two full business days later!  At first, we thought it must just be a coincidence, but no, it was one phone call from the Congressman’s office!  If that’s not amazing, I don’t know what is! Congressman Bilirakis and his staff care and get things done. We are thankful to have him to call upon in a situation like this where you feel like you have no control and there’s nothing you can do. Maybe we can’t, but he sure can! Thank-you Congressman Bilirakis and all the hard-working and caring staff in your office. Especially Rob, who reached out to follow-up with us.  We are truly grateful. 

This is just one example of the work we do each day. Constituent services are a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you!

Sincerely,
 

Gus Bilirakis
Member of Congress
 
 

Rep. Gus Bilirakis | 2354 Rayburn HOB, Washington, DC 20901

Subject: Advocating for You
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website  |  View Online 
￼

 
Dear Friend,  
I am happy to return to your inbox with my new newsletter!
 
I am thrilled to announce that I have been selected to serve on the esteemed United States House Ways and Means Committee. As the first West Virginia Representative to sit on the Committee in 72 years, I will continue to advocate for the modernization and revitalization of our region through increased foreign investment and trade. I look forward to working with my fellow Committee members to advance policies on trade, taxes, and health care that affect West Virginians every day.
 
January was a challenging month for our country. Violence of any kind has no place in the United States of America. I thank you for your prayers and support on that awful day for democracy.
 
One silver lining of last month was that I had the chance to meet with the West Virginia National Guard while they were in Washington protecting the Capitol. From safeguarding Congress, to vaccinating West Virginians, thank you for all you do to keep us safe. Keep up the good work!
 
￼
 
I am so proud that West Virginia is leading the nation in COVID-19 vaccine distribution. Governor Justice and our National Guard have done a phenomenal job with this effort, which is why I led a letter with my West Virginia colleagues to the Biden Administration asking that it prioritize our state in the next vaccine allocation. We must provide our high-risk citizens, frontline workers, and all who are eligible with this vaccine. Read my full letter here.
 
Back at home, we officially made the New River Gorge a National Park and Preserve! The New River Gorge is home to everything West Virginia has to offer -- our beauty, small businesses, and adventurous tourism opportunities. I am so excited about this new designation that will preserve and protect the New River Gorge for generations to come.
 
I promise to never stop fighting for you, your family, and your businesses. With your help, we will continue to make West Virginia the best state in the nation to live, work, and raise a family.
 
You, and those around you, will be in my prayers. Please reach out to any of my offices if we can be of assistance.
 
Sincerely,
 

￼
  
Carol D. Miller
Member of Congress

Subject: #LowcountryFirst Newsletter: Congress Needs to Stop Wasting Time and Do Their Jobs
Message:
#LowcountryFirst Newsletter | February 5th, 2021
￼

Congress Needs to Stop Wasting Time and Do Their Jobs

Friends,
 
I hoped to spend this past week working in DC with my colleagues on the most pressing issues Americans are facing today, including: a new COVID-19 relief package, getting our kids back to school, and boosting vaccine distribution.  
 
But unfortunately, I wasn't able to spend nearly enough time on these crucial challenges. 
 
Our time on YOUR dime was wasted talking about the loudest, most unhinged voices in the room. Frankly, this week in Washington was like watching an episode of Jerry Springer.  
 
To be clear, the embrace of QAnon, conspiracy theories, or any other extreme, racist, bigoted, or violent views will always get a forceful condemnation from me. Like many of you, I firmly believe such toxic rhetoric and behavior has absolutely zero place in America, let alone in Congress. I've condemned Members who peddle this lunacy, no matter their party, at every opportunity.  
 
I am tired of wasting the time you pay me to use to address the serious challenges facing our nation. It’s past-time to prioritize the needs of everyday hard-working Americans. It’s time to get to work. 
 
Sincerely, 
￼

Congresswoman Nancy Mace

Subject: Rise and Shine! It's Sunday!
Message:
02/07/2021
Weekly Update Vol. 1 Issue 4


﻿
￼
￼

CONGRESSWOMAN MARIA ELVIRA SALAZAR'S WEEKLY UPDATE

This week, I participated in my very first Committee hearings on the House Committee on Foreign Affairs and the House Committee on Small Business. 

On the Foreign Affairs Committee, I opposed the slashing of the Western Hemisphere subcommittee. Did you know that Miami's largest trading partners are ALL in the Western Hemisphere? Brazil, Colombia, Canada, Mexico, and Chile. This is offensive to our community. In fact, The Miami Herald published an article about this deeply disturbing move to cut this subcommittee in half. 

I will always fight tirelessly for our American values of freedom, democracy, and respect for Human Rights. Pursue sanctions against the brutal regimes in Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua and strengthen our relationships with our allies and regional partners like Israel, Colombia, and Taiwan. 

On the Small Business Committee, I was selected to serve as the Ranking Member on the Subcommittee on Contracting & Infrastructure. In this role, I'll have the opportunity to guide our community through the burdensome federal government procurement process. I am absolutely committed to working in a bipartisan fashion to assist our struggling small business owners and deliver COVID-19 relief as soon as possible. From Flagler St to Calle Ocho and from Collins Avenue to Miracle Mile, our small businesses have been seriously impacted by the pandemic and I will never stop fighting for our local job creators. 
￼

I look forward to continue addressing your cases, reading your letters, and responding to your comments on Social Media. Please continue to let me know what your thoughts are and never hesitate to reach out to my office. My team is more than happy to assist you with any of your concerns and guide you through any challenges you may have with our federal agencies. 

It is truly the honor of a lifetime to fight for YOU in the halls of Congress.

I WAS SELECTED AS THE RANKING MEMBER ON THE SUBCOMITTEE ON CONTRACTING & INFRASTRUCTURE
￼

Honored to share with you all that I was selected by my colleagues to serve as the Ranking Member on the House Small Business Subcommittee on Contracting & Infrastructure! 

I will fight tirelessly so that our local job creators can access our federal procurement programs!

I SPOKE TO TELEMUNDO's NATIONAL NETWORK
￼

Always great to speak to my friend and colleague, Cristina Londoño, with whom I worked with at several national television stations during my days as a journalist. Always great to share my priorities with Telemundo's audience and our many Spanish-speaking constituents in our district. 

I VOTED FOR THE NATIONAL APPRENTICESHIP ACT 
￼

I helped to expand the National Apprenticeship Program and help get Americans Back to work. 

I voted for this legislation because it focuses on increasing access to education and skills training, promoting entrepreneurship, and strengthening infrastructure. 

This bill will invest over $3.5 billion to provide nearly one million new apprenticeship opportunities and update the original National Apprenticeship Act to meet twenty-first century standards. 

This will assist our efforts to get South Floridians back to work 

NEED THE COVID-19 VACCINE?
CLICK HERE TO PRE-REGISTER

Miami-Dade County has launched a pre-registration system for seniors 65+ and healthcare workers, who will be able to register at any time. Eligible individuals who pre-register will be contacted at a later time to schedule appointments for vaccines as slots become available.
 
If you or a loved one would like to pre-register, please click on the link or call (305) 614-2014

Subject: The Rice Report
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
 
Friends,
Black history is American history. This Black History Month, we honor the contributions, achievements, and influence of those who came before us and shaped America into the nation we are today.
Dr. Matilda Arabelle Evans was born in Aiken, South Carolina in 1872.  In 1897, she became the first African American woman licensed as a physician in South Carolina.She opened Columbia's first hospital for African-Americans and fought to provide free medical exams for public schoolchildren. She also had a thriving independent practice where she cared for patients of all classes and color. Six children were abandoned at her practice and she raised them all, along with five children orphaned by relatives who had died. Dr. Evans was elected president of the Palmetto State Medical Society and vice president of the National Medical Association, and in World War I was appointed to the Volunteer Medical Service Corps.
 

￼
 
 
Covid-19 Vaccines
 
 
Beginning Monday, February 8, any South Carolina resident aged 65 or older, regardless of health status or preexisting conditions, can begin scheduling their appointment to receive COVID-19 vaccine.
To find a location to receive a vaccine, click here.
 

 
 
Ways and Means Subcommittees
 
 
I look forward to continuing to serve on the Select Revenue Measures and Trade Subcommittees, and I am honored to have the opportunity to serve on the Ways and Means Social Security Subcommittee. My focus in Congress has always been American Competitiveness. I’ll continue to use my experience as a CPA and tax lawyer to tackle issues that matter to the 7th District of South Carolina and the US, including job creation, increasing opportunity, and growing our economy.
The House Committee on Ways and Means is the oldest committee of the United States Congress, the only one specifically mentioned in the Constitution, and is the chief tax-writing committee in the House of Representatives.  The Committee exercises jurisdiction over revenue and related issues such as tariffs, reciprocal trade agreements and the bonded debt of the United States.  Revenue-related aspects of the Social Security system, Medicare and social services programs also fall within the Ways and Means’ purview.
 

 
 
Big Tech Censorship
 
 
I sent a letter to Speaker Pelosi regarding Big Tech Censorship of conservative voices asking that she bring forth legislation to protect all Americans. 
You can read the letter here.
 

 
 
Diabetes Caucus
 
 
I recently joined the Diabetes Caucus! Approximately 500,000 South Carolinians have diabetes, and it is the 7th leading cause of death in South Carolina. I look forward to working on legislative activities that would improve diabetes research, education and treatment.
 

￼
 
 
Have a great week!

Sincerely, 
￼
 
Tom Rice

Subject: Dave's Weekly Wrap
Message:
￼
￼

Friends,

It’s become increasingly clear that the number one need right now in the battle against COVID-19 is vaccine distribution. It's critical that Congress act quickly to address this need - the lives and livelihoods of the American people are at stake.
￼

That's why my colleagues and I on the Problem Solvers Caucus called for an immediate vote on a standalone "Defeating COVID-19" vaccination distribution package.

The reality is that billions of dollars from the previous COVID relief packages remain unspent. So, instead of wasting our time with a partisan back and forth on yet another stimulus bill, we should be focusing on a targeted package that directly addresses our nation's number one need while relief from the stimulus package passed in December continues to be distributed.

I urge the Biden Administration and my fellow colleagues in Congress to work together and immediately pass this targeted, bipartisan package without any extra add-ons so that we can prioritize the health of the American people, defeat this virus, get our kids back in school, and safely reignite our economy.

Learn more about our plan here. 

Supporting Drug-Free Communities Coalitions during COVID-19


While we continue to administer COVID-19 vaccinations and rein in the pandemic, we cannot turn a blind eye to the ongoing crisis caused by addiction and substance use disorder. That's why, this week, I introduced H.R. 654, the Drug-Free Communities Pandemic Relief Act, alongside my friend and colleague on the other side of the aisle Rep. Derek Kilmer (WA-06). 

Our bill would provide flexibility to Drug-Free Communities (DFC) coalitions during the COVID-19 pandemic by temporarily allowing the Office of National Drug Control Policy the authority to waive the program’s local matching requirements if the grantee is unable to meet them due to the ongoing pandemic. To put it plainly, this bipartisan legislation would give the DFC program the flexibility it needs to continue its life-saving work during these difficult times.
￼

The DFC program, which was created by legislation authored by then-U.S. Rep. Rob Portman in 1997, is a proven, evidence-based, and community-oriented program that has helped us combat the opioid crisis at the local level and has made a tremendous difference in the lives of countless young Ohioans. No other drug prevention program has achieved the same reduction in youth drug use that the DFC program has consistently achieved.

﻿I urge the House to act quickly on this bill so that we can ensure youth addiction prevention programs have the resources to conduct effective outreach in our communities during the ongoing pandemic.

Stepping Up to Better Serve Our Nation's Veterans

While there has been significant progress in reducing veteran homelessness over the last decade, it’s estimated that on any given night, nearly 40,000 veterans across the country are sleeping on the streets, in shelters, or in tents and stairwells. That's simply unacceptable. We cannot allow the brave men and women who have so selflessly served our country to slip through the cracks. 

That's why I joined my colleagues Anthony Gonzalez (OH-16) and Kathleen Rice (NY-04) in introducing the bipartisan Improving Housing Incomes for Veterans Act. This bill, which has the support of the American Legion, the Paralyzed Veterans of America, and The Fleet Reserve Association, will help local service providers collaborate more effectively with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and streamline the processes necessary to help house America’s veterans and increase their access to affordable housing. 

Since being introduced, our bipartisan, commonsense bill has been referred to the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs. I'm hopeful that it will soon progress out of the committee and receive a vote on the House floor. 

A Fun Snow Day on the National Mall

While we didn't get hit quite as hard as Ohio, Washington got some decent snow this past week. And that made a certain Golden Retriever very happy. 
￼

Thinking about our fun snow day on the National Mall is distracting me from the fact that the Browns didn't make it to the Super Bowl. Here's to hoping you have an uplifting memory from this week that does the same for you!

God bless and stay well,

Dave

Dear Friends,

This week in Washington, I introduced an important piece of legislation that will place maximum pressure on Iran and its leaders to help expose the corrupt nature of Iran’s dangerous regime. Learn more here. In addition, House and Senate Democrats are trying to speed President Biden’s $1.9 trillion COVID-19 plan through both chambers, even though we just passed a COVID relief package just one month ago. We do not need to pass another costly bill until all previous funds are used. Catch up more on my week by clicking here or the photo below.
￼

The historic decision to move the United States embassy in Israel to Jerusalem sent a powerful message to the world that the U.S. officially recognizes Jerusalem as the unequivocal capital of Israel. This week, I urged Secretary Blinken to stand by our great ally and friend, Israel, and keep the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem.
￼
￼

This Saturday, on his birthday, we remembered the legacy of President Ronald Reagan. We honor his leadership, courage, and may his conservative legacy continue to inspire us all.

Latest News
Joining the Veteran Affairs Committee
￼
The House
 Republican Steering Committee has announced I will serve on the House
 Veterans’ Affairs Committee during the 117th Congress. The Third
 Congressional District of North Carolina contains the sixth most veterans
 of any congressional district in the U.S. 
It’s an
 honor to represent the 89,000 veterans who live in the Third District on
 the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee. Our veterans have
 selflessly served our great nation and deserve the benefits that their
 service has earned them. So I am especially thrilled to have another avenue
 to regularly advocate for the veterans in eastern North Carolina as
 well as the nation at large who have given so much for our
 country.

Opposing Budget Reconciliation
On Wednesday, the House passed H. Con. Res. 11, the FY2021 Budget Reconciliation Resolution, which began the budget reconciliation process. Budget reconciliation is a legislative procedure which can circumvent the 60-vote threshold needed to pass legislation in the Senate. It can only be used for fiscal policy matters and is typically reserved for partisan issues. Democrats intend to use budget reconciliation to attempt to pass a $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief package. I opposed it when it came to the floor for a vote. 
Joe Biden’s White House meeting with Senate Republicans the other day was obviously just a publicity stunt to give the impression of unity while continuing to ram through his radical, progressive agenda. Not a single portion of his proposed bill was changed after that meeting. He and Congressional Democrats have no intention to work with Republicans.
Further, if Joe Biden actually wanted this legislation to be bipartisan, then he wouldn’t have included a far-left non-starter $15/hour minimum wage hike. We should be looking to create more jobs, not get rid of them. More than doubling the minimum wage would destroy 1.3 million jobs according to the CBO, which is the last thing our economy needs right now.
After failing to codify their radical ungermane partisan riders in COVID-19 legislation during the last Congress, Democrats are continuing to use the same playbook in this Congress. I will fight against it during this term just as I did in the last.

Urging President Biden not to re-enter the Iran Nuclear Deal
￼
This past week, I led 51 other House Republicans in sending a letter to President Joe Biden urging him not to re-enter the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), commonly known as the Iran Nuclear Deal. Originally adopted during the Obama Administration in 2015, President Trump withdrew the United States from the JCPOA in 2018. During his presidential campaign, Biden indicated he would rejoin the agreement.
Not only was the Iran Nuclear Deal a failure to begin with, the facts on the ground have dramatically changed since it was signed and subsequently pulled out of by the Trump Administration. The max-pressure campaign used by President Trump has worked. Iran’s economy is crippled, their people are protesting more boldly than they have in 50 years, their top general has been taken out, and the power balance has shifted in the Middle East as more and more countries have begun normalizing ties with Israel. These are all major developments for the better for ours and Israel’s national security.
If President Biden decides to make any new agreement with Iran, then it must be contingent on Iran ending their explicit state sponsorship of terrorism. The United States cannot under any circumstances indirectly fund the killing of American soldiers and innocent people as we did under the JCPOA.
I thank my many colleagues who joined me in this effort. Together, we will fight tooth and nail against appeasing the terrorist Iranian regime.

Preventing terrorists from getting vaccines before American citizens
Last Monday, I became an original co-sponsor on a resolution opposing the Department of Defense's plan to vaccinate inmates at Guantanamo Bay against COVID-19 before more at risk American residents are vaccinated. The resolution opposes vaccinating these prisoners before American citizens and asserts American citizens should be prioritized in the vaccination process.
The fact that the Biden Administration was even thinking about providing COVID-19 vaccinations to known terrorists before American citizens is simply beyond comprehension. I fully support protecting our American soldiers and getting them vaccinated. But why on earth would we divert our resources from the elderly and minority populations in this country in favor of terrorists and enemy combatants? Placing the health of our own citizens over terrorists should not be a partisan issue. The temporary "pause" the Pentagon has put on these plans should immediately be made permanent. I’m proud to join my colleagues in formally denouncing this outrage.

Celebrating Black History Month
￼
Black History Month is a time during which we reflect on the many trials and tribulations Black Americans have faced in America, as well as the many contributions Black Americans have made to our country. America has had an imperfect history in the treatment of African Americans. Against such difficult odds great Americans such as Frederick Douglass, Martin Luther King, Jr., Maya Angelou and many others broke racial barriers to accomplish such wonderful things. America has been challenged to live up to the promises of freedom and equality outlined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.
Although more progress still awaits us, it's important to acknowledge that we have come a long way. So in this month, especially during this time of extreme division in our country, we should all remember that we should judge people by the content of their character rather than the color of their skin. Our external characteristics have no connection to our heart and our will. Our internal powers are the ones that prevail.

Addressing the vaccine roll out and Rachel Maddow's comments on Varney & Co. 
￼
I joined Fox Business this morning to talk about the outrageous claims made by uberliberal talk show host Rachel Maddow. Without a doubt the rioters who broke into the Capitol on January 6 committed criminal acts and should be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. But for her to state that the Republican Party is the party of anarchy is laughable and ridiculous. Where was she and the rest of her riot-promoting Democrats when their radical supporters were burning down cities and businesses all summer long?
Republicans had the courage to condemn BOTH instances of violence. Democrats only condemned violence when it was politically convenient for them, and as a result, hundreds of business owners had their stores looted, destroyed and burned to the ground. 

 
Defending the Hyde Amendment and taxpayer priorities
￼
On the 26th, I joined Republican Study Committee Chairman Congressman Jim Banks and nearly 200 of my colleagues in sending a letter to Congressional leadership demanding that the Hyde Amendment remain in place. Taxpayer funds should NEVER be used to fund abortion. I was given an A+ Rating by the Susan B. Anthony List for a reason. I will vigorously oppose any government funding bill that repeals this longstanding and bipartisan provision.
Calling attention to the Chinese stealing Americans' DNA
￼
 
After hearing disturbing reports about Chinese efforts to purchase and steal Americans' DNA, I made a speech on the House floor last week to raise awareness about this alarming new development. Please take a minute to watch the speech above to learn more about this pernicious Chinese practice.

A+ rating from the pro-life Susan B. Anthony List
￼
Proud to receive an A+ grade from the Susan B. Anthony list for my voting record on pro-life issues in the 116th Congress! As a physician who has held 20-week old babies in my hand, it still floors me to think that some do not feel they are worthy of life. Honestly beyond my comprehension. I will continue to fight for the unborn, who are most vulnerable among us, while serving the people of eastern North Carolina in the 117th Congress.

District Work
Holding Suddenlink accountable
I had a very frank but productive conversation with Suddenlink’s executives last Tuesday afternoon. After expressing my many concerns with the inadequate service they have been providing their customers, they acknowledged the many shortcomings they have been trying to work through during the pandemic. Suddenlink officials made verbal assurances they would improve through a myriad of actions. 
We specifically discussed issues occurring in Craven County, where service has been particularly lacking. I will be following up with local elected officials in Craven County in the coming days to talk about the issue with them and monitor the situation in the coming months to determine whether it has improved. While I received assurances of improved internet and customer service in the months ahead, I expressed that the conversation will not end with this phone call. A follow up meeting between Suddenlink, myself and my staff has been scheduled for early March to monitor their commitments. I do believe they are committed to providing reliable service to our region, but I will be persistent in making sure it happens.

Volunteering at the Vidant vaccination clinic
￼
When it opened on the 25th, I spent a great morning with Sylvia and Tracy at the Vidant sponsored mass vaccination clinic at the Convention Center Greenville. They did an excellent job in through put and efficiency. Excellent. Around 1100 were vaccinated that day alone. Fortunately Vidant was able to secure its allotment of product from the state while some areas in the state were not as lucky. They have done a tremendous job during this entire pandemic of taking care of the people of eastern NC. We are nowhere near out of this pandemic but today was a tremendous leap forward. We must remember that the vaccine was only approved a month ago and Health care workers and long term care patients went first. Now 65 and older are being offered. Vaccines are being made as quickly as possible but it will probably be at least the end of March to get the number of units made to get folks their first dose. So please be patient. People are trying as hard as they can. There is light at the end of the tunnel.

Constituent Spotlight
Happy Birthday, Gilbert Carl Mays!
￼
Thank you to my friend, Representative David Rogers, who represents Burke and Rutherford Counties in District 112 of the State House, for presenting Gilbert Carl Mays a flag I had flown over the Capitol in his honor and an Extension of Remarks entered into the Congressional Record. Mr. Mays, a Beaufort County native and veteran who flew torpedo missions from the U.S.S. Yorktown, recently turned 100. Mr. Mays is one of the many dedicated American veterans who have fought so valiantly for our freedom. We should stop and thank them every chance we get.
Thanks for Reading!
Thank you for signing up to receive my newsletter. I would greatly appreciate it if you could forward this to your family and friends so they can receive periodic updates about what's happening in our nation's capital and eastern North Carolina. It's important to me as a U.S. Representative to keep constituents up to date about my position on the issues in DC, achievements made by people from the district and more. If you are not subscribed already, you can click on the link here. If I can ever be of assistance, or you would just simply like to voice your opinion, please contact my office at (202) 225-3415 or visit my website.
