Subject: Congressman Jake LaTurner: We Are Here To Serve You
Message:
For Immediate Release | February 9, 2021

‌
￼

We Are Here To Serve You

￼

Read Congressman Jake LaTurner's latest op-ed on the important constituent services offered by his office:

As the proud representative of the 2nd Congressional District of Kansas, I am fully committed to serving the needs of all my constituents. Whether you voted for me or not, I am here to serve you – I pledge that I will always be a constituent-first Congressman. In addition to working on passing legislation, my priority and representational duty is to provide constituent services.

Constituent services are near and dear to my heart. I began my career in public service proudly working as a District Representative for former Congresswoman Lynn Jenkins where I was able to work directly with constituents and address their concerns. That rewarding experience instilled a deep appreciation for how significant of an impact congressional offices can make when they actively support the communities they represent. I will draw on those lessons throughout my time in office to guarantee my constituents are receiving the best possible representation.

To address constituent issues directly, we are rolling out a comprehensive mobile office hours schedule to help meet the needs of our constituents across the entire District. These mobile hours will increase accessibility and help deliver on the important work our team is doing. Moving forward, we will visit every county in the District at least once per month.

Countless Kansans deal with federal agencies on any given day. If you’re struggling to get an answer from a federal agency in a timely fashion, or if you feel you have been treated unfairly, our office may be able to help resolve a problem or get you the information you need. Common reasons for reaching out are to seek information about the federal government, obtain a missing record, assist with immigration matters, or ask questions related to passport processing, social security applications, veteran issues, or other federal benefits. Constituent benefits for my congressional office include grant assistance, educational internship opportunities, K-12 student art competition participation, and aid with Washington D.C. visits, flag requests and U.S. Service Academy nominations. We will always do our absolute best to ensure you receive a fair and efficient response to your problem. 

We have two district offices located in Topeka and Pittsburg, KS. Our Topeka District Office is located at 3550 SW 5th Street and can be reached by phone at (785) 205-5253. Our Pittsburg District Office is located at 402 North Broadway Street and can be reached by phone at (620) 308-7450. Please never hesitate to call with questions or to seek additional information. To follow the latest updates from my office, like my Facebook page, follow me on Twitter, and subscribe to my e-newsletter. It is truly my honor to represent you and help in any way I can. 


###

Read the op-ed in the Hiawatha World here

Subject: ICYMI: Senate pro-life caucus chairman rails against Biden abortion executive orders
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





ICYMI: Senate Pro-Life Caucus Chairman Rails Against Biden Abortion Executive Orders
FOX News
By: Tyler Olson, 1/28/2021
 
Sen. Steve Daines, the founder and chairman of the Senate Pro-life Caucus, slammed President Biden over his executive actions to roll back two Trump policies that restricted government support for abortion.
Specifically, Biden will issue a presidential memorandum that will rescind the Mexico City Policy, which prevents the federal government from funding international organizations that provide abortion.
In a similar move, Biden's memorandum will direct the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to reconsider Trump-era regulations that require separation between family planning programs funded under Title X and abortion. This includes the actual performance of abortions, referrals for abortions and financial connections to abortion-related activities. 
"President Biden’s decision to reverse critical pro-life policies at home and abroad shows a complete lack of respect for the sanctity of human life," Daines, R-Mont., said in a comment given to Fox News. "These actions will enrich Planned Parenthood and the abortion industry at the taxpayers’ expense, while endangering the most vulnerable. The United States should not be promoting a radical abortion agenda throughout the world, we should be leading the fight to protect the unborn and all life."
The White House Thursday morning said, "for President Biden, this is personal." The actions, it said in a fact sheet, will "protect access to reproductive health care."
Daines, meanwhile, said he is introducing a bill that would ban the abortion of babies because they are diagnosed to have Down syndrome before they are born. 
"Tomorrow is the 48th annual March for Life. Although this year’s March will be primarily virtual, the importance of standing together to protect the unborn, the most vulnerable, and all life is as important now as it has ever been," Daines said. 
"I believe every human being is created with God-given dignity and potential. No Court, no legislature, no law, can take that away," he continued. "Nevertheless, today, babies with Down syndrome are the most endangered on Earth... That’s why I am joining my colleague from Oklahoma, Senator Inhofe, in introducing the 'Protecting Individuals with Down Syndrome Act'" which will prohibit abortions that are sought because of a diagnosis that an unborn child has or may have Down syndrome."
Daines recounted his experience with a friend's son, who he said was named Andrew, saying the boy is "a true joy and his family celebrates his life every day." But, he said, 67% of babies diagnosed with Down syndrome are aborted... In Europe, the numbers are even worse."
The penalty for a doctor knowingly performing an abortion due to a Down syndrome diagnosis in Daines' bill would be up to five years in prison. 
"It is our duty to protect every innocent life, no matter how small, no matter how many chromosomes they may have," Daines said Wednesday.

Subject: ICYMI: Sen. Rick Scott: Families & Businesses Need Targeted COVID-19 Relief, Not $2 Trillion for Blue-State Bailouts and Wasteful Liberal Priorities
Message:
￼
￼￼￼￼ 
In Case You Missed It!
Sen. Rick Scott: Families & Businesses Need Targeted COVID-19 Relief, Not $2 Trillion for Blue-State Bailouts and Wasteful Liberal Priorities
￼
Sen. Rick Scott Votes Against Dems’ $2 Trillion Spending Package That Hurts American Families 
Last week, Senator Rick Scott voted against Senate Democrats’ partisan $2 trillion spending bill that increases America’s crushing national debt and does more to advance wasteful liberal priorities than actually help American families and small businesses. He will continue fighting for targeted relief for Americans and against these reckless proposals.  See more in Senator Scott’s statement HERE and in his interview with Shannon Bream on Fox News HERE or below. 
￼
 
Sen. Rick Scott to OMB: Taxpayers Need Transparency on $4.5 Trillion Allocated for COVID Relief 
Earlier this month, Senator Rick Scott sent a letter to the Acting Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) requesting an update on the more than $4.5 trillion in tax dollars that has been already allocated to provide financial support to individuals and businesses affected by the COVID-19 crisis. As Congress considers additional COVID-19 relief, Senator Scott is asking that all available information is released regarding tax dollar allocations and spending to make the best decisions for how to move the nation forward.  Read the Senator’s letter HERE. 
 
Sen. Rick Scott on Biden COVID-19 Spending Package: Families Need Targeted Relief, Not Blue-State Bailouts and Wasteful Liberal Priorities 
Last month, Senator Rick Scott released the below statement following President-elect Biden’s announcement of his proposed $1.9 trillion COVID-19 spending package.
Senator Rick Scott said, “We have to get serious about how we’re spending taxpayer dollars. Biden wants to spend more than $350 billion to bailout wasteful states. I’ve been clear – asking taxpayers to bailout failed politicians in liberal states like New York and Illinois and save them from their own bad decisions isn’t fair to fiscally responsible states like Florida. It makes no sense. Congress has already allocated more than $4.5 trillion to address this crisis. We still don’t know how much money is unspent from previous coronavirus relief packages; including the nearly $1 trillion package that was passed just three weeks ago. We cannot simply throw massive spending at this with no accountability to the current and future American taxpayer. I will continue fighting for targeted relief that provides needed assistance to Americans hit hardest by this pandemic; but I will not stand by and let failed liberal policies be used to mortgage our kids and grandkids futures."
Read more HERE. 
￼
Sen. Rick Scott: Democrats’ Partisan Plan to Spend Trillions Hurts American Families 
Last week, Senator Rick Scott released the below statement condemning Democrats for outright rejecting bipartisanship and using the budget reconciliation process to pass a $2 trillion spending bill that increases America’s crushing national debt and does more to advance wasteful liberal priorities than actually help American families and small businesses.  Senator Rick Scott said, “Congress is as dysfunctional as ever. Democrats only lasted 10 days before they completely rejected bipartisanship and began their one-sided push for a $2 trillion spending bill. Democrats have moved forward with a wasteful spending bill that would increase our already massive national debt, trigger devastating cuts to Medicare, and hurt the poorest families in our nation the most. Only in Washington does that make sense. So much for the Left’s call for unity.  "While the process the Democrats have chosen makes absolutely no sense and ultimately hurts American families, I will never stop fighting for Floridians. I am filing a number of amendments to the budget to rein in Washington’s out-of-control spending, protect Americans, secure the border, and get our children back to school." 
Read more HERE.  
￼
Sen. Scott on Fox News: Biden COVID bill ‘makes no sense,’ just a ‘payback to the liberal left’ 
Last month, Senator Rick Scott joined Fox News to discuss Democrats’ plans to use the $1.9 trillion COVID-19 spending package to bailout wasteful states, like New York, Illinois and California, that want to use taxpayer money to backfill their poorly-managed budgets and pension plans. 
Senator Rick Scott said, “Senate Republicans are all in for getting targeted relief to Americans that are still hurting from this pandemic. But President Biden and the Democrats want to spend more than $350 billion to bailout their friends in New York, Illinois, and California. And they are lying about the need for this money. Congress has already given states roughly $400 billion to combat this crisis. States across the country are seeing increases in revenue — in some cases, well above projections. Now, we are learning that 47 states show an average decline of just 0.12 percent compared to 2019, and twenty-one of the 47 states show positive year over year growth of tax receipts. Over half of states reported positive growth, including California, New York, and Illinois." 
Watch more in his interview with Fox News HERE or below. 
￼
 
Sen. Rick Scott in the Wall Street Journal: Biden’s COVID Spending Plan is Filled with Wasteful, Liberal Priorities 
Last month, Senator Rick Scott wrote a letter to the editor of the Wall Street Journal in response to a recent editorial, “Biden’s First Spending Blowout” on President Biden’s massive $1.9 trillion COVID spending package, which includes wasteful and unnecessary spending provisions, like billions to bailout liberal states.   In the letter, Senator Rick Scott wrote, “…I agree that more must be done to support those whose livelihoods have been ripped apart due to the pandemic, but President Biden’s proposal goes far beyond that. His plan is filled with progressive pipe dreams and wasteful spending. We ought to be working on solutions that provide targeted relief and deal directly with the horrific economic and health impact of Covid-19. Unfortunately, his plan is more focused on using the pandemic to push harmful liberal priorities.…"  Read the full letter to the editor in the Wall Street Journal HERE.

Subject: February 2020 - The Hastings Monthly Report
Message:
￼

The Hastings Monthly Report
February 2020

Dear Friend,
We enter the new 117th Congress welcoming a new administration. President Biden and Vice President Harris will unite the country and build it back better for all Americans. They will work to aggressively combat the COVID-19 pandemic and help our economy recover, advancing justice for all and ensure that no one is left behind.
This February we commemorate Black History Month, honoring the history of Black Americans. From emancipation to the Civil Rights Movement, the journey of the Black community exemplifies perseverance and triumph. However, the fight for equality and justice is far from over. Sadly, disparities in employment, wealth, and education still exist among communities of color across our nation, which has only been exasperated with the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.  I applaud President Biden and his administration on taking action for advancing racial equality for those who have been underserved and left behind. As we celebrate this Black History Month and throughout the year, we must continue this fight together for racial equality and justice.
Legislation in Focus: Ensuring House Membership Mirrors the Citizens it Represents
On February 8th, I introduced the Congress Commission Act of 2021, which would establish a bipartisan Congressional Commission to Strengthen Representative Democracy. My legislation will mandate such a commission to solemnly examine representation in the people’s House and offer recommendations to report any shortcomings. We have not addressed House membership in over a century, despite a growing population and an overwhelming amount of evidence illustrating the need for reform of the House of Representatives. This past year, Americans from coast to coast demanded change and turned out at the polls in record numbers. It is high time we examine representation to ensure the people’s House truly reflects those we serve.
Legislation in Focus: Expanding Health Care for Breast Cancer Survivors
In January, I reintroduced with my esteemed colleague, Congresswoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-FL), H.R.469, the Comprehensive Breast Reconstruction Act of 2021. While advances in medicine and patient care have perfected breast reconstruction, many post-mastectomy patients’ access to these procedures are determined on a case by case basis or are guided by a patchwork of differing policies, restrictions, and guidelines. This can be an unfair burden for patients and their families. Patients shouldn’t have to fight for the care they deserve. This legislation builds on advancements to fix the loopholes in the current patchwork of care available to survivors after a medically-necessary mastectomy, expanding covered procedures and allowing survivors access to the care they need to heal. I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress on this legislation and hope that it will be acted upon swiftly on the House floor.
As the 117th Congress turns its attention to these and other issues, I will continue to advocate for a more open process that benefits all Americans. For more information on the various issues that I am working on, please visit my official website at www.alceehastings.house.gov. With warm personal regards, I remain, 
Sincerely,
￼ 
Alcee L. Hastings Member of Congress 20th District of Florida www.AlceeHastings.house.gov

Subject: Healing Our Nation
Message:
￼  
Dear Friend,   Today is a historic day, as the Senate trial begins on the article of impeachment that a bipartisan majority of the U.S. House of Representatives passed last month in response to former President Trump’s role in inciting an insurrection against our country. I know that many Oregonians will be tuning in to watch, and I want to share my thoughts about this trial with you -- thoughts based on what millions of people all around the world saw unfold, and what I experienced firsthand, on January 6.    The violent attack on Congress and the Vice President at the United States Capitol resulted in the deaths of five Americans including the murder of a police officer, injured scores more, and put hundreds of lives at risk. The goal was to burn the ballots of millions of Americans and overturn our presidential election to seize power for Donald Trump in defiance of the expressed will of the voters. It was a violent attack on our freedoms, our democracy, our laws, and our Constitution.   While Donald Trump is no longer occupying the Oval Office, we must demand accountability for his “stolen election” conspiracy, lies, propaganda, and incitement of the violent insurrection targeting Congress, the Vice President, and the Capitol. Every senator must consider the facts of the disturbing events that each of us experienced firsthand, consider what is best for the future of this country, and ensure that his behavior is never normalized.   The healing of our nation and the future of our democracy depend on it.   All my best,  Jeff

Subject: Honoring Our Heroes
Message:
￼
HOME  |   ABOUT  |   CONTACT  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   SERVICES 

 
Honoring Our Heroes
 
Dear Friend,
 
I have the honor of interacting with U.S. Capitol Police officers every day I’m in Washington. They are hardworking, professional, and dedicated to their duty protecting the Capitol, its employees, and all who visit.
 
On Wednesday, I paid my respects to Officer Brian Sicknick—who lost his life from injuries sustained in the line of duty on January 6th—as his remains were lying in honor in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda.
 
My prayers continue to be with his loved ones and the family members of all of our brave law enforcement officers as we mourn this tragic loss.
 
 
￼
 
 
Legislative Business
 
 
The calls for unity and bipartisanship originally promoted by the Biden Administration have been abandoned already. Utilizing an arcane budget procedure, Washington Democrats have decided to ignore House and Senate Republicans — and the millions of Americans they represent — to ram through a partisan COVID relief bill that will cost nearly $2 trillion.
 
That’s why I voted against Democrats' proposed shell budget last week. Instead of focusing on targeted, effective, and bipartisan relief measures – or ensuring the $1 trillion in unspent funds left over from previous relief packages are effectively utilized – they are maneuvering to muscle through a liberal wish list under the guise of a pandemic proposal.
 
This isn’t the first time. Democrats have consistently sought to use COVID-19 as "an opportunity" to pass their extreme policies into law. They have fully admitted the tactic in recent years, and the philosophy has continued into the 117th Congress. 
 
They know Republicans won’t be supportive of a wide range of left-wing policies— including enacting a $15 minimum wage that will hurt small businesses and destroy well over one million jobs, bailouts for states like New York and California, whose budget troubles pre-date the coronavirus pandemic, and paying people more to stay on unemployment than to go back to work. My colleagues on the other side of the aisle have decided to use budget reconciliation to fast-track their radical agenda – not provide assistance to real Americans who need real help.
 
Democrats are eager to dodge the 60-vote threshold in the Senate and avoid any bipartisan consensus. They know many of their measures are controversial and unrelated to the problem at hand, and therefore, unlikely to garner 60 votes to be passed by regular order. Reconciliation is meant to deal with budgetary policies – it’s not supposed to be weaponized to pass controversial initiatives unrelated to revenues and spending.
 
Last week’s vote was the first step in the Pelosi-Schumer led strategy to implement President Biden’s far-left agenda through reconciliation. House Democrats would rather masquerade their liberal policy priorities as coronavirus relief than work alongside Republicans.
 
We should be focused on creating jobs, distributing vaccines, growing the economy, and reopening schools. Yet in reality, what this package will do is kill jobs and further balloon the national debt, while overlooking the over $1 trillion in unspent relief money available from previous congressional action.
 
Notable examples of remaining funds include:
	•	SBA’s Paycheck Protection Program: $280 billion;
	•	Health Spending: $239 billion;
	•	Economic Injury Disaster Loans: $172 billion;
	•	Unemployment Insurance Expansion: $172 billion;
	•	Education Funding: $59 billion;
	•	State and Local Aid: $58 billion;
	•	Stimulus Checks: $52 billion;
	•	Child Care and Development Block Grant: $10 billion; and
	•	Agriculture: $29 billion.
 
Even a top economic advisor to former President Obama said that the Biden proposal is too big. It’s not targeted, transparent, or collaborative. President Biden and the majority have made it seem like the only way forward is a partisan bill through reconciliation. That is completely false. I urge renewed efforts to reach across the aisle and negotiate in good faith. We should be serving the American people – not our own political objectives.
 
 
 
Committee Action
 
 
On the committee front, I am pleased to announce that I was selected last Wednesday to serve on the Subcommittees on Select Revenue Measures, Trade, and Oversight for the House Ways and Means Committee, the chief tax-writing committee in the U.S House of Representatives.
 
My focus has always been on creating jobs, building communities, and eliminating government barriers. As our nation enters a new era, I look forward to providing an even greater voice for advancing bold solutions to some of the most pressing issues of today.
 
Through my experience in the medical field, as a mayor, and a businessman for over 30 years, I am eager to continue to partner with Ranking Member Kevin Brady to be an effective advocate for the Third District and the state of Georgia.
 
With the goal of increasing opportunity for individuals and families, growing our economy, and harnessing American competitiveness and innovation, I’m ready to roll up my sleeves and get to work.
 
 
￼
 
 
Look Who's Coming to Town
 
 
Last week, KB Autosys announced that it is investing $38 million to open its first advanced manufacturing facility in the United States. Located in Meriwether County, this development will create 180 new jobs as Georgia remains a national leader for advanced manufacturing facilities.
 
Click here to read more about this exciting announcement.
 
 
 
January Jobs Report
 
 
On Friday, the U.S. Department of Labor released its January jobs report. The sluggish report fell flat, adding less than half the jobs economists were expecting. With Biden signing an executive order to stop the Keystone XL pipeline in his first days in office, he immediately killed thousands of jobs.
 
At a time we should be focused on safely reopening the economy, this action devastated an entire industry. Read more about the January jobs report here.
 
 
 
Building Career Opportunities
 
 
Workers across our nation need access to work-based training to compete on the world stage. That is why I was proud to reintroduce the PARTNERS Act alongside Congresswoman Suzanne Bonamici (OR-01), Congresswoman Haley Stevens (MI-11), and Congressman Brett Guthrie (KY-02) to support apprenticeships and work-based learning programs that provide workers with pathways to better paying jobs and opportunities.
 
 
 
What's on Drew's Docket?
 
 
This week, I will be speaking with Emory President Gregory Fenves, participating in a House Ways and Means Committee hearings, and speaking with constituents about matters that are most important to them.
 
As always, I’m here to serve you. Please contact my office with any questions, comments, or concerns. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to keep track of upcoming legislation and events!
 
 
Sincerely,
￼
  
Drew Ferguson
Member of Congress

Subject: U.S. Senator Joe Manchin Newsletter - February 9, 2021
Message:
￼

February 9, 2021 
#MASKUPWV 

BROADBAND 
Take a Speed Test Here. 
The sad fact is that many places in West Virginia simply do not have access to reliable broadband and the lack of access affects West Virginians every day. Back in 2015, the FCC released a coverage map that stated 99.9% of Americans had wireless coverage. I knew then what I know now: That is just plain wrong. 
HOW MAY WE HELP YOU? 
To request assistance from my case team, click here.  As your U.S. Senator, I am proud to be your voice with government agencies during your time of need. My goal is for me and my staff to provide the best possible customer service for every West Virginian who contacts me needing assistance. While I have no direct jurisdiction in legal or administrative matters of any federal, state, or local agency, I welcome the opportunity to assist you in any way possible and to assure that full consideration is given to your case. See one of our success stories below: 
  
James Uphold of Reedsville contacted the Senator for assistance with his claim for benefits with the U. S. Department of Veterans Affairs. As a result of Caseworker Amber McCartney’s inquiry, James was awarded benefits and the rating resulted in a retroactive payment. 
From the Hill to the Mountains
MANCHIN REINTRODUCES BIPARTISAN BILL TO HELP CHILDREN, YOUTH AND FAMILIES EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS  Washington, DC – Today, U.S. Senators Joe Manchin (D-WV), Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) and Kyrsten Sinema (D-AZ) introduced the bipartisan Emergency Family Stabilization Act. This legislation would create a new emergency funding stream overseen by the Administration for Children and Families within the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to provide flexible funding for community-based organizations working to meet the unique and challenging needs of children, youth, and families experiencing homelessness. Specifically, the bill aims to provide emergency funding to underserved populations and areas, including in rural and tribal communities, who continue to see long-term repercussions of the COVID-19 pandemic.  "Every child deserves a roof over their head and a safe place to sleep but unfortunately, this is not the case today. The COVID-19 pandemic has only made this problem worse due to high unemployment, unstable living conditions, and job insecurity. Recent research has also found the lack of resources in rural areas of America – like West Virginia – create additional burdens for children and youth experiencing homelessness. The Emergency Family Stabilization Act would help address this issue by dedicating emergency funding to help our children, youth, and families experiencing homelessness during the COVID-19 pandemic. I am working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to include this bipartisan, commonsense legislation in the next COVID-19 relief package," said Senator Manchin. 
MANCHIN VOTES TO CONFIRM VA SECRETARY DENIS MCDONOUGH  Today, U.S. Senator Joe Manchin (D-WV), member of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee, voted to confirm Denis McDonough as U.S. Secretary of Veterans Affairs (VA).  "Today I voted to confirm Denis McDonough as Secretary of Veterans Affairs because the VA needs accountability to ensure they are providing our brave Veterans with the care they deserve. Our West Virginia Veterans have endured unacceptable treatment at two of our VA Medical Centers (VAMC), corroding our Veterans’ trust in the VA system and the care provided to them. I will work with Secretary McDonough as I continue to push for better transparency and accountability at the VA and I expect him to immediately address the longstanding and very serious issues at the VA." 
MANCHIN SUPPORT FOR OIL AND GAS INDUSTRY HAS NOT CHANGED  Washington, DC – U.S. Senator Joe Manchin (D-WV) released the following statement on his votes during the Senate’s February 4th vote-a-rama.  "My position on the oil and gas industry has not changed. I have always been and will always be an outspoken advocate for an all-of-the-above energy policy that includes fracking and responsible energy infrastructure development, like the Keystone XL pipeline. Last week, I voted in favor of multiple nonbinding amendments that expressed opposition to a ban on fracking and support for the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline. While I was disappointed that these provisions were removed from the final package, I voted to proceed forward on this urgent COVID-19 relief package because West Virginia families are hurting. They need more vaccines. They need more direct aid in the form of targeted checks. They need to know their unemployment benefits won’t run out in a few weeks. I will not let partisan games and political posturing hold this essential assistance hostage. 
Energy Committee News 
MANCHIN URGES PRESIDENT BIDEN TO RECONSIDER KEYSTONE XL DECISION, SUPPORT RESPONSIBLE ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT  Manchin: Pipelines are our safest mode of transport for oil and natural gas   Washington, DC – Today, U.S. Senator Joe Manchin, Chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, urged President Biden to reconsider his executive order revoking the cross-border permit for the Keystone XL Pipeline and expressed continued support of the responsible expansion of energy infrastructure, including pipelines.  "I am writing today to express my support of responsible energy infrastructure development, including of oil and natural gas pipelines. Pipelines continue to be the safest mode to transport our oil and natural gas resources and they support thousands of high-paying, American union jobs. To that end, I encourage you to reconsider your decision to revoke the cross-border permit for the Keystone XL pipeline and take into account the potential impacts of any further action to safety, jobs, and energy security,” Chairman Manchin wrote in part.  Yesterday, Chairman Manchin reiterated his commitment to an all-of-the-above energy policy that includes fracking and responsible energy infrastructure development, like the Keystone XL and Mountain Valley pipelines. Senator Manchin introduced the original Keystone XL pipeline bill in 2012. In 2014 and 2015, Senator Manchin voted in support of the Keystone XL pipeline because he believed it would be a tremendous job creator and secure American energy independence. In 2017, Senator Manchin praised President Trump’s executive order to resume construction on the pipeline.  Read the full letter here. 
￼ 
Information is updated daily on: manchin.senate.gov/coronavirus
TESTING & VACCINE INFO
Some testing sites require a physician’s order before testing. To report your symptoms and be directed to one of the available testing sites, contact your primary care doctor or a designated hotline for your area.  If you have gone through these steps and are still having problems getting a test, please email me at common_sense@manchin.senate.gov and a member of my staff will reach out to you to see if we can assist. For a listing of one-day, weekly, and drive-through pharmacy testing, visit the West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources website: https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/pages/testing.aspx 
To learn more about COVID-19 vaccine clinics and availability, visit the West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources website: https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/Pages/Vaccine.aspx 
OR call the COVID-19 VACCINE INFO LINE: 1-833-734-0965 
Hours of Operation for the Vaccine Info Line: Monday-Friday 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., Saturday 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., closed on Sunday
Click here for WV DHHR’s latest updates to reported COVID-19 cases 
RESOURCES
Our office is working diligently to bring you the most up-to-date information as it becomes available. Click the links below for more information. All information regarding resources and more can be found on Senator Manchin’s website. 
Unemployment & Direct Payments   Veterans Assistance   Basic Needs   Business Assistance   Volunteer   Feeling Ill? 
WV 211: 
United Way of West Virginia provides an important service to West Virginians by helping users navigate the vast number of resources available to aid with healthcare issues, food shortages, mental health questions and more. This program is more important now than ever as we battle the COVID-19 pandemic and I commend United Way for continuing to serve their fellow West Virginians through this time.  United Way’s new 2-1-1 will make information on a wide variety of local support services more accessible across our entire state,” said United Way of Central WV President, Margaret O’Neal. “Whether it’s information for locating a health clinic, finding child care programs, or getting housing assistance, 2-1-1 is an easy-to-remember, go-to resource for individuals and families.  To utilize these resources West Virginians can:   Call 2-1-1  Text your zip code to 898-211  Visit http://www.wv211.org/contact  Call toll-free 1-833-848-9905 
__________________________  All information is available and updated daily on manchin.senate.gov/coronavirus. 
  
Unsubscribe
  
To learn more, call my office Toll Free at (855) 275-5737, email me, or find me on social media: 
Facebook     YouTube     Twitter

￼

Subject: NEW: Weekly COVID-19 Newsletter
Message:
News from Representative Garamendi  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 

￼
WEEKLY COVID-19 NEWSLETTER
DATA COMPILED ON February 9, 2021 
Each week, I will send a Weekly COVID-19 Newsletter to provide the most up-to-date information on current COVID-19 case trends and updates on vaccine distribution. To continue receiving this Weekly COVID-19 Newsletter, please subscribe to my digital newsletter here. 
The State Government is responsible for distributing the vaccine and setting eligibility standards. As a Member of Congress, I am working to ensure that the state and local governments have the funding and information they need to get vaccines into the arms of Californians as quickly as possible. This newsletter includes information aggregated from multiple sources across the state. For all questions and concerns related to California’s COVID-19 pandemic response and vaccine plan, please contact the Governor's office here. 
County COVID-19 Cases Snapshot
With over 198,143 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 2,692 confirmed deaths, counties in the 3rd District have an average COVID-19 positivity rate of 10.5%, above the statewide average of 5.8%. However, they have seen an average decrease in positivity rates over the last 14 days of -5.6%, better than the statewide average change of -3.2%. 
￼
All 3rd District counties remain in the Widespread tier, with many non-essential indoor business operations closed. For more information on the tiers and what they mean for restrictions in your community you can visit the California Department of Public Health’s website here. 
County COVID-19 Vaccination Snapshot
California has administered a total of 4,746,539 vaccine doses out of the 7,119,225 vaccine doses it has received. Counties in the 3rd District have administered a total of 264,501 vaccine doses.
￼
Currently California is in Phases 1A and 1B of the state’s vaccination plan. In these statewide phases the following individuals should now be eligible for the vaccine. You can find more information regarding the state’s vaccination allocation guidelines here. 
	•	Now Vaccinating
	◦	Healthcare workers
	◦	Long-term care residents
	•	Now Vaccinating as Supplies Allow
	◦	Individuals 65 and older
	◦	Essential Employees
	▪	Education and childcare
	▪	Emergency services
	▪	Food and agriculture
However, it is important to note that each county has the ability to set their own eligibility requirements, which may differ from the statewide phase. I have compiled a list of resources below, which you can use to learn more about how the vaccine is being distributed in your home county.

	•	Solano County: https://www.solanocounty.com/depts/ph/coronavirus_links/covid_19_vaccines.asp
	•	Sutter County: https://www.suttercounty.org/doc/coronavirus/coronavirusVaccine

	•	Yuba County: https://www.yuba.org/coronavirus/vaccines.php
My office and I will also regularly post updates on my website and social media accounts. You can visit my website at https://garamendi.house.gov/ and follow me on Twitter and Facebook.

JOHN GARAMENDI Member of Congress

Subject: The Northwest in Transition
Message:
￼ 
 
Congressman Simpson
The Northwest 
In Transition 

￼
Simpson Releases Energy and Salmon Concept
“We can seize this unique opportunity to shape our future; if we all commit to push ourselves outside of our comfort zones and work together to solve these issues ONCE and for all.” – Congressman Mike Simpson
Washington, D.C. – Idaho Congressman Mike Simpson has released a framework for reimagining the Northwest energy landscape and recovering critically endangered salmon populations. For the last three years, he and his staff have held over 300 meetings with stakeholders, tribes, elected representatives and other interests trying to understand and break down the complex issues related to the ongoing litigation, studies, appeals, biological opinions, spill and other issues creating regional uncertainty related to salmon recovery, dams, energy and transportation.
“The Northwest has been caught in an unsustainable cycle of conflicts over salmon and energy,” said Simpson. “For over thirty years, lawsuits, appeals, salmon management directives and endless spending have prevailed, while salmon, energy, agriculture and transportation interests continue to suffer.  What I am releasing today is a proposal to break that cycle and deliver certainty and security to the Northwest without picking winners and losers.”
Simpson has posted a “concept” to his website that outlines a possible path forward for the Northwest to end salmon litigation.  The goal is to protect all stakeholders, maximize the benefits of the Bonneville System and the Northwest’s abundant renewable solar, wind and hydroelectric resources, as well as giving our salmon a much better chance at recovery.
“I understand that after 30 years of litigation and conflict that it is difficult for people to envision a different way forward,” said Simpson. “Changes of this magnitude might be unnerving at first, but we have a unique opportunity to create a solution that finally puts a stop to the never-ending salmon wars. This concept could take Idaho’s salmon off the path toward extinction and put them on a more certain path of sustainability and viability. We CAN protect our stakeholders and modernize our energy system for the next fifty-plus years, and we CAN do this on our terms.” 
Simpson concluded, “I am not releasing legislation today, but I am beginning a conversation and asking the Northwest Delegation, states, tribes, governors, and all stakeholders: ‘What do we want the Northwest to look like in 30, 40, 50 years?’  We can seize this chance to shape our future; if we resist the urge to make snap judgments and instead work together to solve these issues ONCE and for all.  We owe it to future generations to try.” 
The concept can be found in detail on Congressman Simpson’s website. 

Congressman Simpson would like feedback on this concept. Thoughts and comments can be sent to Simpson.concept@mail.house.gov

Subject: Working Together to Vaccinate Eastern Washington
Message:
As you know, the unfortunate reality is that rural areas are at a disadvantage when it comes to health care access and infrastructure. One-size-fits-all approaches to vaccine distribution will only make it more difficult for people in Eastern Washington to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. That’s why I’m strongly urging Governor Inslee to revisit his strategy and work with local public health officials to get as many people vaccinated as possible.
 


I am also aware of reports suggesting that vaccines are being reallocated from rural counties to more urban counties. This is deeply concerning, and my team and I are working to provide the necessary oversight on this process to ensure no one in Eastern Washington is left behind. I’m confident that collaboration and clear, proactive communication will help us achieve our shared goal of getting shots in arms as quickly and safely as possible, so we can get our lives back to normal.
 
 

Last week, I asked you if you supported breaching the Lower Snake River Dams. The results are in, and only 20% of you think that this is a good idea - and I agree! I strongly believe that the Snake River Dams are critical to our way of life in Eastern Washington because of the role they play in providing clean, renewable, reliable, and affordable energy. 

Additionally, the dams on the Columbia and Snake Rivers supply half of the Pacific Northwest’s energy, making them absolutely critical for a reliable, sustainable power grid. Without them, life as we know it in our region would cease to exist.

Unfortunately, there are new proposals going around that are putting these dams in jeopardy, suggesting that we breach them in the name of protecting salmon populations. This approach is flawed, and it simply fails to account for the sweeping impacts that would be felt across Eastern Washington and the entire Pacific Northwest.

The Lower Snake River dams are directly responsible for developing hydropower that benefits every resident, family, and business in our region. That’s why I led a resolution to reaffirm my commitment to protect existing hydropower resources like the Snake River Dams. This is about more than saving our dams. This is about protecting our entire way of life, ensuring that energy costs remain some of the lowest in the country, that Washington-grown wheat and apples make it to markets around the world, and that our region continues to lead the way on carbon-free energy. 

You can read my resolution here. 
 

During the ongoing pandemic, many in Eastern Washington continue to work from home. Do you support building additional broadband infrastructure to improve internet speeds? 
Select one
Yes, rural internet speeds need to improve.
Select
 
No, my internet is fine the way it is.
Select
 
Unsure or undecided.
Select
 
 
 

	•	Hearing on Restoring Federal Climate Change Leadership – As Lead Republican on the Energy and Commerce Committee, I attended a hearing on America’s efforts to lead on the issue of climate change. Eastern Washington is a great example of what is possible when we embrace change and seek new, innovative energy solutions. More than 70% of Washington’s energy is generated by clean, renewable hydropower that has resulted in our region having some of the lowest energy costs in the world. To win the future, we must follow this example and lead a new era of innovation 
	•	Phone Call with Acting FEMA Administrator – I spoke with Acting FEMA Administrator Robert Fenton to discuss the recent decision to reject individual assistance to those devastated by wildfires in Whitman County. I am disappointed by this decision, but my team and I are working with every agency and government official to find the best path forward to secure the aid needed to begin rebuilding.  
	•	Energy and Commerce Markup of COVID Relief Package – This week, the Energy and Commerce Committee will mark up the partisan reconciliation package put forth by House Democrats. Using reconciliation for COVID relief abandons the promise of bipartisan work, and I am urging my colleagues to work across the aisle to get real results for the people of Eastern Washington and the rest of the nation. 
 
 

Every single individual in Eastern Washington deserves access to affordable health care coverage, including those with disabilities and other pre-existing conditions. This is one of my top priorities, which is why I introduced legislation to ensure those with pre-existing conditions have guaranteed access to quality care they need. 

The Pre-Existing Conditions Protection Act aims to achieve three important goals for patients:
	•	Guaranteed access to coverage
	•	Prohibiting pre-existing conditions benefit exclusions
	•	Banning a premium rating based on health status

This legislation also protects critical safeguards for patients with pre-existing conditions that would withstand any potential changes in law or decisions from the courts. Additionally, the bill would create a foundation to be built on to continue reforming healthcare for all Americans.

We must work together to expand health care options for Americans, not punish them for things out of their control. I’m confident that this bill will serve as a foundation we can build on to bring down costs, and help individuals keep control over their health care decisions.
 
 

As I shared with you last week, President Joe Biden officially approved the Emergency Disaster Declaration for Malden and Pine City. This breakdown will explain what this means, and what you can expect in the days and weeks ahead.

What is the status of the Emergency Disaster Declaration? President Joe Bide approved the Emergency Disaster Declaration for Washington State on February 4th. In this declaration, public assistance was approved for all 9 counties in the state, including Whitman County. Unfortunately, individual assistance was denied by the Biden administration on February 5th. 

What does this mean for Eastern Washington? The good news is that Whitman County is eligible to receive additional funding to begin rebuilding public property that was destroyed during the fires, including city hall. Unfortunately, despite my requests for approval, Individual Assistance, which would have helped uninsured homeowners, has not been made available for individuals in Malden or Pine City. However, low interest loans from the Small Business Administration to cover business and primary residence losses are now available, as well as mortgage programs through the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Please reach out to our office if we can be of any assistance as you navigate these programs.  

What happens next? I am incredibly disappointed by the decision to reject individual assistance for Whitman County. The individuals, families, and businesses need this assistance. My entire team and I are working closely with FEMA, Senators Murray and Cantwell, and Governor Inslee to find the best path forward that delivers results for the communities devastated by these fires. This is something we will continue working on, and I will keep you updated on our progress. 
 

Q: What will you do to keep gas prices low? - Christine from Spokane Valley 

Thank you for your question. In my role as the Lead Republican on the Energy and Commerce Committee, I am fighting to keep gas prices low by pushing back against President Biden’s policies and executive actions that would do the opposite. 

As you know, individuals, families, and businesses continue to struggle due to the economic hardship brought on by the coronavirus pandemic. The last thing our community needs are policies that drive up energy prices and make it more difficult to put food on the table.

Unfortunately, many of the president’s actions and proposals are putting affordable energy at risk. For example, on his first day in office President Biden ended construction of the Keystone XL Pipeline and ordered a review of the regulatory relief President Trump achieved. President Biden has also ordered an indefinite moratorium of oil and gas development on federal land. I have taken a number of actions to push back on these orders that would result in families in Eastern Washington paying more for gas and other utilities.

I am determined to lead our country down a more constructive path. That’s why I am supporting the Keystone XL Pipeline Construction and Jobs Act to make sure America can continue to be energy independent, I am calling on President Biden to reverse his unilateral order ending energy development on federal lands, and I will fight against a return of the burdensome top-down, one-size-fits-all approach to environmental regulations that drives up energy prices. 

My goal as Lead Republican on the Energy and Commerce Committee is to support clean, renewable, and reliable energy sources - like the hydropower we are so familiar with along the Columbia and Snake River System - to make sure energy costs like gasoline in Eastern Washington remain some of the lowest in the world.

What question would you like to see answered next week?
Submit a Question
  ‌   ‌   ‌ 
 

Cathy McMorris Rodgers | 1035 Longworth HOB, Washington, DC 20515

Subject: Rep. Adriano Espaillat Hosts Virtual Black History Month Roundtable
Message:
￼ 
  

MEDIA ADVISORY
For Immediate Release
February 10, 2021


Espaillat Hosts Black History Month Roundtable Honoring District Leaders

Watch Live: 
https://www.facebook.com/RepEspaillat


NEW YORK, NY - Representative Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) will hold a virtual roundtable in recognition of Black History Month on Thursday, February 18th at 6:30 p.m. to honor local champions in the fight for racial equality and representation throughout New York's 13th congressional district. 

During the event, Rep. Espaillat will be joined by honorees:  Kevin “K.B.” Bracey, President of the Epsilon Sigma Chapter of Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Incorporated; Hazel N. Dukes, President of the NAACP New York State Conference; Reverend Ronald E. Sullivan, Pastor of the Christian Parish for Spiritual Renewal; and C. Virginia Fields, Founder and CEO of the National Black Leadership Commission on Health. 

Watch live at https://www.facebook.com/RepEspaillat

￼

WHO: 
* Representative Adriano Espaillat (NY-13)
* Kevin Bracey, President, Epsilon Sigma Chapter of Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc.
* Hazel N. Dukes, President of the NAACP New York State Conference
* Reverend Ronald E. Sullivan, Pastor, Christian Parish for Spiritual Renewal
* C. Virginia Fields, Founder and CEO of the National Black Leadership Commission on Health.

WHAT: Virtual Black History Month Roundtable 

WHEN: Thursday, February 18th at 6:30 p.m. (EST)

WHERE: Watch live at https://www.facebook.com/RepEspaillat 

# # #

Representative Espaillat is the first Dominican American to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives and his congressional district includes Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill and the north-west Bronx. First elected to Congress in 2016, Representative Espaillat is serving his third term in Congress. Representative Espaillat currently serves as a member of the influential U.S. House Committee on Appropriations responsible for funding the federal government’s vital activities. He is also a member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus (CHC), where he serves as the Second Vice Chair and is a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, where he serves as Deputy Whip. Representative Espaillat also currently serves as a Senior Whip of the Democratic Caucus. To find out more about Rep. Espaillat, visit online at https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Media inquiries: Candace Person at Candace.Person@mail.house.gov

También es miembro del Caucus Hispano del Congreso (CHC), donde se desempeña como segundo vicepresidente y es miembro del Caucus Progresista del Congreso, donde se desempeña como subcoordinador (Deputy Whip). El congresista Espaillat también se desempeña actualmente como coordinador sénior del Caucus Demócrata. Para obtener más información sobre el congresista Espaillat, visite su portal en línea en https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Subject: Poll: How do we fill the shortage of American trade jobs?
Message:
￼
￼
￼

Dear Hoosiers,
 
As our 21st century economy grows, so does the need to fill trade positions in America. According to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation, “74% of hiring managers agree that there is a skills gap in the current labor market, with 48% saying that candidates lack the skills needed to fill open jobs.” American businesses and manufacturers are struggling to find qualified candidates to fill in-demand jobs and it remains critical that we properly prepare our workforce for an ever-evolving economy.  

To that end, there are numerous options leaders at the local, state, and federal levels believe can help increase preparedness and interest in trade careers. Last Congress, I introduced the DRIVE Safe Act, which works to encourage more young people to enter the truck driving industry, and just last week, the House of Representatives took action to reinforce apprenticeship programs across the country. 

I voted against the recent House action because it doesn’t allow enough flexibility for businesses to create apprenticeships that fit their specific industry needs and implements barriers to enter the programs. I believe we need to be enabling more opportunities for hands-on experience, not less. 
 
QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Which option do you think best bridges the skills gap and fills the shortage of American trade jobs? 
 
[_] We should increase access to apprenticeships and other real-world training programs 
[_] We should invest in STEM courses 
[_] We should provide more federal assistance and encourage attendance to two-year technical programs versus four-year institutions 
[_] We don’t need more technical education 
[_] I don’t know 
[_] Other 
Take the poll here
￼
￼


Rep. Trey Hollingsworth | Connect 
￼ ‌ ￼ ‌ ￼ ‌

Subject: CongressMann Mail
Message:
CONGRESSMANN MAIL
Proudly serving the BIG FIRST of Kansas 
 

Welcome to the first edition of the CongressMann Mail newsletter! This newsletter will provide insight into the issues Congress is working on and how they impact Kansans. It has been a busy first month, both in Washington and in Kansas. Check out highlights of the work I'm doing for the First District. 
 

LOOK AHEAD 

The House has a District Work Week. Here is what you can expect. 

	•	The Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) has been reauthorized and is open for business. Click here for more information on PPP. 

	•	House Veterans' Affairs Committee will meet to adopt committee rules, assign subcommittees and hold a Committee Markup on the Budget Resolution. 

	•	House Agriculture Committee will meet to adopt committee rules, assign subcommittees and hold a Committee Markup on the Budget Resolution. 
 

Follow me for updates: 
Mann.House.Gov | Twitter | Facebook | Instagram | Newsletter 
 

Hitting the Ground Running

In my first month in Congress I supported legislation and signed onto letters focusing on the interests of the First District.


Pro-Life legislation I supported: 
	•	No Taxpayer Funding For Abortion Act

	•	Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act

	•	Support and Value Expectant (SAVE) Moms and Babies Act

	•	Life At Conception Act

	•	Defund Planned Parenthood Act

	•	Born-Alive Survivor Protection Act

	•	Title X Abortion Provider Prohibition Act

	•	Recognizing Jan. 22 as National Sanctity of Life Day

	•	Letter to Defend the Hyde Amendment & Pro-Life Appropriations Provisions

	•	Ultrasound Informed Consent Act

	•	Protecting Individuals with Down Syndrome Act

Energy legislation I supported: 
	•	Saving America's Energy Future Act

	•	Safeguarding Oil and Gas Leasing and Permitting Act

	•	Protecting American Energy Production Act

	•	Promoting Cross-Border Energy Infrastructure Act

	•	Keystone XL Pipeline Construction and Jobs Act

Other legislation I supported: 
	•	Keep the Nine Amendment: Resolution amending the Constitution to require the Supreme Court consist of nine judges

	•	Resolution amending the Constitution to impose term limits to House and Senate Members

	•	Oppose Vaccine for Guantanamo Bay Detainees

	•	Resolution honoring the U.S. Capitol Police for their bravery and sacrifice on Jan. 6, 2021

	•	Resolution thanking the National Guard who were deployed in support of Inauguration Activities

	•	USPS Fairness Act
 

‌
 

 

Introducing the More Accountability is Necessary Now (MANN) Acts

On February 2, I introduced H.R. 713-718, the More Accountability is Necessary Now (MANN) Acts. The MANN Acts include six pieces of legislation promoting accountability and transparency in future executive orders made by the Executive Branch.

The MANN Acts will require the Executive Branch to notify Congress with its intent to issue any new, or revoke any existing, executive order pertaining to these six areas:

	•	Agriculture, Food, and the Livelihood of American Farmers, Ranchers, and Producers
	•	Energy
	•	America’s Natural Resources and the Environment
	•	Pro-life Provisions Including the Hyde Amendment and the Right to Life
	•	The Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution
	•	Immigration into the United States

Watch my video on walking to the House Floor and introducing the Mann Acts below: 
 
 

Maiden Floor Speech

This week I delivered my maiden speech on the Floor of the U.S. House of Representatives. I am proud to represent the Big First and it is an honor to speak on its behalf. 

The Big First is home to the geographic center of our great Nation and a tremendous amount of common sense and sound judgment. I work hard to take the perspective of Kansans to Washington, D.C. and let it inform the policy I pursue. 

In my speech I talked about my legislation, the More Accountability is Necessary Now Acts (MANN Acts). These six pieces of legislation would require the White House to give Americans 30-days notice before an Executive Order can be signed. This would ensure the voices of Kansans are heard BEFORE any Executive Orders are signed by the President. The Executive branch was NOT created to legislate - Congress was. 

I did not come to Congress to be a caretaker in the slow demise of America - I ran so I could fight and work to make it stronger. That's what I intend to do while believing that our brightest days are yet to come.

Watch the full speech below: 
 
 

Committee Assignments

It is an honor to have secured placement on the House Agriculture Committee and the House Veterans Affairs Committee. I look forward to advocating on behalf of our agriculture industry and the service members in the Big First.
 


House Agriculture Committee
﻿
“I’m pleased to welcome Congressman Mann to the House Agriculture Committee. The lessons learned growing up on his family farm in Kansas make him particularly attuned to the needs of our rural communities,” said Rep. Glenn “GT” Thompson, Republican Leader of the House Agriculture Committee. “Tracey’s perspective will be crucial as we move forward to restore a robust rural economy and support the hard working men and women of our nation’s agricultural sector.”  

My roots in agriculture run deep. I understand agriculture and have a passion for our rural way of life. These are the three priorities I will focus on in the Agriculture Committee:

	•	Protect and Strengthen Crop Insurance: Agriculture faces risks and uncertainty unlike any other industry, and I will work to make sure that producers have the tools needed to manage this risk.

	•	Stop Regulatory and Administrative Overreach: I will push back on regulations, conduct oversight as the Biden Administration introduces executive orders, and work to stop overreach from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Department of the Interior, and other federal agencies.

	•	Increase Trade: Holding China accountable to Phase 1 commitments in our current trade deal is my highest priority. I will also work to shift the focus to a long-term approach that benefits our agriculture partners for years to come.
 
 

House Veterans Affairs Committee


“I am so happy to have Rep. Mann serving on the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs this Congress," said Ranking Member of the Veterans Affairs Committee Mike Bost. He brings a wealth of experience in business and politics to the table, along with a passion for rural America. I have no doubt he will serve veterans in Kansas and across the country well over the next two years.” 




I am a proud supporter of our military. Our servicemembers deserve health and job security following their service to our country. As a member of the Veterans Affairs Committee I will prioritize the following issues:

	•	Workforce Transition Programs: I will work to make the transition from active duty to civilian life is as seamless as possible for our veterans. Job resources are an essential part to that process.

	•	Health Services: I will work to ensure veterans in rural Kansas have access to quality health care from the provider of their choosing, including via telemedicine.

	•	Top Quality Education Assistance, Housing Services, and Financial Benefits: I will work to ensure veterans have the assistance they need. A top priority of mine is to have accessibility and efficiency within these programs.
 
 

Protecting and Supporting Kansas Energy

I addressed the Biden Administration's executive actions that negatively impact Kansas energy producers. The Big First is made up of communities that grow and shrink with oil and gas prices, and they deserve common sense energy policies from Washington, D.C. President Biden delivered mixed messages claiming to support fossil fuels and American jobs, but has issued many harmful executive orders, including dismantling the Keystone Pipeline. I will do everything I can to support our Kansas energy sector. From fossil fuels to renewable fuels Kansas energy is a priority for me. 
﻿
Watch the full speech below: 
 
 

In the Office

 
 

Meeting with the Kansas National Guard members who were stationed in Washington, D.C. for the Inauguration.
 
 

 

I met with the U.S. Army Liaison Office and received the Army seal to display in my office. We discussed the important mission of Ft. Riley and their essential mission to the Army and the Big First.
 
 
 

I met with General Finerty, the Director of the Legislative Liaison Office for the U.S. Air Force and received the Air Force seal to display in my office. We talked about the priorities of the Air Force and the importance of Air Force missions in Kansas.
 
 

District Visits

 

Jackson Meat, Hutchinson KS

During my tour of the Big First, I visited Jackson Meat in Hutchinson. Established in 1946, this local business has been around to "meat the needs" of Hutchinson for 75 years.

Pictured: Rep. Mann, Andrew and Jeni Bryan (owners). 

 

Hutchinson Regional
Healthcare System

I had the pleasure of meeting with the senior staff at Hutchinson Regional Healthcare System. We discussed how the hospital is doing despite the challenges caused by Covid-19.

Pictured: Rep. Mann, President/CEO Ken Johnson, Vice President Chuck Welch, External Affairs Rep. Richard Shank, Dr. Michael Hagley, Dr. Rex Degner. 

 

Chamber of Commerce, McPherson KS

It was great meeting with members of the McPherson Chamber of Commerce and United Way. I also was able to meet with members of the Chamber of Commerce in Hutchinson and Junction City. I enjoyed learning about their service to their communities and how we could work together to better our state.

Pictured: Rep. Mann, McPherson Chamber of Commerce Executive Director Debbie Hawkinson, United Way Executive Director Rob Mackey. 

 

Hutchinson/Reno County Chamber of Commerce

I enjoyed meeting with the Hutchinson/Reno County Chamber of Commerce. We discussed Reno County businesses and the challenges they have had to overcome with the Covid-19 pandemic. We also talked about the importance of growing current local businesses, education, economic development, and agriculture.

Pictured: Chamber President/CEO Debra Teufel and Start Up Hutch Entrepreneur Navigator and Director Jackson Swearer, Rep. Mann.

Subject: Reminder: COVID-19 Vaccine Updates and Other Important News
Message:
February 7, 2021
 

Dear Neighbor, 
 
Today is the big day! Best of luck to our very own Tampa Bay Buccaneers as they compete in the first ever Hometown Super Bowl! I know many of us are looking forward to an exciting evening for our favorite team and our community. I predict a big Bucs’ win!
 
Unfortunately, I am not so optimistic about the American people continuing to win under this new administration. Our country has serious problems and remains deeply divided. We need to come together and find areas of agreement rather than continuing to stoke political division. However, since taking office, President Biden has unilaterally taken 42 Executive actions on highly controversial issues which further divide our nation. This is far more than his recent predecessors in either party. 
 

Now, he and Congressional Democrats are contemplating the use of a special budget procedural maneuver to avoid having to negotiate with Republicans on another new stimulus package. While more targeted relief measures may indeed be needed to improve vaccine distribution and help those who are still struggling to recover from the pandemic, there has not even been a serious discussion about how much of the billions of dollars of federal funding already allocated has yet to be dispersed. Consider these important figures:

First Pandemic Supplemental - $8 billion 
Families First Coronavirus Response Act-$192 billion 
CARES Act- $1.72 trillion 
Paycheck Protection Program and Health-$483 billion 
Consolidated Appropriations Act FY 2021- $1,043 trillion 
Proposed New Biden Stimulus - $1.9 trillion
Higher Debt Interest from 5 previous and 1 proposed pandemic relief measure- $400 billion 
Total Allocated and Proposed Measures- $5,747 trillion 
Total Amount of Previously Allocated Funds Already Dispersed - ? 

We have not examined which prior relief programs are working and those which are not reaching targeted goals. For example, I am a strong supporter of public education. We have allocated billions of funding to help students safely return to the classroom and yet more than half of the states in our country have not reopened in-person learning sites. In Florida, we followed the science and school has been back in session all year. The science said it was relatively safe to have students and teachers return to the classroom, with appropriate safeguards in place, especially when weighed against the very real socio-emotional and educational concerns associated with not re-opening in person learning opportunities. We have seen very few problems with COVID-19 transmission in our classrooms, but the burden of managing that process and paying for those safeguards has largely fallen to state and local governments. We have not seen a large influx of federal funding to support the safeguards that were necessary to re-open classrooms, even though billions of dollars have been allocated. It is logical to ask where the allocated funds have gone and why we need to appropriate $170 billion more for education through this new stimulus proposal, especially if there are not imminent plans to follow the science and immediately re-open schools throughout the country.  

Last week, I joined my colleagues on the Energy and Commerce Committee to officially request this type of information of the Biden Administration. Informed decision-making is critical for ensuring that any future legislative measures will meet the needs that exist. Instead of asking these important questions, the relief measure being pushed quickly through Congress ushers in long-standing Democratic priorities such as bailing out local and state governments for non-pandemic expenses, raising the federal minimum wage, and extending federal unemployment benefits through the end of 2021.    

The actions taken during the past two weeks do not reflect a commitment to heal the nation and find common ground.  I remain focused on working across party lines to find common sense solutions that will help all Americans during this difficult time.
 
Please continue reading for some important information. 
 

Vaccinating Seniors and Strengthening our Medical Supply Chain
    
I know that the vaccination distribution process continues to be confusing and frustrating for many local seniors. Currently, it is important to realize that seniors have a few primary options for getting a vaccination. If they live in Pasco, they can register through the Pasco health department's CDR system and then log in to try to obtain an appointment once those slots are released on Sundays at 2:00 p.m. They can also pre-register through the state's new process, reserve their space in line for a vaccine and be notified when a dose is available. I was relieved to see Pinellas County announce improvements to its vaccination process. Hopefully these changes will make it easier for seniors. Additionally, Publix locations in Pasco and Pinellas are now offering seniors the COVID-19 vaccine. You can learn more about how to register through Publix here. I am continuing to share your feedback with the state and local officials who have jurisdiction over this process and believe it will continue to improve. 

As noted in this local news report, I am glad to see that the state of Florida received more than 300,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccine last week- a more than 40,000 increase from our previous weekly allocation from the federal government. I will continue to advocate for additional doses for Florida, and for an expansion of the federal pharmacy program.  

As part of the federal effort to expand access to the COVID-19 vaccine and after months of groundwork, the CDC has activated the Federal Retail Pharmacy Program. While additional details are still being finalized, an initial one million doses of vaccine will be sent to participating pharmacies around the nation on February 11th. Participating pharmacies in Florida include: Publix; Walmart and Southeastern Grocers. This program will run in tandem with the Pharmacy Partnership for Long-Term Care Program, a program used to prioritize vaccination of seniors in long-term care facilities. It is separate from the allocation each state is receiving from the federal government for distribution. These state allocations are currently being distributed through a variety of locations including: local health departments, state sites, and Publix. I will continue to support all efforts to increase circulation of the vaccine to Floridians and will share more information when it becomes available.

Many constituents have asked how people under 65 with severe medical conditions can sign up for COVID-19 vaccination. Here is some limited information. Once more information is available, I will share it. 

During last week’s Health Subcommittee hearing, I discussed the work being done to improve seniors’ access to a COVID-19 vaccine and the fact that our state needs more doses for distribution. I also highlighted the need to modernize our nation’s emergency supply chain to ensure we are less dependent on foreign governments during future emergencies. Click here to listen to my exchange with panelists.  
 
 

Consumer Protection Connection
 
During this week’s kick off meeting of the Consumer Protection and Commerce Subcommittee, we examined the scams that bad actors have used during the COVID pandemic to exploit seniors and other vulnerable populations. During my remarks, I highlighted the disgusting example in Pasco County in which someone made a fake Eventbrite account to sell phony vaccine appointments to seniors. We must do all we can to educate vulnerable populations about these duplicitous scams, put safeguards in place to protect the public, and prosecute those who perpetrate these crimes. Click here to listen to my remarks. 
Sadly, this local news report highlights how scammers are seeking to exploit vulnerable populations desperate to obtain a COVID-19 vaccine. Remember, by law, all COVID-19 vaccines are to be made available free of charge, without co-payments or deductibles, including for those who are uninsured. 

Additionally, this story serves as a good reminder that exploitation often comes from unexpected sources. Remember, nursing home and ALF providers are not legally allowed to take seniors’ stimulus checks. Any incidence of theft should be reported to the Florida Attorney General’s office.  
 
 

Fighting Childhood Cancer
 
Pediatric cancer remains the number one disease that leads to the death of American children. While survival rates have improved for some types of pediatric cancers, thousands of children are lost to cancer each year and many more encounter life threatening complications related to harsh chemotherapies. Children have significantly fewer treatment options than adults and oftentimes must rely on treatment regimens developed for adults because pediatric-specific treatments simply do not exist for many pediatric cancers and rare diseases. 
 
The Gabriella Miller Kids First Pediatric Research Program at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) is working to facilitate a better understanding of pediatric cancers and holds the promise for the development of better treatments and possible cures. As a longtime advocate for children and rare disease patients, I was proud to co-author bipartisan legislation last week which will provide a new funding source for this successful program.  

Specifically, our new bill will redirect penalties levied against pharmaceutical, cosmetic, supplement, and medical device companies by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for violating the Foreign Corrupt Practice Act (FCPA) towards the Kids First program. In recent years, hundreds of millions of dollars in penalties have been levied against these companies, and the Gabriella Miller Kids First Research Act 2.0 will help channel those funds directly to critical medical research focused on children. 
 
 

Facilitating Economic Recovery

Right now, we should be focused on helping Americans get back to work, rebuild their businesses, and safely send their children back to school.  I am disappointed to see so many Executive Actions taking us in the opposite direction. 
 

However, we are seeing some encouraging signs for our local economy. For example, I am glad to see projections that our local housing market will continue to remain strong this year.  
 

Additionally, the recent announcement of Moffitt’s new research facility in Pasco County is another exciting economic development opportunity for our entire region. Moffitt's expansion project is expected to support 14,500 new jobs and will help the hospital continue critical research as it seeks to prevent and cure cancer. 
 
 

Protecting our Children 
 
There is no higher priority than keeping our children safe. By providing high quality screening and prevention training to school staff and peers, we can identify threats before they materialize, and ensure that those who are at risk get the mental health treatment they need. I have seen first-hand how effective these programs can be when I visited a high school in Pinellas which has already implemented these best practices. Sadly, some communities in my district are among those with the highest suicide rates in our state, and the pandemic has only exacerbated the problem. With training like this, we can help reverse that troubling trend, which is why my colleagues and I re-introduced the STAND-UP Act last week. Click here to learn more.  
 
 

Helping our Heroes

Veteran unemployment rates have been disproportionately high throughout the pandemic. I am hosting a Veteran Employment Fair later this month in order to connect Veterans, Guard and Reserve members and spouses of Veterans and active duty personnel with available positions in our community. Please feel free to share this information as appropriate. 
 
 

Community Concentration 

My team recently had the opportunity to participate in a briefing on Human Trafficking which featured speakers from the FBI, U.S. Attorney’s Office- Middle District and Department of Homeland Security. These agencies are working in a coordinated manner to identify cases and support victims. Unfortunately, studies have shown that human trafficking rates historically spike when cities host large-scale events. As we prepare to host today’s Super Bowl, we can all do our part to remain alert and report any suspicious activity to law enforcement. 
 

My team had the privilege of participating in the recent graduation of the Pasco County Housing Authority’s Self Sufficiency Program. Every program graduate was able to leverage the skills learned to realize the dream of home ownership. Congratulations to each of these families and best wishes for your continued success.﻿
 

Additionally, my team enjoyed participating in the Grand Opening of HD Real Estate Company with the North Tampa Bay Chamber last week. Congratulations to owner Ray Hendricks and best wishes on his continued success. 
 
 

Constituent Corner

I recently received this message from a constituent in my district. 

On Friday January 22nd, we sent a letter requesting the Congressman’s assistance with resolving a delay in our son’s security clearance. Our son called us the following Tuesday to report that he’d been given his clearance! Not even two full business days later!  At first, we thought it must just be a coincidence, but no, it was one phone call from the Congressman’s office!  If that’s not amazing, I don’t know what is! Congressman Bilirakis and his staff care and get things done. We are thankful to have him to call upon in a situation like this where you feel like you have no control and there’s nothing you can do. Maybe we can’t, but he sure can! Thank-you Congressman Bilirakis and all the hard-working and caring staff in your office. Especially Rob, who reached out to follow-up with us.  We are truly grateful. 

This is just one example of the work we do each day. Constituent services are a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you!

Sincerely,
 

Gus Bilirakis
Member of Congress
 
 

Rep. Gus Bilirakis | 2354 Rayburn HOB, Washington, DC 20901
