Subject: Protecting Free Speech for all Americans
Message:
Freedom of speech is unique to us as Americans, and it has been fought for and defended all through our history. Elected officials using their platform to pressure private companies to censor media outlets they disagree with is deeply troubling and sounds a lot like actions from the Chinese Communist Party. 

Now more than ever, we need to uphold the First Amendment, which states that “Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press.” 
 

Freedom of speech is foundational to our personal rights and liberties. We should all be troubled when duly-elected representatives launch an attack on the First Amendment to coerce private companies to censor political speech.  

Instead, let’s give people hope in the Promise of America again—so they have the courage to be unique, creative, and live their lives without fear. We should all be publicly denouncing this censorship campaign on news that doesn’t fit a specific worldview. 

Click here to watch how I fought back this week. 
 
 

	•	Helping you get a COVID-19 vaccine – This week, I took to the Energy & Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations to highlight the shortcomings of Washington State’s vaccine distribution strategy. The Washington Department of Health ignored basic logistics in their rollout plan, and Governor Inslee threatened to withhold vaccines from Whitman County if health officials began vaccinating teachers, despite the swift and efficient vaccination of all other eligible people. This one-size-fits-all approach is misguided, and it is hurting Eastern Washington. 
	•	Protecting your right to free speech – Yesterday, Democrats launched an attack on Americans’ right to free speech by trying to censor media outlets they disagree with. This sets a dangerous precedent, which is why I am fighting to uphold the First Amendment that is foundational to our way of life. Click here to watch. 
	•	Upholding our way of life – This week, I had a virtual meeting with the Washington State Potato Commission to discuss the importance of the Lower Snake River dams to our farmers. We also discussed my priorities as Lead Republican on the Energy & Commerce Committee to close the digital divide and make sure farmers can continue to make positive environmental impacts. 
 
 

Last week, I asked you if you supported expanding financial opportunity for the millions of Americans living with a disability. The results are in, and only 16% of you who responded thought that Americans with a disability did not need to save. Like the vast majority of you, I believe that every American - regardless of their abilities - has the right to save for their future! 

This week, I introduced the ABLE Age Adjustment Act to build on the incredible progress we’ve made to empower people with disabilities to live fuller and more independent lives. This important legislation will expand access to tax-free ABLE accounts for people who develop a disability later in life – as late as 46 years old – so they can invest in their education, pay for medical expenses, and look for a job.  

ABLE puts our focus on every person’s abilities and God-given talents, not their limitations. Additionally, the ABLE Age Adjustment Act will help us continue to close the gap between Americans with disabilities looking for a job and the small fraction who actually find one.  

There is more work to be done to build on the legacy of the ABLE Act, but I’m confident this is a great step that will empower more people to live with dignity and reach their potential. 
 

The First Amendment guarantees that “Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press.” Do you support censoring media outlets? 
Select one:
Yes, free speech is dangerous.
Select
 
No, free speech is a fundamental American right.
Select
 
Unsure or undecided.
Select
 
 
 

I’m excited to announce that my office is now accepting submissions for the 2021 Congressional Art Competition. This is a great tradition that gives students in grades 7-12 an opportunity to highlight their artistic talents, and the winner will have their piece displayed in the U.S. Capitol. The application deadline is April 23, so I hope you’ll consider submitting your piece! 
 

Q: Why can’t K-12 students go back to school full-time immediately? - Judy from Spokane 

Thank you for your question. This is an issue I feel very strongly about. As a working mom of three, I understand the struggles that so many parents in our community are going through right now.  

I recently heard from a number of families in Eastern Washington who are struggling with their mental health as a result of schools being closed and extracurricular activities being canceled.  

Virtual school isn’t working. Our kids are falling behind in the classroom. We have allowed our children to feel neglected and ignored, and I am deeply concerned about their well-being, especially their mental health. 

The isolation has taken a toll on our children, and we are seeing a steep increase in depression, anxiety, drug abuse, and even suicide attempts. As your representative, and more importantly as a mom, I am heartbroken over what this pandemic has done to our children. 

That’s why I continue to encourage President Biden to follow the science and reopen schools across the country immediately. Additionally, for the health of our kids, we must come together in a bipartisan way to provide relief that ensures our kids are back in school, people are back to work, and everyone who wants and needs a vaccine gets one. 

To all of the families who are struggling with this, please know that you are not forgotten, and I stand by each and every one of you in this fight. 

What question would you like to see answered next week?
Submit a Question
 
 

Earlier this month, I received this letter from the Washington Grain Commission in Spokane thanking me for protecting the Lower Snake River Dams. In all of my years serving in Congress, this was one of the most thoughtful letters I have ever received. I agree, “Friends are God’s way of taking care of us,” and I am grateful to each and every person in our community who joins me in these important fights. God bless you! 
  ‌   ‌   ‌ 
 

Cathy McMorris Rodgers | 1035 Longworth HOB, Washington, DC 20515

Subject: Making Progress and Staying Safe
Message:
￼

 
Making Progress, Staying Safe
 
February 25, 2021
  
This newsletter provides vaccine updates, events recognizing Black History Month, immigration information, and free resources for our community.
  
 
COVID-19 and Vaccine Updates
 
Vaccine Update
 
Everyone who is eligible for a vaccine should get their shot as soon as possible. Here is a list of all who are currently eligible for a vaccine in our community, although supplies are limited and most are first come, first served.
	•	Healthcare workers (including in home health workers)
	•	Long term care staff and residents
	•	Nursing home staff and residents
	•	Residents age 65+
	•	Longshore workers at the Port of Los Angeles and Port of Long Beach can be vaccinated at Long Beach vaccination sites. Port workers should contact their employer or their union representative for more info about this vaccination distribution.
	•	In Long Beach ONLY: Government emergency response workers
	•	In Long Beach ONLY: Food or agriculture workers
	•	In Long Beach ONLY: Education and childcare workers
On March 1st, in L.A. County (not just Long Beach) workers in three additional sectors will become eligible for the vaccine:
	•	Education and childcare workers
	•	Emergency services and first responders
	•	Food & agriculture workers (Note: Our office was advised by the State Health and Human Services Agency that port workers who handle cargo with food and agricultural products are eligible under this category)
To find out when you or your family members are eligible under state guidelines, please go here. Please note that you should also check LA County guidelines which govern here in LA County. 
 
Where Can I get a Vaccine?
 
Eligible residents can be vaccinated at a variety of sites. Make sure you reach out to your healthcare provider to discuss your options. Some clinics offer vaccines to their patients.
	•	Federal FEMA run sites:
	◦	Cal State LA
	•	L.A. County run sites - check for appointments here or call 833-540-0473.
	◦	The Forum
	◦	Downey Education Building
	◦	Fairplex Cal State Northridge
	◦	Six Flags Magic Mountain
	◦	Compton College 
	◦	Unincorporated LA County/Willowbrook: MLK Community Health Center is vaccinating healthcare workers and residents 65+ from these specific zipcodes.
	▪	Dates: 2/24 - 2/26 8am-5pm
	▪	Address: 12021 Wilmington Blvd.
	▪	No appt needed -- walk-up with photo ID!
	•	L.A. City run sites, sign up here.
	•	Carson pop-up vaccine clinic: Fri. 2/26 ONLY, 10am-1pm
	◦	BHS Bayani Health Center: 23251 S Main St. Carson, CA, 90745
	◦	All appointments are currently booked, but walk-ups may be able to receive extra doses if supplies remain. Early arrival recommended.
	◦	Only for healthcare workers or those 65+, bring ID / proof of occupation.
	•	Community Clinic run sites:
	◦	JWCH has a Lynwood clinic (3591 E Imperial Hwy, Lynwood, CA 90262)
	▪	If you are a patient with JWCH, contact your provider to book an appointment at the Lynwood site.
	▪	If you are not a JWCH client, you can contact the JWCH Bellflower Clinic site (14371 Clark Ave. Bellflower, CA 90706) to try and reserve an appointment online or by telephone (866) 733-5924, or (562) 867-7999
	◦	AltaMed - coming soon!
	•	Drugstore and pharmacy sites:
	◦	Rite Aid (locations in our district here)
	◦	CVS
	◦	Ralphs
	◦	Walgreens
	•	Long Beach vaccination sites, eligible Long Beach residents can sign up here.
** Note this may be a partial list. If you know of a site providing vaccines not on this list, please contact my office so we can help others in our community who want to get the vaccine.
  
￼
  
Second Dose Information
 
Residents Vaccinated at L.A. City Sites, Including Dodger Stadium
 
You will receive an email and text from Carbon Health with information about your second appointment 3-7 days before your second-dose appointment. Most appointments will be scheduled approximately 28 days after your first appointment and should be scheduled within the CDC recommended timeframe. If you have questions, reach out to your health provider or vaccine provider. 
 
Residents Vaccinated at Other Sites
 
For those who were vaccinated at the many dozens of other sites across the county, including pharmacies and health centers, please contact the provider or site where you were vaccinated if you have not heard from them about your second-dose appointment. They will be able to give you information regarding your second appointment.
  
 
Immigration Updates
 
  
In my role as Chairwoman of the Subcommittee on Border Security, I went to San Ysidro, the Port of Entry between San Diego and Tijuana on Monday. I was briefed by U.S. Customs and Border Protection officials and witnessed the first steps in phasing out the cruel and inhumane MPP or “Remain in Mexico” policy. I oversaw the arrival of migrants and their processing for entry and met with asylum seekers in the MPP program. I was able to see the challenges and success of the new process, including challenges registering eligible migrants which limits the number of migrants processed each day. Many of these migrants have waited for years in deplorable conditions to legally enter the U.S. to have their asylum cases heard. It was emotional to witness this long awaited day for many.
  
￼
￼
  
We need an immigration system that is fair and humane while providing immigrants who have lived in the United States a pathway to citizenship. That’s why I’m proud to support the US Citizenship Act. The bill, introduced this past Thursday, is  a comprehensive immigration bill that will provide an opportunity to earn citizenship to the hardworking people who enrich our communities every day and who have lived here for years (in some cases for decades).
  
 
Black History Month
 
  
￼
  
A Conversation with Clean Air Champions
 
It was great to chat with constituents and environmental activists Jackie Badejo and Linda Cleveland of the Watts Clean Air & Energy Committee on Facebook Live. We talked environmental justice, community organizing, and pathways for healthier communities.
  
Recognizing PFC James Anderson Jr.
 
This Black History Month, it's an honor to reintroduce a bill to rename a Compton Post Office after the first African-American Marine to receive the Medal of Honor, Private First Class James Anderson, Jr., a patriot and a hero in the purest sense.
  
￼
On February 28, 1967, while on patrol outside of a village in Quang Tri Province, PFC Anderson's platoon was ambushed and a grenade landed near PFC Anderson and his fellow Marines. Without hesitation, PFC Anderson absorbed the majority of the blast with his body, heroically saving the lives of the Marines around him at the cost of his own. PFC Anderson made the ultimate sacrifice for his  country and his fellow soldiers. Renaming the post office would honor his memory and be a reminder to the community he grew up in of his selfless sacrifice. 
  
 
Community Resources and Events
 
  
Crisis Text Line 
 
Your mental health is very important. If you, or any of your friends or family need someone to talk to, the Crisis Text Line can help. Text CRISIS to 741741 and you will be connected with a live, trained crisis counselor who is overseen by a trained staff supervisor in around 8-20 seconds. 
 
Willowbrook Library Resources & Services  
 
Willowbrook Library remains closed to the public, but they are offering a huge selection of virtual and remote resources. Their library, and many others in the county, have gone virtual! Visit their website to learn more. 

 
Grant Updates 
 
I am excited to announce a couple of federal grants that were awarded this week that will have a positive impact on our district:  

	•	The Northeast Community Clinic in Wilmington recieved $2.5M from the Department of Health and Human Services for the Health Center Program.  
	•	The Long Beach Water Department recieved $1.5M grant from the Bureau of Reclamation. I wrote a letter in support of this proposal.  
If your organization is interested in applying for federal grants, please contact my office to learn more about these funding opportunities.
  
 
Updates from Washington, D.C.
 
  
I'm back in D.C. this week to help push forward another critical coronavirus relief package to help constituents stay healthy and make ends meet. After work in committees, the House will now consider the President's American Rescue Plan, a landmark, life-saving legislation which we hope will be passed into law before unemployment benefits expire.
 

The President’s American Rescue Plan will help us return children safely to the classroom, get vaccines to everyone, put dollars into families’ pockets and put people back to work. More information here.
 
This week has two Homeland Security Committee hearings scheduled on the pandemic response one year later and cybersecurity.  Our last one this week if Friday, please tune in if you're interested.
 
On Friday, the House of Representatives will consider a major public lands conservation package of bills, which includes my Outdoors for All Act legislation.
 
The Outdoors for All Act supports funding for urban parks in underserved communities by establishing in law the Outdoor Recreation Legacy Partnership (ORLP) program, which makes critical investments in urban parks. Only two weeks ago, I successfully led the fight to save the program from being eliminated. Ensuring the continuation of the ORLP program is important for the 44th district and in Los Angeles County, where low income communities and communities of color lack equal access to local parks.

 
 
In Community,
  
￼
Nanette Diaz Barragán
Member of Congress, Congresista

Subject: Medicare-X: A Pathway to Universal Health Coverage through a Public Option
Message:
￼
Dear friend,
Expanding access to affordable health insurance options has long been a priority of mine, and the COVID-19 pandemic has demonstrated it's past time for the U.S. to significantly improve our health care system. With widespread job losses, exacerbated health disparities, and increasing health care costs, Congress has an urgent duty to expand access to high-quality, affordable care.
That's why this week, Senator Michael Bennet and I reintroduced the Medicare-X Choice Act, comprehensive legislation that would build on the Affordable Care Act to help millions more Americans, especially those in rural communities, access health care coverage while drastically reducing our health care costs.
The ACA expanded health insurance to an additional 20 million Americans. However, many Virginians still face high health care costs and limited options for affordable health insurance. Currently, there are 53 counties and independent cities in the Commonwealth that still have only one health insurer offering coverage on the exchange.
Medicare-X would build on the Medicare framework by establishing the Medicare Exchange (Medicare-X) Health Plan, a public option for uninsured individuals, families, and small businesses. People could then could compare the option with existing private plans when choosing their insurance.
Here's more on how our new Medicare-X legislation would help expand affordable health coverage:
• The public option would first be sold on the individual exchange in areas where there is a shortage of insurers or higher health care costs due to less competition, including rural communities, across Virginia. By 2025, the plan would expand to every ZIP code in the country.
• It would expand Medicare's network of doctors and providers and guarantee the essential health benefits established in the ACA, such as maternity care and mental health services.
• It would ensure access to affordable prescription drugs by empowering the Secretary of Health and Human Services to negotiate drug prices for the new Medicare-X plans and the Medicare Part D program.
• It would fix the "family glitch" in the ACA, making 2 to 6 million more Americans eligible for tax credits.
As we continue to combat one of the most devastating public health emergencies in the last century, we must pass this legislation to offer more Americans more quality, affordable health insurance choices and help them get the care they need. I'm committed to pushing forward on this next big step forward to make sure no Virginian - or American - is left behind in health care coverage moving forward.
Sincerely,
￼ 
 
Visit my website: kaine.senate.gov

Subject: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Malliotakis Introduces Resident Toll Commuter Relief Act
Message:
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
Friday, February 26, 2021

MEDIA CONTACT: Natalie Baldassarre 
Natalie.Baldassarre@mail.house.gov
(202) 841-8817
 

Malliotakis Introduces Resident Toll Commuter Relief Act
﻿
Malliotakis' first bill corrects predecessor's bad deal by ensuring that extra revenue derived from two-way tolling is given back to toll payers who reside on either side of the toll bridge
 

(WASHINGTON, DC) - Congresswoman Nicole Malliotakis (NY-11) today introduced her first bill, H.R.1356, the Resident Toll Commuter Relief Act, legislation that requires the extra revenue generated by moving from one-way tolling to two-way tolling, to be used to lower tolls or fund rebates and credits for individuals residing on landmasses on either side of the bridge. Applicable to the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge, this would provide a reduced toll to the residents of Staten Island and Brooklyn.  
 
"My predecessor was in a position to negotiate a fair deal for us, but instead chose to let the Metropolitan Transit Authority (MTA) pocket the extra revenue from going to two-way tolling, which is estimated to be $12 to 15 million," said Congresswoman Nicole Malliotakis. "My act rights the wrong of my predecessor's bad deal and simply returns extra revenue to the toll payers in our community. This is something that should have been negotiated by Rep. Max Rose to avoid putting more of a toll burden on our residents. At the time, I said that the money should be going back to the citizens, not to into the MTA's black hole." 
 
In 2019, language inserted into the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act by former Congressman Max Rose repealed language that banned two-way tolling on any bridge connecting the boroughs of Brooklyn and Staten Island. Currently, the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge has the second most expensive round trip bridge toll in the United States.
 
Malliotakis added: "I believe there was little to no benefit in moving to two-way tolling on the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge. The MTA's own study showed a 0.1 mph increase in traffic flow, and any reduction in vehicles during the morning commute is gained in the evening. The only true benefit for our community would be returning the extra revenue back to residents in the form of a toll reduction.” 
 
You can view Malliotakis' Resident Toll Commuter Relief Act HERE. 


###
 
  ‌   ‌ 

Congresswoman Nicole Malliotakis (NY-11) | 417 Cannon House Office Building, Washington, DC 20515

Subject: Boozman Bulletin: This Week in the Senate
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

     
      Boozman Bulletin: This Week in the Senate
 The Senate confirmed Tom Vilsack to serve as U.S. Secretary of Agriculture. Secretary Vilsack has a track record of working with Congress, and the strong bipartisan vote expresses the Senate’s confidence that he will continue that approach moving forward. Congress and the administration must work together to address the many pressing matters facing the ag community and rural America, particularly the need to provide swift relief to those affected by the ongoing pandemic. Building a good relationship with Secretary Vilsack will help us achieve our mutual goals while ensuring that the needs of farmers and ranchers are always at the forefront of USDA’s agenda. I spoke on the Senate floor in support of Secretary Vilsack’s confirmation. 
￼
 I’m proud to serve as the top Republican on the U.S. Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry this Congress. The committee has a well-deserved reputation as being among the most bipartisan on Capitol Hill. It is a place where committee members actually sit down around a table, hash out our differences and create policy that is good for American agriculture. I am confident this trend will continue as Chairwoman Debbie Stabenow (D-MI) and I work together to address the many challenges our agricultural producers face. My focus will be on efforts to address the impact of the pandemic, grow the farm economy, modernize important nutrition programs and expand opportunities across rural America. Read what Arkansans have to say about what my new role means to our state’s ag community.  

Follow Arkansas’s Lead & Reopen Schools   The Natural State can be proud of the teachers, administrators and elected leaders who continue finding ways to keep schools open and providing critical services children need. It’s time that students in other states have the same opportunities. In a speech on the Senate floor, I explained how Arkansas educators thought creatively and used federal COVID-19 relief aid to invest in cleaning supplies, barriers and retrofitted classrooms. Communities across the state faced different challenges, but Arkansas schools united under one goal: finding the best and safest way to get and keep children and teachers in the classroom.  The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) research recommends schools reopen. Earlier this month, the CDC issued new guidance to help schools safely open for in-person learning. While President Joe Biden pledged to reopen schools within his first 100 days in office, the administration is now backing away from the original goal. Getting students back in the classroom must be a priority.  

Protecting Health Care Workers from Discrimination 
This week I helped reintroduce the Conscience Protection Act to protect health care providers, including health insurance plans, from government discrimination if they decline to participate in abortions. The legislation also provides a private right of action for victims of discrimination. 
Our conscience rights are one of the most fundamental aspects in our society and democracy. Protecting the ability of health care workers to decline to violate their own deeply-held religious beliefs and convictions is absolutely necessary. I’m proud to join my colleagues in introducing this legislation that safeguards that option and provides opportunities for those discriminated against to receive their due process, including private legal action.
I will continue to advocate for policies that protect religious liberties and support legislation that promotes the value of life. 

Celebrating Black History Month 
February is Black History Month—a time to reflect on the influence of African Americans in our history and celebrate their achievements and contributions to the fabric of our nation. We commemorate the heroes of the African American community who fought injustice and triumphed in the face of adversity.   We honor individuals like the 16 Arkansans who served in the historic 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion, the first and only all-female, all-black battalion to be deployed overseas during WWII. The Women’s Army Corps launched the Six Triple Eight in November 1944 with more than 850 personnel assigned to sort the logjam of mail in the European Theater. We should all be inspired by the courage, determination and willingness of these women to serve our country, and in a uniquely special and necessary role. This week I cosponsored legislation to award the unit the Congressional Gold Medal. Such recognition would be a fitting tribute to commemorate the legacy of these trailblazing Americans and the role they played in our history.   
￼
 We continue to honor those who served their country in uniform. In the ‘Salute to Veterans’ series that honors Arkansas veterans, we featured the late Benjamin Haymon, a WWII veteran who served in the Pacific Theater. At the age of 31, he was considerably older than many of his brothers in arms when he was drafted in 1941. When Mr. Haymon passed away in 2019, he was the oldest known WWII veteran in our state. 

Constituent Corner   My staff and I remain committed to doing all we can to help during these challenging times. While some federal agencies are struggling to meet the changing demands of their services during the pandemic, we continue to get answers for Arkansans. 
￼
I am pleased my office was able to help Marecia navigate the Social Security process when she was having trouble getting updates on the status of her claim. The COVID-19 emergency has made communicating with many government agencies more difficult and I am happy we could help her bridge the gap. Let us help you. 

Connecting on Social Media 
Stay up to date with what I’m doing for Arkansans via social media. You can find me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

Subject: Take My Survey on the Pandemic Relief Package
Message:
Dear Lindsey,

The past year has been very challenging for our nation and for many of our neighbors. We have provided 5 bipartisan relief packages to help small businesses and individuals. There is still $1 trillion in unspent federal funding from the first 5 packages. While I believe more relief might be needed in some areas, we have an obligation to look at what is working, what is not and where the unmet needs are. Wanting transparency and accountability for how your tax dollars are spent should not be a partisan issue. I believe relief should be temporary, targeted and tied to COVID-19. We should not be using the suffering of Americans to play politics. 

The pandemic package that is currently before Congress includes nearly $2 trillion in spending. After excluding the stimulus payments to individuals, almost half of the bill's funding is not slated to be spent until after October 1, 2021. There seems to be an urgent need to pass a package, but I am troubled that those funds will not be used to help Americans who are suffering now. I am also concerned that less than 9% of the $1.9 trillion in proposed spending will go to combatting the virus through public health measures such as vaccination and more testing. Defeating the virus should be our primary objective- not using the crisis to pass a partisan wish list of items not related to COVID-19. 

I want to build consensus and move the country forward in a united manner. We have serious challenges facing our nation, and the American people deserve for their elected representatives to be serious and thoughtful about finding effective solutions to those problems. I would like to know your thoughts on this important subject. Your input on the brief survey below will be valuable in determining how I can best represent you.
 
Take this survey
 

 
Sincerely,
 


Congressman Bilirakis
 
Rep. Bilirakis, 2227 Rayburn HOB, Washington, DC 20901

Subject: Representative Adriano Espaillat Statement in Support of the $1.9 Trillion COVID-19 Relief Plan
Message:
￼ 
  

PRESS RELEASE
For Immediate Release
February 26, 2021


Representative Adriano Espaillat Statement in Support of the $1.9 Trillion COVID-19 Relief Plan

Espaillat Highlights Legislative Record as Transportation Champion


WASHINGTON, DC – Today, Representative Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) released the following statement in support of the $1.9 Trillion COVID-19 relief package put forth in President Biden’s American Rescue Plan:

“The American Rescue Plan is a robust vision that provides funding for vaccinations, transportation systems, unemployment assistance, support of state and local governments, and much more to help get Americans back on track as families continue to suffer due to the ongoing public health crisis,” said Rep. Adriano Espaillat. “I have long stood as a champion of public transportation and understand that such funding will provide critical support of entities like the Port Authority of New York as well as serve as a vital lifeline for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA), which require vigorous federal funding to remain operational to ensure the economy of New York comes back to life. 

“COVID-19 had an immediate and overwhelming effect on transportation systems in my district and around the nation and there are millions of transportation and construction jobs associated with them. Our legislation is aimed at helping ensure these essential transit projects that have already gone through rigorous, bipartisan processes can move forward, including projects in red and blue States across the country. 

“The Republicans misinformation campaign does not surprise me. Specifically, about the BART to San Jose project, which was approved under the Trump Administration, has among the highest local share of any transit capital project in the country, and is not receiving special funding. Additionally, the allocation for the Seaway International Bridge, which is not taxpayer funded, would help cover the tolling revenue shortfall due to restrictions against non-essential travel put into place as a direct result of the COVID pandemic. These projects impact their respective regions similarly to how funding the MTA and the Port Authority is vital to New York’s economy. 

“While American families continue to suffer due to the ongoing public health crisis, I urge my Republican colleagues to put an end to the partisan posturing and to join my House Democratic colleagues and I to put forth a package to help families build back stronger and to help them get their lives back on track and overcome this pandemic for good.”

# # #

Representative Espaillat is the first Dominican American to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives and his congressional district includes Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill and the north-west Bronx. First elected to Congress in 2016, Representative Espaillat is serving his third term in Congress. Representative Espaillat currently serves as a member of the influential U.S. House Committee on Appropriations responsible for funding the federal government’s vital activities. He is also a member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus (CHC), where he serves as the Second Vice Chair and is a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, where he serves as Deputy Whip. Representative Espaillat also currently serves as a Senior Whip of the Democratic Caucus. To find out more about Rep. Espaillat, visit online at https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Media inquiries: Candace Person at Candace.Person@mail.house.gov



Declaración del congresista Adriano Espaillat en apoyo del plan de ayuda por COVID-19 de $1.9 billones

Espaillat destaca récord legislativo como defensor del transporte


WASHINGTON, DC – Hoy, el congresista Adriano Espaillat (NY-13) emitió la siguiente declaración en apoyo del paquete de ayuda por COVID-19 de $1.9 billones (trillones en el sistema numérico inglés) presentado en el Plan de Rescate Estadounidense del presidente Biden:

“El Plan de Rescate Estadounidense es una visión sólida que proporciona fondos para vacunas, sistemas de transporte, asistencia por desempleo, apoyo a los gobiernos estatales y locales, y mucho más para ayudar a que los estadounidenses se recuperen en momentos en que las familias continúan sufriendo debido a la actual crisis de salud pública”, dijo el Rep. Adriano Espaillat. “Durante mucho tiempo me he mantenido como un defensor del transporte público y entiendo que dichos fondos brindarán un apoyo fundamental a entidades como la Autoridad Portuaria de Nueva York y también servirán como un sustento vital para la Autoridad Metropolitana de Transporte (MTA), que requiere fondos para seguir funcionando para garantizar que la economía de Nueva York vuelva a la vida.

“El COVID-19 tuvo un efecto inmediato y abrumador en los sistemas de transporte en mi distrito y en todo el país y hay millones de empleos de transporte y construcción asociados con ellos. Nuestra legislación tiene como objetivo ayudar a garantizar que estos proyectos de transporte esenciales que ya han pasado por procesos bipartidistas rigurosos puedan avanzar, incluidos los proyectos en los estados rojo y azul de todo el país.

“La campaña de desinformación de los republicanos no me sorprende. Específicamente, sobre el proyecto de BART a San José, que fue aprobado bajo la Administración Trump, tiene una de las cuotas locales más altas de cualquier proyecto de capital de transporte en la nación y no está recibiendo fondos especiales. Además, la asignación para el Puente Internacional Seaway, que no es financiado por los contribuyentes, ayudaría a cubrir el déficit de ingresos por peajes debido a las restricciones contra los viajes no esenciales implementadas como resultado directo de la pandemia de COVID. Estos proyectos impactan en sus respectivas regiones de manera similar a cómo financiar la MTA y la Autoridad Portuaria es vital para la economía de Nueva York.

“Mientras las familias estadounidenses continúan sufriendo debido a la actual crisis de salud pública, insto a mis colegas republicanos a que pongan fin a la postura partidista y se unan a mis colegas demócratas de la Cámara y a mí para introducir un paquete para ayudar a las familias a recuperarse más fuertes y ayudarlas a volver a encarrilar sus vidas y superar esta pandemia para siempre".

# # #

El congresista Espaillat es el primer domínico-estadounidense en servir en la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos y su distrito congresual incluye las comunidades de Harlem, East Harlem, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights, Inwood, Marble Hill y el noroeste del Bronx. Elegido por primera vez al Congreso en 2016, el congresista Espaillat cumple su tercer mandato en el Congreso. El congresista Espaillat actualmente se desempeña como miembro del influyente Comité de Apropiaciones de la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos, responsable de financiar las actividades vitales del Gobierno federal. También es miembro del Caucus Hispano del Congreso (CHC), donde se desempeña como segundo vicepresidente y es miembro del Caucus Progresista del Congreso, donde se desempeña como subcoordinador (Deputy Whip). El congresista Espaillat también se desempeña actualmente como coordinador sénior del Caucus Demócrata. Para obtener más información sobre el congresista Espaillat, visite su portal en línea en https://espaillat.house.gov/.

Preguntas de los medios: Candace Randle Person a Candace.Person@mail.house.gov

Subject: Equality For All!
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Congresswoman Beatty Heralds Historic House Passage of Equality Act   Helped lead introduction of LGBTQ+ rights bill
Yesterday, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the Equality Act, H.R. 5, comprehensive civil rights legislation that prohibits discrimination against members of the LGBTQ+ community in employment, education, credit, jury service, federal funding, housing, and public accommodations. Reacting to the vote, U.S. Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (OH-03), an original cosponsor of the Equality Act, issued the following statement:   
“No one should lose their job, be kicked out of their home, forced to leave school, or sacrifice their livelihood because of who they love or how they identify. Yet, in 2021, a person can get married on a Sunday and fired on Monday—or even face financial ruin—for those very reasons. I am proud to stand in strong solidarity with the LGBTQ+ community in Ohio’s Third Congressional District and across this great nation, and I call on the Senate to pass the Equality Act quickly. Let’s finally guarantee that all Americans are treated equally under the law.”

Subject: Matt's Weekly Memo -- Delivering COVID-19 Relief
Message:
Click here to view this email in your browser 
￼

 
Delivering COVID-19 Relief
 
  
Dear Lindsey,
 
In December when we had to compromise with Senate Leader Mitch McConnell to pass a much needed COVID-19 relief bill, I told you I'd vote for it but that I'd get right to work on more aid in 2021. It was clear we needed to do more to speed up vaccine distribution and ensure everyone's economic wellbeing, and that's why we've been working hard in the House to put the president's American Rescue Plan into writing.
 
This week we are getting it done. 
 
The American Rescue Plan is coming to the House floor today, and I will be supporting it. First, it invests in vaccine distribution and production, speeding up the process of getting shots in arms. The sooner we get the virus under control, the sooner we can recover and rebuild.
 
Second, it invests in our communities. We also need to get folks back to school, back to work, and put dollars back into people's pockets. The $1,400 stimulus checks and other economic lifelines this plan provides will protect working families from falling further behind.
 
These are the key pillars of the
American Rescue Plan:
  
￼
  
Our goal is to pass it in the House this week, then send it to the Senate and have it signed by President Biden as soon as possible. Enacting this bill quickly will help us crush COVID-19, get our economy moving again and get our kids back in school.
  
 
Quickly & Efficiently Delivering Stimulus Checks
 
  
Lots of Northeastern Pennsylvanians told me throughout last year they had difficulty receiving their stimulus checks.
 
Earlier this week, I raised those concerns again with with IRS Commissioner during an Appropriations Subcommittee hearing to ensure his department is ready to help Americans receive future payments as quickly and as early as possible. Americans can't afford to experience continued issues and the IRS is essential in delivering economic relief to Americans across the country. 
 
Here is my exchange with the IRS Commissioner this week:
  
 
￼
 
  
 
Federal Dollars at Work in NEPA
 
  
Yesterday, I announced that Luzerne County Head Start has received its second installment of a federal grant for 2021. The installment of nearly $5 million will be used to continue providing young students in our area with a strong foundation for success later in life. As a senior member of the Appropriations Committee, I will continue to fight for federal investment in our children’s success, which is our country’s future success.
  
Read More
  
Last week, I was so proud to announce that four fire companies will be awarded federal funds to provide additional personal protective equipment (PPE) and essential supplies that will help keep them safe on the job. 
 
These grants are a critical resource for firefighters and communities in Northeastern Pennsylvania and we should continue investing in equipment that aids the incredible work they do.   
  
Read More
  
 
COVID-19 Vaccine Dashboard
 
  
**Two Important Vaccine Updates**
 
Winter weather complicated vaccine distribution last week, and that unfortunately led to some delayed appointments. But things are getting back on track as the backlogs clear, and appointment availability should be picking up once again.
 
Let's end the week on a high note. We hit a significant milestone this week: all nursing facility residents and staff in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania who opted in to receive a COVID-19 vaccine are fully vaccinated with both doses. Our seniors who live in nursing homes have been the most vulnerable to this virus, and the staff charged with protecting them have been among the most challenged during this pandemic. I'm grateful to all the health care workers who had a hand in this achievement.
 
Here's the latest on vaccine distribution in PA-08.
  
￼
  
Be safe and well,
  

￼
  

  
You are receiving this email because you opt-ed in for periodic updates from my office.

Subject: Newsletter
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website  |  View Online 
￼

Dear Lindsey,
 
It's been a busy 2 weeks for my office. I drove nearly 2,500 miles across our state and visited with small business owners, local officials, and concerned Montanans to talk about what's going on in our nation's capital.
 While traveling across Eastern Montana, I visited several local businesses including American Harvest, a hemp processing facility in Sidney; Eastern Montana Meats; and Meadowlark Brewing. 
.
￼
American Harvest
.
￼
￼
                                      Meadowlark Brewing                                                                                               Eastern Montana Meats
.
In Fallon County, I visited with local officials who explained how President Biden's decision to kill the Keystone XL Pipeline has already had a negative impact on their community. 
 
The Mayor of Baker and County Commissioners of Fallon showed me area that was supposed to be housing for Keystone XL workers and shared how the pipeline's cancellation will hurt the economic recovery of their community from the pandemic.
.  
￼
(click to watch)
.
When Montanans were experiencing electric blackouts, I was able to visit McCone Electric Co-op General Manager Michael Hoy and received an explainer on electric failures. 
.
￼
(click to watch)
.
I also received a tour of the Phillips 66 refinery in Billings and paid a visit to the Raymond Port of Entry at our Northern Border. 
 
In both places, I spoke with leaders about what they need to succeed with their tasks which are both so essential to our state. 
.
￼
￼
                                       Raymond Port of Entry                                                                                           Phillips 66 Refinery
.
When I wasn't in Montana, I was busy focusing on important policy issues in DC that impact you back home. 
 
I introduced two pieces of legislation, The Forest Information Reform (FIR) Act and the REMAIN in Mexico Act.
 
The FIR Act amends the Cottonwood requirements for re-consultation in Forest Service plans when new information is found. This legislation allows the Forest Service to incorporate new information into their current plan rather than starting from scratch.
 
This bill is a common sense solution that will bring Forest Service Management out of a perpetual cycle of litigation and into a new era of efficiency by reversing the disastrous Cottonwood decision
 
The REMAIN in Mexico Act directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to continue to implement the Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP) implemented in January 2019 under Secretary Nielsen, which stipulates that non-Mexican nationals who arrive at or cross our southern border and claim asylum, but fail to meet the “credible fear test” are returned to Mexico to await the adjudication of their asylum claim.
 
We experienced the danger of the Obama-Biden practice of ‘catch and release.’ The Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP) was one of the most effective policies to help end this practice. 
 
Montana may be far from the southern border, but ‘catch and release’ allows the immigration crisis to come to every town in America. It’s my hope that this legislation will deter illegal immigration, help Border Patrol secure our border, and keep the rest of our country safe.
 
I've been fighting for increased vaccine shipments for Montana and sent a letter to the Biden Administration requesting they increase the amount of vaccines they're sending to our state. Earlier this week we heard the good news that the Biden Administration is listening and have sent more vaccines our way!
 
I co-sponsored the VA VACCINE Act, which allows the VA to offer COVID-19 vaccines to all veterans regardless of their eligibility to enroll in the VA healthcare system, caregivers of veterans in certain long-term and home-based care programs, as well as veterans living abroad who rely on the Foreign Medical Program.
 
I am also glad to be helping Kevin McLean, a community leader in Helena who is gathering supplies to send to families struggling from the recent winter storms in Texas. Kevin is sharing updates on his progress and ways you can help on his Instagram page.
 
Thanks for following along with the ways my office is serving the taxpayers of Montana. To receive updates in real time, please follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.

Subject: Brett's Bulletin: Updates for KY-02
Message:
February 26, 2021 
￼ 
￼ 
 


Dear Friends,
Sadly, this week we crossed a terrible milestone with more than 500,000 Americans lost due to COVID-19, including more than 4,500 Kentuckians. We remember all of the family, friends, neighbors, mentors, and many others taken too soon by this awful virus. With two safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines currently being administered each day to people in the Commonwealth and across the country, we move closer to defeating COVID-19 and returning to a sense of normalcy. I am hopeful that very soon we will have another vaccine approved for distribution to increase our vaccine supply. In Kentucky, we have had declining COVID-19 cases for six weeks in a row. I want to thank everyone who is taking COVID-19 precautions in order to make this possible. I also want to encourage everyone to roll up their sleeves when they have the opportunity to be vaccinated. Today, I want to share how I’m helping with vaccine distribution as your representative in Congress and share resources for receiving COVID-19 vaccines in Kentucky. 
Vaccine Work
￼
Rep. Guthrie speaking at a recent Health Subcommittee hearing
Defeating COVID-19 with safe and effective vaccines is my main focus in Congress. Through my oversight role on the Energy and Commerce Committee, I know that these vaccines have been developed with high efficacy requirements and without cutting any safety corners. I have supported five COVID-19 relief packages to help Kentucky families, workers, and businesses. These bills have included funding for development and manufacturing of COVID-19 vaccines and therapeutics. Summaries of each of the COVID-19 relief packages can be found HERE. I recently supported $8.75 billion to help states with vaccine distribution. Recently, Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) awarded $46.9 million to Kentucky for administering vaccines. In January, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) awarded more than $297 million to Kentucky for vaccine distribution and COVID-19 testing.
Through my senior leadership roles on the Energy and Commerce Committee, I have led hearings on COVID-19 vaccines and developed policy recommendations to help meet the ultimate goal of delivering vaccines to all Americans. I am committed to continuing this work on COVID-19 vaccines in my leadership role this Congress as the Republican Leader of the Health Subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee. This committee has jurisdiction over HHS, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and other federal health agencies involved with COVID-19 response efforts. I will not stop working until all Kentuckians have had the opportunity to be vaccinated for COVID-19. 
Where to Find Vaccines
Kentucky Regional Sites On March 1, regional COVID-19 vaccination sites will open to Phase 1C in Kentucky. While I help ensure federal resources are available for Kentucky for vaccine distribution and other COVID-19 needs, decisions on vaccine eligibility phases are made by the state government. Phase 1C expands vaccine eligibility to all essential workers as well as Kentuckians who are 60 years old and older or 16 years and older with certain high-risk conditions. Kentuckians in Phase 1A and 1B will still be able to be vaccinated. You can also complete an online form to learn what phase you are in by clicking HERE or you can call 855-598-2246. A map of regional vaccination sites can be found HERE, and the COVID-19 hotline to answer questions is 800-722-5725. Below is a list of regional vaccination sites located in Kentucky’s Second District and how to schedule an appointment or vaccine information at the respective site.
TJ Health Pavilion (Barren County) 310 North L. Rogers Wells Blvd. Glasgow, KY 42141 Click HERE for COVID-19 vaccine updates Schedule by phone: 270-659-1010
Ephraim McDowell Regional Medical Center (Boyle County) 217 South Third Street Danville, KY 40422 Click HERE to schedule online Schedule by phone: 859-936-8350
Owensboro Health Regional Hospital (Daviess County) 1201 Pleasant Valley Road Owensboro, KY 42303 Schedule by phone: 270-685-7100 option #6 Click HERE to schedule online  Owensboro Health Twin Lakes Medical Center (Grayson County) 910 Wallace Ave. Leitchfield, KY 42754 Click HERE to schedule online
Baptist Health Hardin (Hardin County) 913 N Dixie Hwy Elizabethtown, KY 42701 Schedule by phone: 270-706-1004 Click HERE for COVID-19 vaccine updates
The Medical Center at Bowling Green (Warren County) 250 Park Street Bowling Green, KY 42101 Healthcare workers: Text SHOT to 270-796-3200 K-12; childcare personnel: Text SCHOOL to 270-796-3200 Ages 60+: Text SENIOR to 270-796-3200 Other individuals in phase 1C: Text COVID to 270-796-4400 Click HERE for COVID-19 vaccine updates
Greenwood Mall (Warren County) 2625 Scottsville Road Bowling Green, KY 42104 Click HERE to schedule online
Additional Sites Kroger Retail – Click HERE to schedule online Walgreens Retail – Click HERE to schedule online (need a Walgreens account) Walmart Retail – Click HERE to schedule online Kentucky COVID-19 Vaccine Federal Partnership Sites – Click HERE for locations
Veterans Affairs Sites VA medical centers are offering COVID-19 vaccines to certain veterans enrolled in care at the VA. Health care staff with the VA are contacting veterans based on eligibility to schedule an appointment. The VA also has a “Keep Me Informed” tool you can find HERE. Below are links to COVID-19 information pages for VA medical centers that serve Kentuckians in the Second District.
Lexington VA Health Care System – Click HERE for more info Marion VA Medical Center – Click HERE for more info Robley Rex VA Medical Center – Click HERE for more info  Tennessee Valley Healthcare System – Click HERE for more info  
My office and I are happy to assist you and help navigate federal agencies on your behalf. To contact my office, please click HERE or call 270-842-9896.
 
￼
BRETT GUTHRIE
Member of Congress

Subject: Blaine's Bulletin: FFA Week
Message:
￼ 
February 26, 2021
For Immediate Release | Contact: Georgeanna Sullivan (202) 225-2956 

BLAINE'S BULLETIN: FFA WEEK
With 2/3 of our state covered in farmland and being home to the second highest number of farms in the nation, Missouri knows a little something about the agricultural business. Our state is home to generations of skilled ag producers who play a critical role in our local economies, job market and food supply chain. And with an $88 billion agriculture industry, Missouri is not only a major supplier for the nation but the entire world. This week is Future Farmers of America (FFA) Week and with over 25,000 active Missouri FFA members, I am extremely encouraged that our state’s strong agricultural tradition will continue and grow with the next generation of Missourians. 
The FFA was started in 1928 by a group of young farmers with the mission to “prepare future generations for the challenges of feeding a growing population.” This still remains a major pillar of the FFA’s mission, but the organization has evolved over the years as agricultural opportunities have expanded and the industry has become more comprehensive. While planting and harvesting of course will remain the priority, FFA also helps high school students explore other areas of the industry and potential careers in agricultural biology, engineering, chemistry, veterinary care and business ownership. Through classroom education and hands-on, real world experience to help develop skills in areas of interest, FFA is helping keep Missouri’s agriculture industry alive and well. And with the members of our state’s organization achieving the highest number of American FFA Degrees – the highest achievable honor in FFA – of any state in the country, it looks like Missouri will continue to be a national industry leader. 
Not only does Missouri continue to be one of the biggest contributors to our nation’s traditional agricultural industry, but we have become a global leader in agricultural technology. Organizations like FFA are helping the next generation of agricultural enthusiasts learn about the technological advancements in the industry. Every day, researchers are figuring out ways things like drones, satellites and robots can be used to make life in one of the world’s most unpredictable industries a little bit easier. Our state has such a high concentration of researchers, innovators, and producers that we are now home to the “Ag Coast” of America, have become a major hub for agricultural science, and are helping set the “AgTech” tone for the rest of world. 
Farming and ranching are quintessentially Missourian and I’m grateful that organizations like FFA are helping keep our agricultural tradition going by providing education and experience to our state’s students. This industry has fed and supported families in our state for generations, my own being no exception. I helped pay my way through college raising hogs and cattle and my wife and I still run our family farm in St. Elizabeth. It can be one of the most challenging jobs there is, but also one of the most rewarding. Farmers and ranchers are tasked with feeding the world, and as the Representative of one of the top producing states in America, I will continue to do everything in my power to help Missouri farmers in Congress.
CONTACT US: As always, for those of you with Internet access, I encourage you to visit my official website. For those without access to the Internet, I encourage you to call my offices in Jefferson City (573-635-7232) Washington, Mo. (636-239-2276), or Wentzville (636-327-7055) with your questions and concerns. If you want even greater access to what I am working on, please visit my YouTube site, Facebook page, and keep up-to-date with Twitter and Instagram.
###

Subject: Baldwin Supports Bipartisan Legislation to Help Struggling Restaurants in Wisconsin
Message:
￼ 


  
Dear Lindsey, 
Senator Baldwin is supporting the reintroduction of the bipartisan, bicameral RESTAURANTS Act of 2021.   Supported by the Wisconsin Restaurant Association, the legislation is an updated proposal to establish a $120 billion revitalization fund to support independent restaurants and small franchisees as they deal with the long-term structural challenges facing the industry because of COVID-19. 
“For the last year, local restaurants and workers across Wisconsin have fought to keep their doors open, and they need our support now more than ever to survive this economic crisis,” said Senator Baldwin. “Many small and independent restaurants are operating at reduced capacity and may be forced to close their doors for good if we don’t act now. Our legislation will create a new revitalization fund that will help folks in Wisconsin and across the country get through this pandemic and keep our Made in Wisconsin economy moving forward.”  “Restaurants have suffered more losses in jobs and revenue than any other sector because of the COVID-19 pandemic,” said Kristine Hillmer, President & CEO of the Wisconsin Restaurant Association. “We have already lost many unique restaurants in our state that were the cornerstones of their communities. The majority of the remaining restaurant owners believe that it will be 7 to 12 months, or more, before business conditions return to normal for their restaurant. Restaurants need specific and targeted assistance to survive. The RESTAURANTS Act of 2021 establishes a $120 billion “Restaurant Revitalization Fund” to provide direct grants to eligible entities. The RESTAURANTS Act is vital to helping Wisconsin’s restaurants and restaurant employees survive the devastating impact of the pandemic and sustaining our state’s once vibrant restaurant industry.”  “We fully support the bipartisan RESTAURANTS Act of 2021 which addresses the incredible hardship restaurant and taproom operators like us have experienced over the past year,” said Dan Katt, Co-Founder & CEO of Good City Brewing, LLC in Milwaukee. “Our taproom restaurant in downtown Milwaukee is adjacent to Fiserv Forum and was forced to close on March 12, 2020 when the NBA season was suspended. Our revenue at that location dropped by 95% over the past year and while Paycheck Protection Program has helped us stay in business and keep many of our key employees, we face incredible hurdles to be able hire new staff, pay rent, and fulfill debt obligations in the future as we will not be able to operate at 100% capacity for many months. This is a critical piece of legislation that will help a small locally-owned business like ours eventually recover from an incredibly challenging time.”  “COVID-19 has greatly impacted our business. Since reopening on June 2, 2021 our sales have been reduced by approximately 40%,” said Jon Seybold, Owner of Houligans Steak & Seafood Pub in Eau Claire. “Even though the Paycheck Protection Program has helped, we are still playing ‘catch up’ financially. We had to use all of our business savings just to survive the 2+ month forced shutdown. The aid in the RESTAURANTS Act of 2021 could allow us to expand outdoor dining opportunities which are sure to be in high demand this upcoming season. The aid could also allow us to explore modifying our banquet room into extra dining since banquet business has ‘dried up’ and we believe we will be need to keep some type of social distancing well into the future.” 
The bipartisan RESTAURANTS Act of 2021 is modeled after legislation the authors introduced last Congress. Their new proposal would create a $120 billion Restaurant Revitalization Fund to provide relief to food service or drinking establishments that are part of a group of up to 20 facilities. Owners could apply for grants of up to $10 million to cover eligible expenses retroactively to February 15, 2020, and ending eight months after the legislation is signed into law.  Grants could be used to support payroll, benefits, mortgage, rent, utilities, building maintenance and construction of outdoor facilities, supplies (including protective equipment and cleaning materials), food, operational expenses, paid sick leave, debt obligations to suppliers, and any other essential expenses.  The bipartisan RESTAURANTS Act of 2021 also includes several new provisions to help restaurants and their employees and ensure the integrity of the program. These provisions would: 
	•	Update the award calculation based on annual loss from calendar year 2020 rather than quarterly.
	•	Provide grant eligibility for new restaurants that opened after January 1, 2020.
	•	Provide paid sick leave as an eligible expense for employees and provides a bonus amount to cover the cost of voluntarily providing 10 days of sick leave to employees.
	•	Provide Treasury the discretion to help reduce waste, fraud, and abuse.
	•	Impose reporting obligations on the Department of the Treasury to share who gets loans and demographic information about the recipients.
	•	Ensure that restaurants can use both the Employee Retention Tax Credit and the RESTAURANTS Act grant program, so long as they are not used for the same expenses.
Read more about the bipartisan RESTAURANTS Act of 2021 and see why the bill is also supported by the Independent Restaurant Coalition (IRC) and the National Restaurant Association (NRA) here. 


￼ ￼  ￼  ￼

Subject: An Ounce of Prevention is Worth a Pound of Cure
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
U.S. Representative Billy Long
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER	      
February 26, 2021


An Ounce of Prevention is Worth a Pound of Cure 



It seems like every week or two there is a new story about personal information being stolen, corporate secrets taken and government agencies hacked. These threats are real, and we need to combat them. Over the years, nefarious actors have become relentless in their pursuit to hack U.S.-based companies, individuals, and the federal government.  The scale and frequency of these attacks continue to grow at an alarming pace. Now more than ever, the federal government and the private sector need to work together to protect our nation’s cyberinfrastructure. 

Cyberattacks can come from anywhere at any time. Nefarious actors can be a lone individual, a group of individuals, a terrorist organization, or a foreign government. The most recent cyberattack, dubbed 'Solar Winds', is a perfect example of why cybersecurity needs to be a top priority in this Congress and for the Biden Administration. The perpetrators of this attack, allegedly working with or for the Russian government, breached dozens of private companies and federal agencies. When all is said and done, this will likely be one of the most significant cyber breaches ever perpetrated against the federal government. Not to mention absolutely the most costly to taxpayers as systems will need to be destroyed and rebuilt across several different agencies and departments. The fact that Solar Winds was able to operate unabated for years is simply inexcusable and certainly not acceptable. This attack cannot be addressed by simply replacing software. These systems will need to be blown up at the hardware level and completely new systems will need to be developed and installed. Not an inexpensive undertaking across several federal agencies. Hence, the title of this weeks 'Long's Short Report' - " An Ounce of Prevention is Worth a Pound of Cure ."

Whether it is this attack by Russia, the Chinese stealing intellectual property, or hacking groups attacking websites or corporations, we need to come up with a comprehensive plan to protect our nation’s cyberinfrastructure. A key to this is working hand in hand with the private sector. Congress needs to formulate a plan to facilitate public-private partnerships with cybersecurity firms and corporations. This will be key in ensuring that both public and private information technology infrastructure is secure from cyber threats. These public-private partnerships must also focus on securing the supply chain. President Trump made great strides in ensuring the supply chain is secure by removing Chinese telecommunications equipment and I hope that President Biden follows suit.

There is only so much the government can do though. A key part of making sure that your personal information is safe from hackers is to remain vigilant. Never give your personal information to someone over the phone, through email, or any other form of communication unless you absolutely trust them. Never use the same password across multiple platforms. If a company that has your personal information suffers a cyber-attack and your password is compromised, hackers can get into other accounts that you may have. Having a separate password across your online accounts will limit your exposure should your information be stolen in a cyber-attack.

Together, individuals, the federal government, and the private sector can work to prepare for and protect our nation from cyber-attacks. The federal government needs to take these cyber-attacks seriously. And in the category of 'too little too late' Congress needs to create a bipartisan, apolitical framework to protect our cyberinfrastructure, secure federal information technology infrastructure, and ensure that our intellectual property is protected. While running for President, President Biden stated he will not stand idly by in the face of cyberassaults on our nation. I hope that he will make good on his word and am looking forward to working with the President and my colleagues to come up with a plan to protect our nation from cyberattacks. 

For more information on my activities in our district and in Washington, I encourage you to follow my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/Rep.Billy.Long and my Twitter page at https://twitter.com/USRepLong. You can also subscribe to my weekly newsletter, "Long's Short Report,” by visiting https://longforms.house.gov/newsletter-and-email-updates-form.

Subject: Congressman Gosar Denounces Democrat Land Grab in His District
Message:
For Immediate Release
Contact: Jessica Lycos
Date: February 26, 2021
jessica.lycos@mail.house.gov
 
Congressman Gosar Denounces Democrat Land Grab in His District
 


WASHINGTON D.C. - Congressman Paul Gosar (AZ-04) issued the following statement after voting against H.R. 803, the Grand Canyon Protection Act.



“This falsely-named legislation has absolutely nothing to do with protecting the Grand Canyon. Instead, it is an open attack on Northern Arizona mining and the hard-working people of my district.



Speaker Pelosi and her liberal allies refused to hold a single hearing for meaningful consideration or debate of this legislation. In doing so, Democrats foisted a massive land grab of more than one million acres and permanently banned mining and other multiple-use activities in our great state of Arizona.



It is estimated that this harmful bill will destroy as many as 4,000 jobs and cost $29 billion in sacrificed economic activity. The withdrawal area also contains 4,204 acres belonging to the Arizona State Land Department for the benefit of Arizona’s school children. This withdrawal will mean hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenues for local communities and for our schools.

 

This bill is also an attempt to lock out the ability to mine high-grade uranium, a critical element for carbon-free renewable energy that has irreplaceable applications in defense and medicine. The real beneficiaries of this bill are Russia and other bad state actors who we must turn to in order to secure uranium for our domestic needs.



Because the domestic supply is scant, the United States imports 97% of uranium from foreign sources, including Russia. If we pass bills like the Grand Canyon Preservation Act, we will forever close this area and soon 100% of our uranium will be supplied by foreign nations. At the same time, our ability to provide for the defense or our nation and other necessary industries will be comprised because of this bill.



I urge my colleagues in the Senate to defeat this badly flawed legislation,” said Rep. Gosar.



###

Subject: Senator Rosen's Senate Briefing
Message:
￼ 

  
Dear Fellow Nevadan, 
Welcome to this week’s edition of the Senate Briefing. The Senate is back in session this week. We’ve been busy holding confirmation hearings, introducing legislation, and more. 

￼
I’m excited and honored to serve as Chair of the newly formed subcommittee on Tourism, Trade, and Export Promotion!   Tourism-related industries drive job creation and economic growth in states across the country. The COVID-19 pandemic has posed significant challenges for Nevada’s tourism-heavy economy, and in communities across our nation that rely on travel, tourism, hospitality, and live entertainment. In this new leadership position, I pledge to work tirelessly to support the sustainable recovery of the tourism industry, highlight the challenges that our tourism-centered businesses face, and advocate for critical support as we recover from this ongoing economic crisis. I will also strive to support fair trade and export deals that protect American jobs, promote growth, and strengthen the economies of Nevada and the United States.
Are you looking forward to the work Senator Rosen will be doing as Chair of the Tourism, Trade, and Export Promotion subcommittee? 

￼
I recently introduced an important bipartisan bill with Senator Susan Collins (R-ME) to increase access to fast and reliable broadband service to unserved communities.  The American Broadband Buildout Act will provide up to $15 billion in matching grants to increase high-speed internet access for rural homes and businesses. 
￼

  
￼
IN THE NEWS 

￼



Jacky Rosen to chair new Senate subcommittee on tourism, trade
"U.S. Sen. Jacky Rosen will chair a newly created Senate subcommittee with jurisdiction over tourism and trade, a boost for a state crippled economically by the coronavirus pandemic, officials said Thursday…  Rosen said she would use her new position to support recovery of the tourism industry and advocate for critical support as the state recovers from the ongoing economic crisis.” 
￼
UNLV’s $2M share of federal grant will fuel nuclear research 
"UNLV will receive $2 million over five years from the Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration, U.S. Sen. Jacky Rosen said in a Wednesday news release. 
 ‘Congratulations to UNLV for receiving this funding, which will help to advance their research in nuclear science, engineering, and safety — all issues important to the state of Nevada,’ Rosen said. ‘The research UNLV is conducting will further our goals of development, while working to advance measures that keep our nation’s nuclear stockpile safe and secure.’” 
  






￼


MEDIA CENTER 
At this week’s Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee hearing, we got our first opportunity to question security officials on the events of January 6th. I asked our security officials what they knew about the violent January 6 attack on our Capitol, and when they knew it – as well as the threat of future attacks. Watch our full exchange: 
￼



￼
I WANT TO HEAR FROM YOU 
As always, I want to hear from you. Contact my office, find me on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, email me, or sign up for my e-newsletter to receive regular updates on my legislative work. 
It’s an absolute honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, 
￼
  
  
  
  
Jacky Rosen U.S. Senator for Nevada 
Washington, DC 
144 Russell Senate Office Building 
Washington, DC 20510 
Phone: 202-224-6244
Las Vegas 
333 Las Vegas Boulevard South, Suite 8203 
Las Vegas, NV 89101 
Phone: 702-388-0205
Reno

Reno, NV 89501
