Subject: Against Speaker Pelosi's Bailout Bill
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | Contact
LESS THAN 9% OF $1.9 TRILLION BILL WOULD FIGHT COVID
￼
A few hours ago, in a middle-of-the-night vote, the House passed Speaker Pelosi’s $1.9 trillion bailout bill – even though more than $1 trillion in existing COVID relief funding remains unspent.
As safe and effective vaccines get us closer to ending this pandemic, we should be focused on defeating coronavirus, getting Americans back to work, and helping small businesses recover.
Instead, Democrats tossed bipartisanship aside for a rushed, one-sided, $1.9 trillion spending bill – with less than 9% actually going to fight COVID.
￼
There hasn’t even been a full accounting of $1 trillion in unspent relief funds, but Speaker Pelosi wants taxpayers to foot the bill for trillions more. That’s why this week I cosponsored a resolution requesting information from the Biden administration about the remaining funds from previous relief measures.
Despite claims the massive reconciliation bill is needed as an emergency COVID relief measure, much of the funding – $670 billion – would not be spent until fiscal year 2022 or later. 
This massive bailout will send Hoosier tax dollars to fiscally irresponsible cities and states, allow taxpayer funding for abortion, and make it harder for small businesses to hire workers and rebuild our economy.
This is not the unity President Biden once called for, it’s certainly not the targeted COVID relief our country needs.
NO TAXPAYER FUNDING FOR ABORTION
￼
Speaker Pelosi’s partisan $1.9 trillion spending bill also excludes critical pro-life provisions.
Hyde protections to prohibit taxpayer funding for elective abortions have been in place under every president since Ford. Even President Biden supported them as a senator.
But now House Democrats have abandoned nearly a half-century of bipartisan consensus.
I offered an amendment in the Ways and Means Committee to preserve this important pro-life safeguard. I also joined my colleagues in submitting a similar amendment for Floor consideration. 
Democrats rejected both.
￼
You can watch my speech on the House floor urging my colleagues to join me in protecting innocent life by opposing this bill.
This is a moment that calls for healing, not destruction. It’s sad to see partisanship take priority over the most vulnerable among us: the unborn.
I believe every human life is precious, and taxpayers should not be forced to pay for the destruction of life. I won’t stop fighting to defend life and protect the conscience rights of every American.
IRAN SANCTIONS
￼
Iran took advantage of weak policies during the Obama Administration, and President Biden must not repeat those same mistakes.
I joined 42 Republicans in the House and Senate in introducing a resolution to make it clear that until the Iranian regime has put an end to its nuclear-weapon program and no longer sponsors terrorists, the U.S. must maintain sanctions.
You can read the resolution here.
SAFE & EFFECTIVE VACCINES 
￼
I’m fully confident the vaccines approved by the FDA are safe and effective, and they are the key to our nation’s recovery. I will continue working with federal, state, and local officials to ensure vaccine doses are distributed in our communities as efficiently as possible so that together we can defeat this invisible enemy. 
Indiana is continuing its phased plan to administer FDA-approved vaccines, starting with frontline health care workers, residents and staff of long-term care facilities, and now all Hoosiers aged 60 or older.
The state has opened hundreds of vaccination sites with at least one in every county, and so far 531,962 Hoosiers have been fully vaccinated. Vaccines administered by the state are free to all Indiana residents, but insurance may be charged an administrative fee.
To register and to find the nearest vaccination clinic, call 2-1-1 or visit OurShot.in.gov. The second dose will be scheduled at the clinic when the first dose is administered. A caregiver or loved one also may make an appointment on behalf of an eligible senior.
This week, the state is launching new initiatives to help get the vaccine to more Hoosiers.
Ten mobile clinics will be deployed across the state to counties where there are currently no open vaccine appointments, including one in the 2nd District! The mobile clinics will be open Thursday – Saturday from 8? a.m. to 8? p.m. for eligible Hoosiers, by appointment only.
LaPorte County Ivy Tech 3714 Franklin Street
The Homebound Hoosiers vaccination program, a state partnership with local fire and EMS departments, aims to administer vaccines directly to those who need special transportation or assistance to leave the home or have medical conditions that prohibits leaving the home. For more information and to register, contact your local Area Agency on Aging by calling 800-986-3505.
As always, it is a privilege to represent 2nd District Hoosiers in Congress.
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website and join me on social media:
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Sincerely,
￼
 
Jackie Walorski U.S. Congresswoman

Subject: House Democrats Advance Partisan, Progressive Priorities
Message:
￼ 
HOUSE DEMOCRATS ADVANCE PARTISAN, PROGRESSIVE PRIORITIES 

This week, House Democrats advanced not one, but two, partisan bills that are stuffed to the brim with progressive priorities. Here’s the breakdown:

H.R. 5, the so-called “Equality” Act 
This politically motivated bill violates the First Amendment rights of Americans to freely practice and exercise ones’ religion. I opposed this legislation that:
	•	Forces schools (both public and private), churches, hospitals, businesses, and other institutions to recognize an individual’s “chosen gender” instead of their “biological sex” 
	•	Allows biological males who identify as female to compete in women’s sports competitions and use female public facilities, such as locker rooms 
	•	Forces employers to cover abortions and medical professionals to conduct or assist in performing abortions and gender transition procedures 
	•	Lays the groundwork for taxpayer-funded abortions 
￼
Congressman Allen speaks on the House floor in opposition to H.R. 1319

H.R. 1319, Pelosi’s Payoff to Progressives Act
Speaker Nancy Pelosi and House Democrats passed their $1.9 trillion stimulus bill out of the House. It will now go to the Senate under a “budget reconciliation” process, which means it only needs a simple majority to pass in the Senate. This is not a relief bill -- only 9% of this $1.9 trillion goes toward pandemic-related expenses. It’s riddled with progressive priorities that are unrelated to the pandemic, including:
	•	A $15 federal minimum wage requirement that will destroy 1.4 million jobs 
	•	$350 billion in blue state bailouts while leaving behind states like Georgia 
	•	Funding for a Silicon Valley underground tunnel 
Throughout this whole process, my Democrat colleagues have rejected commonsense amendments prioritizing reopening our schools – despite the CDC stating that schools can safely reopen with proper precautions. I offered an amendment that would require schools to at least offer parents the option of sending their children for in-person instruction in order to be eligible for additional stimulus funds, but Democrats blocked it.

This isn’t “COVID relief,” this package is clearly just a payoff to progressive priorities.

￼

Introducing Legislation to Encourage School Reopenings

This week I reintroduced the Educational Flexibility for Families Act. This legislation is similar to the amendment I introduced to Democrats’ budget scheme and would require K-12 schools to provide an option for students to safely attend in-person classes during the 2021 and 2022 school years in order to be eligible for additional federal assistance.

￼
Congressman Allen reintroduces the Educational Flexibility for Families Act

Earlier this month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) issued additional school reopening guidance and the science is clear: Schools can safely reopen with proper precautions in place. Too many students throughout the nation have not even seen the inside of a classroom in a year and families should have the option to return their children to in-person learning. My bill prioritizes students and parents throughout the nation who are eager to return to school, not teachers’ unions who are forcing them to remain closed until their radical demands completely unrelated to the pandemic are met.

Meeting with Georgia Wing of Civil Air Patrol

￼

I’m incredibly grateful for the men and women who serve in the Georgia Wing. This week I had the opportunity to meet with members and receive an update on their activities over the past year.

House Agriculture Committee Hearing 

￼

This week, Democrats on the House Agriculture Committee held a climate hearing. Unfortunately, the extreme climate scare tactics being pushed by the left have created an epidemic of fear within our nation. But conservatives have climate solutions, including provisions in the 2018 Farm Bill that I was proud to help champion. Our farmers and ranchers are not the problem, they are the original stewards of the land and are working toward climate solutions every day. I will continue to listen to our agriculture leaders on this important topic.

COVID-19 Vaccine Update

Governor Brian Kemp announced this week that starting March 8th, Pre-K-12 educators and staff, adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities and their caregivers, and parents of children with complex medical conditions will be eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. This is great news as we continue to ramp up efforts to ensure that every Georgian who wants a vaccine is able to get one.

ICYMI: I held a telephone town hall to answer questions from GA-12 constituents

￼
￼
￼

I held a telephone town hall Tuesday night to update residents of #GA12 about President Biden’s executive orders, COVID-19 relief, legislation to reopen schools, and more. For those who were unable to participate, here are some of the highlights.

You can sign up to participate in future telephone town halls here.

￼

No American should be forced to pay union dues as a condition of employment. Forced unionism goes against every aspect of our Constitution and the beliefs of our Founding Fathers. 

That is why I am a proud original cosponsor of H.R. 1275, the National Right to Work Act. This legislation repeals the provision in federal law that allows unions to take dues from an employee’s paycheck.

As always, my office is here to help. You can email me ⇒ HERE, contact any of our offices or join the conversation on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram. 


Sincerely,

￼
 

Rick Allen
Member of Congress

Subject: PASSED: The American Rescue Plan
Message:
￼
Dear Friend,
 
When I voted in December for the most recent COVID-19 relief package, I promised you that it was a down payment and that I would immediately begin work on another round of relief that actually meets the needs of the American people.
 
Last night, I voted to keep that promise when the House passed President Biden’s American Rescue Plan. This historic legislation will deliver for working families across the Third District and set our nation on course to defeat the virus, get our kids safely back into the classroom, and rebuild our economy.
 
Specifically, the American Rescue Plan provides:
	•	Survival Checks: Fulfills President Biden’s promise to provide $2,000 in direct assistance to households by providing $1,400 checks per person, following the $600 down payment passed in December;
	•	Extended Unemployment: Extends access to unemployment benefits beyond the March 14th expiration date for workers laid off as a result of the pandemic and increases the critical monthly supplemental benefit to $400;
	•	Food and Housing Assistance: Makes bold investments in food assistance and child nutrition programs, including increasing the maximum SNAP benefit through September, and provides more than $40 billion for housing programs to help people afford their rent, mortgage, and utility payments;
	•	Direct Assistance to Vulnerable Families: Establishes a Pandemic Emergency Fund to allocate funding directly to states like ours to provide emergency assistance to low-income families with children;
	•	Resources for National Vaccination Plan: Provides more than $20 billion to establish a National COVID-19 Vaccination Program and improve the administration and distribution of vaccines, including allocating funds for FEMA vaccination sites across the country and strengthening the CDC’s ability to promote, distribute, monitor, and track COVID-19 vaccines;
	•	Funding Necessary to Reopen Schools: Allocates nearly $130 billion, which will be made available to states and school districts so they can work with public health experts to ensure the safe return of students and educators. This provision of the bill will deliver an estimated $1.9 billion to Massachusetts K-12 schools and another $13.6 million for Head Start programs;
	•	Support for Small Businesses and Nonprofits: Increases Paycheck Protection Program funding and expands eligibility to ensure it reaches nonprofits of all sizes and types while also creating a $25 billion Restaurant Revitalization Fund to offer assistance to restaurants and bars with 20 or fewer locations that have been hit hard by the pandemic;
	•	And MUCH MORE.
This legislation now moves to the Senate, where it should be taken up without delay so we can get it to President Biden’s desk as soon as possible. Rest assured that I will keep you updated regarding developments on the American Rescue Plan.
 
If I or anyone our team can be of any assistance in the meantime, please don’t hesitate to reach out via phone at 978-459-0101 or email at Rep.LoriTrahan@mail.house.gov.
 
Warm regards,

￼
  
Lori Trahan
Member of Congress
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
 
P.S. Due to the ongoing public health crisis, my offices will continue to be physically closed. However, my staff and I are teleworking full time and can be reached via phone at 978-459-0101 or by email at Rep.LoriTrahan@mail.house.gov.

Subject: Floor Wrap-Up: $1.9 Trillion COVID Bill, "Equality" Act, and Public Lands Package
Message:
Hello from Washington, DC.


This was a busy week in Washington, but unfortunately, Speaker Pelosi had us voting on more of her liberal messaging bills that will hurt rural Coloradans, jeopardize the work of religious organizations, and saddle our children and grandchildren with more debt. 

I spoke with Charles Payne on Fox Business about Speaker Pelosi's 'Pork-Filled' COVID bill, watch the full interview below:
 

Here are just a few of the most ridiculous pieces of pork Pelosi shoved into the American Recovery Act: 
 
	•	A $15 federal minimum wage mandate that will eliminate 1.4 million jobs
	•	$350 billion bailout for blue states
	•	$129 billion for public schools whether or not they have reopened
	•	$1 billion for 'racial justice' for farmers
	•	$112 million for a California rail project in Silicon Valley
	•	$200 million for museums and libraries
	•	$750 million for 'global health'
	•	$750 million for Native American housing
	•	$1.5 million to Senator Schumer’s home state for a pet project
 
And that’s just the tip of the iceberg. This bill will drastically increase our national debt by nearly $2 trillion. Not to mention, it also cuts $36 million from Medicare. 
 
Do you want to know the craziest part? 
 
We still have $1 trillion—yes, that's trillion with a "T"—left in unspent funds from previous COVID legislation. That’s why I voted against the Democrats' pork-filled COVID bill.


I joined my fellow Colorado Republicans in voting “NO” on the Democrats’ Federal Land Grab package: 
 

Did you know the federal government already owns 35.9% of Colorado?

The federal land grab package, HR 803, only gives more power to bureaucrats in Washington to enforce onerous restrictions and kill energy jobs. This package includes the text of several pieces of legislation including Rep. Diana DeGette (D-Colo.)’s Colorado Wilderness Act of 2021 and Rep. Joe Neguse (D-Colo.)’s Colorado Outdoor Recreation and Economy Act. Combined, these bills will create restrictions on over one million acres of land, much of which will be new wilderness – the most restrictive federal land use classification. Click here to read my full statement. 

I voted against Speaker Pelosi’s 'Equality' Act:
 

On Thursday, the House voted on HR 5, the so-called 'Equality' Act. This bill guts religious protections and threatens constitutional freedoms with drastic changes to federal civil rights laws. Not only will this legislation force religious charities to violate their deeply held beliefs and shut down faith-based adoption agencies, but it also forces women and girls to compete against biological men and hurt their athletic and scholarship opportunities. 

Equality for some is equality for none. It goes without saying that we should never tolerate prejudice or intolerance for a group of individuals. HR 5 is a laundry list of bad policies with serious repercussions for women, people of faith, churches, and charitable organizations.  

The Equality Act is anything but — and that is why I voted against it.

If you have any questions or concerns about my voting record please reach out to my office to leave a comment. Your opinion is important to me as I work to effectively represent you in Washington.

God Bless,
 

Ken Buck
Member of Congress
  ‌   ‌   ‌   ‌ 

Rep. Buck | 2455 Rayburn House Office Building, Washington, DC 20515

Subject: A Plan to End the Pandemic
Message:
￼ 
  

Dear Neighbors,
Last night, the House passed the American Rescue Plan that struggling families desperately need to help stay afloat during this ongoing public health and economic crisis. This legislation implements a national plan to crush the COVID-19 pandemic. It provides the tools and resources we need to ramp up distribution and administration of lifesaving vaccines and testing to track and trace new hotspots before they become larger outbreaks.  
The bill expands access to quality, affordable health care coverage to millions of Americans who lack access to care in the midst of the pandemic. The American Rescue Plan also includes vital assistance to help families keep the lights on, the heat working, the water running, and to expand internet connectivity to help students and teachers without home internet access. It will also deliver critical aid to our state and local governments. Read more here
My Energy and Commerce Committee held a hearing this week with vaccine manufacturers to hear what steps each company is taking to rapidly expand vaccine production, what hurdles might stand in the way, and what additional help they need to increase supply. Widespread access to vaccines and ensuring reliable production lines are in place is essential to achieve herd immunity and end this pandemic. Read more here
I also held another hearing on disinformation and extremism that are a threat to our nation. It has been especially dangerous over the past year when media outlets downplayed the seriousness of the COVID-19 pandemic, peddled ineffective treatments, and mocked effective precautionary measures. We owe it to our constituents and our democracy to examine how and why disinformation is being aired on traditional media and social media. Read more here
A Food and Drug Administration (FDA) advisory panel approved Johnson & Johnson’s COVID-19 vaccine on Friday. Formal emergency use authorization from FDA is expected over the weekend. New Jersey should receive an initial shipment of roughly 70,000 Johnson & Johnson vaccine doses once the vaccine receives approval. 
Local COVID-19 Announcements
Religious services and celebrations can now operate at 50% capacity of the room in which they are held with no cap on the number of individuals permitted to attend.
Indoor and outdoor collegiate sports practices and competitions may now allow two parents or guardians per participating athlete as spectators.
Effective March 1st, sports and entertainment venues with a fixed-seating capacity of over 5,000 people may open for spectators – 10% capacity for indoor venues and 15% capacity for outdoor venues.
Coronavirus Resources
If you have questions about resources available to New Jerseyans during the coronavirus pandemic, click here to visit my website or call my offices directly:
Middlesex County: 732-249-8892
Monmouth County: 732-571-1140
Stay healthy,
￼
Congressman Pallone

Subject: Getting K-12 Schools Re-opened + Increasing the Minimum Wage
Message:
￼
￼    February 22 - February 26, 2021 
This week, Senator Romney and a group of colleagues unveiled the Higher Wages for American Workers Act—legislation to gradually raise the federal minimum wage to $10/hour and require employers to use E-Verify to ensure jobs go to legal workers. Unlike Democrats' plan to increase wages to $15/hour, the group's proposal protects small businesses and would not cost jobs. Discussions also continued this week about the next phase of COVID-19 relief. In an op-ed, Senator Romney urged the Administration to come to the table to negotiate a bipartisan package to provide need-based relief. He also pressed the Administration to follow the science, not teachers unions, in getting K-12 schools open. Senator Romney provided these updates, and more, when he reported to the Utah legislature this week. Keep scrolling for a brief recap of the week:  
￼
￼
 
￼
  It’s been more than a decade since the federal minimum wage has been increased, leaving millions of Americans struggling to make ends meet. However, the Administration's proposal to increase the federal minimum wage to $15/hour would cost nearly 1.4 million jobs. Senator Romney teamed up with Senators Cotton (R-AR), Capito (R-WV), Collins (R-ME), and Portman (R-OH) to introduce the Higher Wages for American Workers Act, a proposal to raise wages for nearly 3.5 million workers without costing jobs. Additionally, the legislation would require employers to use E-Verify to ensure that businesses only hire legal workers—eliminating a key driver of illegal immigration. More information on the proposal can be found here.  
￼
 
￼
  Full story by Dennis Romboy here.    ￼    More than one-third of funding in the Administration's proposed COVID-19 package wouldn’t be spent until 2022 or later, undermining their claim that the massive price tag is justified for urgent pandemic-related needs. The next relief package should be targeted and bipartisan. Senator Romney wrote an op-ed for the Wall Street Journal urging the Administration to come to the table to negotiate the next COVID-19 package, saying Senate Republicans "stand ready to negotiate a plan that helps America recover, both physically and financially, from this dread disease. We are willing to compromise in an attempt to get the administration to come down from its ill-considered $1.9 trillion plan and instead provide need-based relief."  
￼
  Full opinion by Senator Romney here.   
￼
  The Administration’s COVID-19 proposal calls for $170 billion for education, yet has no realistic plan to re-open K-12 schools. During a Senate Health Committee hearing, Senator Romney pressed witnesses about the Administration's plan for re-opening schools given that data does not indicate COVID-19 spikes in open schools. The timetable for opening schools should be dictated by science, not teachers unions. Senator Romney also asked the Administration's witnesses about plans to curb the youth vaping epidemic.  During a separate Health Committee hearing, Senator Romney asked Xavier Becerra, the Administration's nominee for HHS Secretary, to explain his stance on abortion—particularly his previous votes in support of partial-birth abortions. "There are areas in which we can find common ground—but this isn’t one of them," Senator Romney said. "There is no common ground here."  
￼
 
￼
  Full story by Lee Davidson here.   
￼
  Senator Romney spoke with The New York Times' Andrew Ross Sorkin during a DealBook DC Policy Project event about his new legislation to raise the minimum wage, the latest discussions regarding COVID-19 relief, and other economic policy issues.  
￼
  
￼
  Confucius Institutes are a propaganda tool of the Chinese Communist Party. Senator Romney teamed up with Senators Rubio (R-FL), Grassley (R-IA), and Portman (R-OH) in sending a letter urging the Biden Administration to implement the proposed rule requiring U.S. academic institutions disclose their relationships with Confucius Institutes.  “We have significant concerns regarding the CCP’s nefarious actions and urge you to follow through on your commitments to advancing the interests of the American people as we collectively respond to the challenge that the CCP poses,” the senators wrote. “We believe it is critically important to better understand and reduce the CCP’s influence on the American people, including through the Hanban, its propaganda arm that runs Confucius Institutes through the PRC Ministry of Education. The proposed rule is a necessary step in that effort and would bring needed transparency to Confucius Institutes.”   
￼
  With two-thirds of Utah held as public land, the Secure Rural Schools program is an essential funding source for schools in Utah’s rural communities, which have also been hit especially hard by the health and economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. Senator Romney joined a large bipartisan group of colleagues to introduce legislation to reauthorize the SRS program through September 2022. It is necessary for Congress to reauthorize the SRS program, and Senator Romney will continue pushing to ensure that Congress sees it through. 
                               ￼     ￼     ￼     ￼     ￼ 
Unsubscribe 
￼￼

Subject: Moving forward, together
Message:
￼

February 27, 2021
 
Dear Friends,
 
This week has brought tremendous loss but also encouraging news in our effort to crush this pandemic and heal as a nation. As of Monday, just over a year after our nation’s first confirmed COVID-19-related death, we hit the heartbreaking milestone of more than 500,000 Americans lost to this virus. My heart breaks for the families, friends, and loved ones of the half-million Americans who have died as a result of COVID-19. This tragic loss of life is a solemn reminder that although we have made great strides towards crushing this virus, the pandemic is not over.
  
￼
I joined my colleagues and the nation in mourning the 500,000 Americans lost to COVID-19.
  
 
But here's the good news, this week, we also moved one step closer towards the authorization of a third safe, effective COVID-19 vaccine. The Johnson & Johnson vaccine could be a game-changer in our nation’s response to this pandemic — especially for rural and difficult to reach communities. The anticipation of a third coronavirus vaccine in the U.S. is a hopeful sign that we will be able to continue picking up the pace to get more vaccines into the arms of Americans quickly and efficiently.
 
While I am encouraged by the significant increase in the number of vaccines distributed to states under the Biden administration — an increase of nearly 70% in the past five weeks — we are not out of this crisis yet. Granite State doctors, nurses, and health care workers have gone above and beyond the call of duty and faced serious challenges during the COVID-19 surge of the past three months. The best way we can honor their service is to maintain the precautions that have allowed us to reduce our COVID-19 numbers and keep our communities safe. Social distancing and mask-wearing are our best defenses until the COVID-19 vaccine is widely distributed. 
 
There is light at the end of the tunnel and by working together, relying on science, and following the guidance of public health officials, we will have brighter days ahead.
  
 
Making Progress in Congress
 
  
￼
Friday morning I spoke on the House Floor to urge my colleagues to pass this critical relief legislation.
  
 
Hardworking Granite State families, small businesses, health care workers, and first responders are hurting because of the COVID-19 public health and economic crisis. Support cannot come soon enough, and I’m pleased the House took action and passed the American Rescue Plan Act, much-needed and forward-looking legislation that included two of my bills to bolster and quicken our nationwide vaccine rollout — the Immunization Infrastructure Modernization Act and the Coronavirus Vaccine and Therapeutic Development Act. 
 
The American Rescue Plan will provide critical resources for our NH communities to build back from this pandemic. The plan includes funding to re-open schools safely to get students back into classrooms, extend key relief to small businesses to keep employees on staff, and ensure our frontline workers and first responders have the supplies they need to safely do their jobs and protect our communities. Additionally, this bill will provide funding to bolster our nationwide vaccine rollout and ensure that the United States is able to mass-produce and administer COVID-19 vaccines to all Americans. 
 
There’s a lot of work to be done, and I’m committed to building back better so no one is left behind as we recover from this pandemic.
  
 
￼
 
I questioned vaccine manufacturers about our nation’s production capacity.
  
 
Although I have concerns about our nation’s COVID vaccine manufacturing capacity and increasing demand from our limited supply, this week’s Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee hearing and the testimony from leading vaccine producers — including Moderna and Pfizer who pledged to boost supply to the U.S. — made me proud of what our country has accomplished in our response to this pandemic, and hopeful for our ability to limit the threat of the new variants.
 
Safe, effective COVID-19 vaccines continue to be some of our best tools for crushing this pandemic — but, unless we are able to ramp up production and get shots into arms across the country efficiently and equitably, we will continue to be one step behind the virus. I will continue working in Congress to advance legislation to bolster our COVID-19 vaccine production and distribution, ensure that our supply meets the demands of this public health crisis, and expand access to life-saving vaccines and therapeutics so no one is left behind as we recover from this pandemic.
  
 
￼
 
I questioned experts on how we can mitigate climate change’s worst effects.
  
 
Climate change short-circuits New Hampshire’s maple-sugaring season, complicates the growing season for our farmers, and brings more invasive species to our forests. During Thursday’s Agriculture Committee hearing on the role of climate change in the agriculture and forestry industries, I questioned experts about how climate change threatens our economy and our livelihoods, and how we can mitigate its worst effects. 
 
I will continue working in Congress, through my role on the House Agriculture Committee and with the Biden-Harris administration to ensure our agriculture and forestry sectors are equipped with the resources, science, and federal support to address climate change and continue serving our communities for generations to come. Just this week, the EPA took important steps on dangerous PFAS and forever chemicals, which impact families throughout New Hampshire. I’ve worked with colleagues on both sides of the aisle in Congress to address PFAS, and I urge the administration to take immediate action to establish strict PFAS drinking water standards that will protect families and hold contaminators accountable.
  
 
￼
 
I voted in favor of the Equality Act to help ensure equal rights and justice for all.
  
 
No one should be denied housing, a job, education, or the opportunity to apply for federal funding because of who they are or who they love. And this week, the House passed the Equality Act to extend anti-discrimination protections to LGBTQ Americans and guarantee full federal civil rights protections. I’m proud to join my colleagues in supporting this legislation, and I will continue working to ensure equal rights and justice for all.
  
￼
This week, I helped reintroduce the END Child Exploitation Act.
  
 
Ensuring the safety and wellbeing of children in New Hampshire and across the country is one of my top priorities, and we must do more to safeguard them from exploitation online. 
 
This week, I was proud to help reintroduce the END Child Exploitation Act — commonsense, bipartisan legislation to help law enforcement and technology companies respond to child sexual abuse images, hold perpetrators accountable, and protect Granite State children and communities. I urge my colleagues to support this helpful bill to keep children across our country safe.
  
 
Hope on the Homefront
 
  
￼
The Treasury Department took swift action and listened to our calls to ensure flexibility in federal rental assistance funds.
  
 
There is no one-size-fits-all solution for those struggling to afford essential services or keep a roof over their head during this public health and economic crisis, and our federal COVID-19 response must reflect the diverse needs of our communities. I’m pleased the Treasury Department took swift action and listened to our calls to ensure flexibility in federal rental assistance funds.
 
Also this week, New Hampshire announced a new program to help with lapsed rental and utility payments that will become available in the next few weeks. I will continue working in Congress and with the Biden-Harris administration to provide crucial relief to those who need it most in New Hampshire and across the country. We must ensure Granite Staters have access to the support they need throughout the ongoing pandemic.
  
￼
I’m proud to advocate for NH restaurants in Congress.
  
 
Our Granite State restaurants and foodservice industry were hit hard by the COVID-19 public health and economic crisis. This week, by advancing the American Rescue Plan, we got one step closer to ensure these businesses have sufficient relief to weather this storm and continue serving our communities.
 
I'm proud to advocate for these New Hampshire businesses and their employees in Congress, and to support them at home!
  
￼
The 2021 Congressional Art Competition for New Hampshire’s Second District is now open!
  
 
Each spring, a nation-wide high school arts competition is sponsored by the U.S. House of Representatives. The annual Congressional Art Competition is an opportunity for high school students in New Hampshire’s Second District to showcase their artistic abilities!
 
I invite current high school students within New Hampshire’s Second Congressional District to participate in this year’s competition. The overall winner of our district's competition will be displayed for one year in the U.S. Capitol as well as the House Congressional Art Competition webpage. For safety reasons because of the COVID-19 pandemic, art submissions for the 2021 contest must be made virtually.
 
For information about the rules and how to enter, head to my website!
 
  
￼
We will get through this crisis, together.
  
 
The empathy, compassion, and sense of community that Granite Staters and New England neighbors have demonstrated during this crisis have been heartwarming. Whether it’s members of the New Hampshire National Guard putting their lives on hold to help others, or generous donations for those feeding the hungry, I know we will get through this stronger than ever.
  
 
News You Can Use
 
  
￼
The Biden administration extended resources for small businesses.
  
 
Our Main Street businesses are the backbone of our economy in New Hampshire, but the COVID-19 pandemic has had a heavy toll on small businesses. Starting this past Wednesday, the Biden administration has opened a window for businesses with fewer than 20 employees to have exclusive access to the Paycheck Protection Program for 14 days, from February 24 - March 10, 2021.
 
Learn more about eligibility and COVID-19 relief resources.
 
  
￼
Submit your best photos to my 2021 Winter Photo Contest!
  
 
If you live in New Hampshire’s 2nd District and enjoy photography, I invite you to enter my 2021 Winter Photo Contest! From now through Monday, March 1st at 11:59 PM, my office is accepting submissions of images and scenery to highlight the Granite State's natural beauty. Learn more about how to submit your photos on my website.
 
A program at the UpREACH Therapeutic Equestrian Center in Goffstown that is working to help ease tension for first responders and front-line workers by spending time with horses has been extended into April and possibly longer if sponsors step forward. The program offers free equestrian therapy sessions to help those on the frontlines during the COVID-19 crisis.
 
COVID-19 testing can be a helpful tool to identify active cases and stop the spread of the coronavirus, and advancing technology is making it easier than ever. A mobile COVID-19 testing lab is now offering its services to the public at the Mall of New Hampshire, specifically, those who need PCR results quickly, sometimes in just 30 minutes.
 
Sign-ups for Phase 1B of New Hampshire’s COVID-19 vaccination process are now open.
 
Phase 1B opens vaccine registration to:
—Those 65 years or older
—Those under 65 but medically vulnerable
—Residents or staff of residential facilities
—Correctional officers working in facilities 
 
Confirm your eligibility and register for your vaccination on www.vaccines.nh.gov/. If you need assistance, you can call 2-1-1 for help. 
 
As always, the CDC and the New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services are the best resources to turn to during the COVID-19 public health emergency. If you are sick, stay home and call your health care provider. If you live in NH and have questions about coronavirus, dial 2-1-1 or visit CDC.gov for more information.
 
To stay updated on my work in Congress and around the Granite State, as well as for important information and resources, like my page on Facebook and follow me on Twitter. 
 
As we continue working to heal from COVID-19, remember that hope and brighter days are on the way! We’re all in this together, and we will come out stronger on the other side. I hope you have a safe and fun weekend!
 
Sincerely, 
 
Annie

Subject: Biden Bailout Doesn't Add Up
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email 
￼
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 

February 27, 2021
 
HAPPENING IN THE HOUSE
This week, the House passed H.R. 5, the Equality Act, which would withhold federal funding from any college or university that does not allow biological men to compete in women's sports. Allowing transgender individuals to compete in women’s sports is unfair, unsafe, and completely undermines the intent of Title IX which was put in place to protect women and girls. As the father of three girls involved in wrestling, I want them to be able to compete on a level playing field. If our laws do not recognize the biological difference between men and women, female athletes will be the ones to suffer the consequences.
 
Check out my most recent "Mullin it Over" column where I explain the history of Title IX and outline how H.R. 5 seeks to undermine women's participation in school sports.
￼
 
BIDEN BAILOUT DOESN'T ADD UP
The Biden Bailout is exactly what it sounds like: a bill full of wasteful government spending, blue state bailouts, and Democratic wish list items that hinder our economic recovery from the pandemic. Of the $1.9 trillion, only 9 percent will actually go to COVID relief and 45 percent isn’t even going to be used this year. That is unacceptable and reckless. With $1 trillion from previously enacted relief bills still unspent, we should be focusing on getting that relief to those who need it most and getting our economy fully reopened. 
￼
 
This 1.9 trillion bailout includes: 
	•	$510 billion for Democrat-run states that chose to shut down
	•	$471 billion for liberal policies that destroy jobs 
	•	$422 billion for another round of direct government payments to individuals 
	•	$325 billion for non-COVID-19 Democratic wish list items 
	•	$160 billion for actually combatting COVID-19 
	•	$12 billion in foreign aid
	•	And a federal mandate forcing states to raise the minimum wage to $15 per hour
This should be simple. Any pandemic relief legislation must be temporary and directly tied to COVID-19. 
 
￼
 
"IN AMERICA WE'RE ABLE TO DEBATE, BUT WHAT WE SHOULDN'T DO IS HATE"
This week, House Energy and Commerce Committee Democrats attempted to bully private media companies into silence for their opposing views. This was yet another attempt by the Pelosi Democrats to eliminate any points of view that differ from their socialist narrative. Freedom of speech is a right and it must be protected. I was honored to participate in this hearing and point out the clear hypocrisy that exists within left-wing media. 
  
￼
  
Click here to watch the full segment of my Q&A.
 
This week I also appeared on Newsmax to discuss the spread of disinformation in left-wing media as well as the hypocrisy and danger that exists when Democrats attempt to violate the First Amendment and silence opposing media views. You can watch my full interview here: 
 
￼
 
WINTER WEATHER RECOVERY
As Oklahomans recover from last week's storm, please know that my team is here to help. We have updated our website to reflect the latest resources, including FEMA disaster reporting, mental health services, and the livestock indemnity program. Click here for more information on winter weather recovery services. 
 
￼

 
NATIONAL FFA WEEK
This week we celebrated FFA Week! For 90+ years, National FFA has been educating premier youth about the science, business, and technology of agriculture. Thank you Oklahoma FFA for providing the hands-on experiences that will help future leaders meet the agricultural challenges of tomorrow.
 
￼
 
GOLD STAR FAMILIES FELLOWSHIP
My team is seeking a Gold Star Family Member for a fellowship in our Claremore office. I am proud to partner with the House to provide employment opportunities for families whose loved ones have paid the ultimate sacrifice to protect our nation. The Gold Star Family Member Program was established by the House of Representatives to ensure that families of fallen service members have access to employment in addition to the care and services they need. I encourage all eligible to apply!
 
OK ON ZOOM 
I was glad to have the chance to talk with many Oklahomans this week to discuss important district issues. I wish we could have met in person! 
 
￼
  
I was glad to have the chance to meet with student government leaders from OU and OSU to discuss college affordability and food insecurity in Oklahoma. Thank you all for joining in!
 
￼
  
Thank you to the Oklahoma members of the American Alliance of Museums for taking the time to meet with me to discuss pandemic relief, museum and library grant programs, and incentivizing charitable giving.   
￼
  
I was honored to speak with Col. Roberts and Lt. Col. McCollum this week about Civil Air Patrol’s upcoming activities and future budget plans. It was wonderful to connect with you both!   
WHERE IN DISTRICT 2? 
Communities all across the Second Congressional District of Oklahoma are full of things that make them unique and I want to highlight some of them. Every week on my Facebook page, I will post an up-close photo of a landmark somewhere in the district with a clue to where it is. I encourage everyone to put their best guess in the comments. The correct answer will be right here, in my weekly e-newsletter.
 
￼
 
This landmark is Centennial Plaza at Northeastern State University in Tahlequah. Centennial Plaza was dedicated March 6, 2009 in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the founding of Northeastern. Congratulations to Ginger Ott Ziese for guessing this landmark correctly! 
 
￼
 
WEEKLY WRAP UP
 
￼
 
Again, the Equality Act is the perfect example of Pelosi Democrats giving in to the “woke” movement. This bill puts political correctness over protections for women in education and sports. Watch this week's wrap up on Facebook and YouTube. 
 
Stay in touch by visiting my Facebook and Twitter pages and as always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way.
 
Thank you,
￼
  
Markwayne Mullin
Member of Congress
 
Votes Taken the Week of February 21, 2021:

Subject: Rep. Grothman Newsletter- Air Americans
Message:
￼

 
Air Americans
 
Between 1950 and 1976, a group of approximately 1,000 U.S. citizens worked for Air America, which was portrayed as a privately-owned company carrying out flight operations during the Cold War. Now-declassified documents have revealed that Air America was wholly owned and controlled by the U.S. government – meaning these brave Americans were federal employees under the law at the time they worked. 
 
Due to the secretive nature of their work and a technicality within the government bureaucracy, however, these individuals are not officially recognized as former federal employees are not afforded federal retirement benefits.
 
On Wednesday, I introduced the Air America Act, which currently has 60 bipartisan cosponsors. My bill will correct this inequity suffered by the brave Americans who are former employees of Air America by ensuring they receive the federal retirement benefits and recognition they have earned. Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) introduced a companion version of this bill in the U.S. Senate, which is currently cosponsored by a bipartisan group of 27 Senators.
 
Congress has twice passed corrective legislation for other covert CIA-affiliated groups and it is not right to continue to ignore Air Americans. These patriots risked their lives, many of them giving their life, fighting communism in the same way members of the Air Force did. I am honored that so many of my colleagues on both sides of the aisle are joining me to support these heroes. Now is the time to properly recognize Air Americans for their service to our country.
  
 
Lt. Col. James "Maggie" Megellas
 
Let me briefly tell you the story of Fond du Lac native James "Maggie" Megellas.
 
On January 28, 1945, First Lieutenant Megellas led his platoon in a successful attack on an enemy battalion near Herresbach, Belgium, despite being outnumbered ten-to-one. After the attack, he advanced his platoon towards the town when a German Mark V Panther tank pinned them down. Megellas weathered enemy fire to attack and destroy the tank himself with just two grenades and his submachine gun. He then led his platoon to secure Herresbach for advancing Allied forces. Under Megellas’ command, his platoon did not suffer a single casualty that day. Megellas would go on to become the most-decorated soldier from the 82nd Airborne Division, receiving the Distinguished Service Cross and the Silver Star for his actions during the Battle of the Bulge. Sadly, Maggie passed away last year at his home in Colleyville, TX at the age of 103.
 
I am proud to, once again, introduce a legislation that would authorize the President to award Lt. Col. Megellas the Medal of Honor, America's highest military honor, for his heroic efforts to go above and beyond the normal call of duty. My bipartisan bill is cosponsored by every member of Wisconsin's House delegation, Congressman Ron Kind (D-WI-03), Congresswoman Gwen Moore (D-WI-04), Congressman Mark Pocan (D-WI-02), Congressman Mike Gallagher (R-WI-08), Congressman Bryan Steil (R-WI-01), Congressman Tom Tiffany (R-WI-07), Congressman Scott Fitzgerald (R-WI-05), as well as Congresswoman Beth Van Duyne (R-TX), who represents Colleyville, TX. Senator Ron Johnson introduced a companion bill in the U.S. Senate that has bipartisan support from Senator Tammy Baldwin (D-WI) and Senator John Cornyn (R-TX).
 
Maggie deserves to be recognized with the Medal of Honor. His story is amazing and an example of the unbreakable American spirit. I have been sharing Maggie's story with my other Congressional colleagues and hope that one day soon, we will pass this bill and give Lt. Col. James "Maggie" Megellas the Medal of Honor he so deserves.
  
 
Weekly Roundup
 
People residing in assisted living communities and employees have had to be particularly careful during COVID-19. I spoke with the Wisconsin Assisted Living Association about how we can continue to keep these folks safe and what it will take to safely return to normal.
  
￼
  
￼
  
Click the image to read the full letter
  
On Monday, February 22, we observed George Washington’s birthday. We must remember that the Constitution exists to protect the rights of American citizens from government overreach.
  
￼
  
I visited Attwill Medical Solutions in Lodi and learned about how they are using their pharmaceutical technology to make crucial components of COVID-19 testing kits.
  
￼
￼
  
I spoke with the Fox Cities Chamber of Commerce and its members about what to expect from Congress in the near future as well as my work to protect the jobs of individuals with disabilities.
  
￼
  
￼
  
Click the image to read the full letter
  
COVID-19 cases in Wisconsin are falling, which is great news. This week, I spoke with the Wisconsin Medical Society about how we can continue the downward trend and get back to normal.
  
￼
  
￼
  
Click the image to read the full letter
  
I met with the Wisconsin Alliance for Retired Americans to discuss how I am working to ensure Congress is protecting seniors by preserving programs like Social Security and Medicare.
  
￼
  
 
Contact Me
 
As your Congressman, I’m here to serve you. If you have any questions please don’t hesitate to reach out to my offices in Fond du Lac and Washington. If you enjoyed this newsletter be sure to forward it to your family and friends so they can stay informed on what I’m doing in Washington and the Sixth District. 
 
You can also stay up-to-the-minute by following me on Facebook (Congressman Glenn Grothman), Twitter (@RepGrothman) and Instagram (@RepGlennGrothman).
  
Sincerely,
￼
  
Glenn Grothman
Member of Congress

Subject: The Democrats' "COVID Stimulus" is Neither
Message:
￼
￼

 
The Democrats' "COVID Stimulus" is Neither
 
 
Americans are desperate for the COVID-19 vaccine. Our main street businesses are hurting. Millions of Americans are still out of work. Schools remain closed across the nation. 
 
These are the real problems we’re facing. And yet, the Democrats' partisan proposal ignores them all. 
 
￼
WATCH: Congressman Brady speaks on the floor against the Democrat’s partisan payoff bill.
 
In fact, only 9% of the $1.9 trillion in this bill is spent on combating the virus. The truth is, the Democrats' "COVID stimulus" is neither. 
 
Instead of creating jobs, the Democrats are dishing out money to special interest groups, including: 
	•	$350 billion bailout for blue states 
	•	$12 billion for foreign aid
	•	$100M for a rail project to Silicon Valley 
	•	$135 million for the National Endowment for the Humanities 
	•	$50M for environmental justice grants 
	•	$1.5M for a bridge connecting Canada to NY 
	•	And more….
It doesn’t have to be this way. For the last five COVID-19 emergency aid bills Republicans and Democrats worked together, and were able to deliver the largest recovery package in American history – over $3.5 trillion. But this time, by refusing to work together, President Joe Biden and Democrats in Congress are punishing the American people. 
 
￼
 
Instead of this political payoff, let’s find common ground on what’s truly urgent: crushing the virus, rebuilding this economy, saving Main Street businesses and getting people back to work.

Subject: Dingell Update: February 27, 2021
Message:
￼ 
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
Helping
You 
Email
Debbie 
Invite Debbie
To A Meeting 
News
And Updates 
On The
Issues 
Meet
Debbie 
February 27, 2021
 Thought of the day: “The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.” ― Mahatma Gandhi  
￼
Last night, the U.S. House of Representatives voted to pass the American Rescue Plan, sending the relief package over to the U.S. Senate for final consideration. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said the Senate will pass the relief package by March 14, before unemployment assistance for over 18 million Americans is due to expire. 
The American Rescue Plan will deliver immediate relief to millions of Americans and small businesses, including:
	•	$1,400 survival checks for Americans
	•	Funding to SAFELY reopen schools and keep them open
	•	Takes action to speed up COVD-19 vaccinations
	•	Increases COVID-19 testing, contact tracing, and mitigation
	•	Extends and increases unemployment assistance
	•	Expands health care access and lowers costs
	•	Increases housing and nutrition assistance
	•	Expands access to affordable childcare
	•	Provides support for frontline workers
And much more focused on helping us crush COVID and build back our economy.  

Coronavirus Update

On Friday, Michigan reported 1,073 new cases of COVID-19 and 1 new death, bringing the state’s total cases to 586,425 and deaths to 15,454. Our efforts to defeat this virus are working, but we can’t become complacent. We can’t relax now that Michigan’s numbers are continuing to trend in hopeful directions. Now we must really commit to following CDC guidelines, so we don’t erase the progress we’ve made, especially with more contagious variants of COVID spreading in our state. We’ve got to keep wearing our masks (two is better than one, according to the CDC), keeping our physical distance, and washing our hands.  
On Friday, Michigan reported 2,621,225 COVID vaccines have been distributed and, of that, 2,131,955 vaccines have been administered. We continue to have many issues with the rollout of the vaccine—from seniors unsure of how to make an appointment, to shortages in vaccines causing health systems to cancel appointments. We’ve got to better communicate how eligible people can get vaccination appointments and really work to address vaccine shortages.
Yesterday, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Advisory Board voted unanimously to approve Johnson & Johnson’s single-dose COVID-19 vaccine, paving the way for the US’s third COVID, and first single-dose, vaccine. The FDA will now work quickly to authorize the vaccine for emergency use, which may come as soon as today. The addition of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine will help us continue to stomp down case numbers and prevent serious illness due to the virus, once authorized.
COVID-19 Vaccine Information
Michigan is busy at work distributing and administering COVID vaccines. More information can be found by following the links below.
Washtenaw County Vaccine Information
Wayne County Vaccine Information
Local pharmacies like Meijer and Rite Aid have launched webpages to provide the most up-to-date information on their vaccination plans, including options for eligible Michiganders to pre-register and schedule appointments for COVID vaccines.
Michigan continues to prioritize vaccines for those 65 and older, front-line workers, some state and federal workers, jail and prison staff, Pre-K through 12th-grade teachers, and childcare providers.
To pre-register with a Meijer Pharmacy, visit their online pre-registration form or text “COVID” to 75049 or call your local Meijer Pharmacy. Visit Meijer Pharmacy’s COVID vaccination webpage for more information.
To check your eligibility and schedule a COVID vaccine appointment with Rite Aid, visit their COVID-19 Vaccine Scheduler.
MI-12 COVID Testing Sites
The State of Michigan has launched a statewide COVID testing site locator. This tool will help Michiganders search for cost-free testing sites near them. If you or someone you know may have been exposed to COVID, it is important you get tested.  
￼
Additional COVID testing sites are announced regularly and this list may not be exhaustive.
ACCESS Community Health and Research Center (6450 Maple Street, Dearborn) offers free COVID testing. Call 313-216-2230 for more information on testing at ACCESS.  The 2|42 Community Church in Ann Arbor (648 S. Wagner Road, Ann Arbor) is offering contactless drive-thru only saliva testing. Those needing to be tested can view testing hours and pre-register here: lynxdx.health/register
What I'm Reading
What’s in the House’s $1.9 trillion coronavirus plan – Washington Post
As USPS delays persist, bills, paychecks and medications are getting stuck in the mail – Washington Post 

Team Dingell is here seven days a week and wants to listen and help. It isn’t as smooth as we want on some issues, but we will never stop fighting for you. Call our office at 313-278-2936 or contact us through our webpage.

Be safe, Michigan! Wear your mask, keep your physical distance, and wash those hands!
New information becomes available every day. Below is a list of resources and information that can be helpful during this time. Please share this information with your family, friends, and colleagues. Remember, stay home, stay safe, save lives.
Coronavirus information

Subject: A Rescue Plan for America
Message:
￼
Services  |   Contact  |   Events 
SUBSCRIBE 

Dear Friends,  
As the pandemic continues to take lives and hurt Coloradans' livelihoods, providing robust economic relief is our number one priority. This week, we passed the American Rescue Plan through the House, a comprehensive COVID-19 relief plan to crush the virus, return children safely to the classroom, get vaccines to the people, put dollars into families’ pockets and put people back to work. 
 
The plan will mount a national vaccination program that includes setting up community vaccination sites nationwide. It will deliver immediate relief to working families bearing the brunt of the crisis through $1400 checks for eligible Americans, direct housing, and nutrition assistance and it will provide crucial support for the hardest-hit small businesses through EIDL grants, expanded Payroll Protection Program eligibility, and more. 
 
When America is hurting, we cannot turn our backs. This plan will address both the public health and economic needs produced by this crisis and ensure we are answering the many devastating impacts our communities have witnessed over the last year—feeding hungry kids and families, supporting workers who have been laid off and businesses who are struggling and providing the necessary infrastructure to get Americans vaccinated and our economy reopened as quickly as is safe.
 
This bill now heads to the Senate for approval, and we'll be in touch in the coming weeks with more information on how to access aspects of this plan. 
 
WHAT ELSE HAVE WE BEEN WORKING ON?
	•	On Monday, March 1st. I will be hosting a Telephone Townhall at 6:30pm MT to give updates on COVID relief, wildfire recovery, our efforts to preserve Colorado public lands, and more! You can sign up and live stream the event at neguse.house.gov/live.   
	•	I wrote FEMA to request that surveillance testing be included as a reimbursable expense to support teachers and students and assist in Colorado's efforts to reopen our economy.   
	•	We passed the Equality Act, critial legislation that will ensure LGBTQ+ individuals are afforded the same protections against discrimination as every other American. The legislation would amend the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and other existing laws to expand these rights.   
	•	We introduced the Fairness in Social Security Act, which was inspired by a Silverthorne constituent, to address a faulty IRS rule to ensure individuals who rely on social security are not left owing huge tax bills. 
As always we are so grateful for your input and feedback. Please contact my office if you have ideas on how to improve the lives of Coloradans and Americans, as well as if you need any help with a federal agency.
 
Stay safe and healthy as we welcome our state’s snowiest month next week!
 
Sincerely,
￼

Subject: This Week with Claudia #NY22
Message:
Contact Me
 

A message from 
Congresswoman Tenney:

Thank you for signing up for my weekly e-newsletter. I'm looking forward to keeping you updated on my work in Congress and throughout the 22nd District. It's a privilege to represent you in Congress, where my priority will always be to advance compassionate policies that restore opportunity and prosperity for Upstate families, small businesses and seniors. If my office can ever be of service to you, please do not hesitate to contact us.
 
 
 
 
 
Speaker Pelosi’s spending bill was focused more on partisan priorities than our Nation’s COVID recovery. Read about why I voted "No."

The unprecedented COVID-19 crisis demands a robust, targeted response from the federal government. But only 9% of the funding in Speaker Pelosi's proposed $1.9 trillion COVID relief bill was actually for COVID relief. The rest was a grab bag of nearly $1 trillion in pork and other provisions that were totally unrelated to COVID - things like $100 million for a train project in Silicon Valley. Nancy Pelosi used this bill as cover to push a partisan agenda rather than build on areas of bipartisan consensus to deliver real relief to American families, which is why I voted against it. I encourage you to read my detailed explanation here. My priority in Congress is unchanged: to deliver targeted relief to the constituents I represent. I urge my Democratic colleagues to put partisan wish lists on hold and focus on getting our nation through this unprecedented challenge. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Rep. Tenney named to Small Business and Foreign Affairs Committees, attends first Committee hearings this week

Last week I was named to the House Small Business Committee and the Foreign Affairs Committee. I'm proud to have been named to these important committees, and will use my positions to continue fighting for the 22nd Congressional District. My priorities include delivering relief to small businesses, countering China's theft of American intellectual property, protecting jobs, and bringing back American manufacturing. Read more about my priorities. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Rep. Tenney shares testimony from NY22 small businesses at Committee hearing

Earlier this week I attended my first Small Business Committee meeting, which was focused on a proposal by House Democrats to increase the minimum wage. While the proposal may be well-intentioned, I highlighted during the hearing how a minimum wage hike would hurt small businesses as well as lesser-skilled workers throughout New York. It would also cost the economy 1.4 million jobs. I shared testimony from A&P Master Images, a small business in Utica, New York. Owners Howard and Amanda Potter stated a wage hike could be catastrophic for their small manufacturing company. Watch my opening remarks here. 
 
 

Foreign Affairs Committee Adopts Two Bills on Burma Co-Sponsored by Rep. Tenney

Utica, New York is home to more than 4,000 Burmese refugees, many who still have family in Burma. Earlier this month, Burma's military overthrew the civilian-led government, leading to tragic violence across the country. I recently met with a group of Burmese refugees from Utica to learn more about their concerns and underscore my commitment to addressing this issue. Earlier this month I wrote a letter to Secretary of State Tony Blinken calling on the Biden Administration to sanction those responsible for the coup. This week the House Foreign Affairs Committee passed two bills I supported to condemn the coup and hold those responsible for it accountable. Read my full statement here. 
 
 

House Democrats refuse to consider Rep. Tenney's "Cuomo Accountability Amendment" to increase transparency

I introduced a commonsense amendment to require Governor Cuomo and every Governor across the country to comply with requests for information from federal agencies regarding COVID-19 data. House Republican Whip Steve Scalise (LA) and New York Representatives Elise Stefanik, Andrew Garbarino, and Lee Zeldin co-sponsored this amendment. House Democrats unfortunately prevented this amendment from even being considered for a vote. 
 

Rep. Tenney demands Governor Cuomo's resignation after latest allegations of sexual harassment by former aide

The allegations of sexual harassment made against Governor Cuomo are deeply disturbing and expose the climate of fear, bullying, and abuse that Governor Cuomo has used to silence critics and escape accountability. New Yorkers have lost faith in Governor Cuomo and this week I renewed my repeated calls for him to resign. If he refuses, Governor Cuomo must be impeached by the New York State Legislature. His crimes must be fully investigated to shed light on the full extent of his wrongdoing. Read my full statement. 
 

 

NY22 Resident Jessie Clemente turns 103

This week it was such a privilege to wish Utica, New York resident Jessie Clemente a Happy Birthday from the House Floor of Congress. Jessie turned 103 this week and celebrated the momentous occasion with her family. Happy Birthday, Jessie!
 

Rep. Tenney visits Rome Lab for an update on its important work
 
 
 
 
Rome Lab is an engine of growth and prosperity for our community and employs more than 1,000. This week, I visited the Lab to meet with its leadership. I received an update on its research and reiterated my strong support for the Lab and its workforce. The Lab is on the cutting-edge of technological advancements in a range of fields vitally important to our national security. Every dollar of funding Rome Lab receives is an investment in our country's security and our region's future. 
 

Contact my offices for help with a federal agency

One of the most important responsibilities I have as your representative in Congress is to ensure you get the help you need when dealing with a federal agency. If you are experiencing any difficulties or have questions regarding eligibility for COVID-related benefits, I encourage you to contact any one of my three offices, which are open for business and ready to serve you.
 
 

Have news or updates to share? Email me!

If you have updates regarding events in the community or other news to share from across New York's 22nd Congressional District, please visit the "Contact Me" page on my website to share it with me. My team will try to include as many of your updates from around #NY22 as we can each week.
 
  ‌   ‌ 
 

Rep. Tenney | 1410 Longworth House Office Building, Washington, DC 20515 
Unsubscribe 
Update Profile | Customer Contact Data Notice 
Sent by reptenney@mail8.housecommunications.gov

Subject: The American Rescue Plan
Message:
￼

 Dear Friend,  
Today, I voted to pass the American Rescue Plan, a comprehensive COVID-19 relief package that will help control the virus, ramp up the distribution of vaccines in every community, safely reopen schools, put money into Marylanders' pockets, support small businesses and provide vital economic aid to state and local governments across our state so that Maryland communities can maintain vital services and keep residents safe.  
This robust new round of COVID-19 relief will help us get to the other side of the ongoing public health crisis.  
Key provisions of the American Rescue Plan include:  
	•	Accelerating vaccine distribution for all Americans, expanding testing capacity, improving contact tracing, enhancing treatment and controlling the virus. This includes creating a national vaccination program to speed up the equitable distribution of vaccines, partnering with state and local governments to set up community vaccination centers, funding COVID-19 testing and contract tracing programs, increasing stockpiles of personal protective equipment and other medical supplies, investing in high-quality treatments and addressing health care disparities.  
	•	Helping schools reopen safely. This includes funding for K-12 schools and higher education institutions to help mitigate costs related to the pandemic and keep students, teachers and school workers safe.  
	•	Sending direct payments to American families. This includes $1,400 for individuals, $2,800 for couples, and an additional $1,400 for every child or dependent. Direct payments will phase out for individuals earning more than $75,000 and for couples earning more than $150,000.  
	•	Supporting state and local governments. This includes dedicated funding for state, local, tribal and territorial governments to help pay for COVID-19 emergency costs, compensate first responders, public health personnel, transit workers, teachers and other essential frontline workers and deliver critical community services for the American people.  
	•	Extending and expanding unemployment benefits. This includes increasing federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation to $400 per week, up from $300 per week, and continuing jobless benefits through August 2021.  
	•	Extending another lifeline to small businesses. This includes increasing resources for small businesses through the Paycheck Protection Program and the Economic Injury Disaster Loan program, and helping small businesses stay open, keep employees on the payroll and continue playing a vital role in American communities.  
	•	Strengthening and expanding federal nutrition programs to address the current hunger crisis. This includes extending increased monthly Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits through September 2021 and boosting support for the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC).  
	•	Delivering housing and rental assistance. This includes extending the eviction and foreclosure moratoriums through September 2021 and providing rental assistance for struggling families across the country.  
	•	Assisting child care providers and helping parents get back to work. This includes grant funding for child care providers to cover payroll, rent and personal protective equipment costs, among other needs. It also helps provide child care for low-income families.  
	•	Strengthening America's health care system. This includes expanding access to affordable health insurance - especially for unemployed and low-income Americans - through COBRA, the Affordable Care Act marketplaces and Medicaid. It also includes robust funding for Community Health Centers, tribal health programs and state, local and territorial health departments to help expand the delivery of health care to every community across the country.  
	•	Aiding America's veterans. This includes critical resources to help the VA meet the health and economic needs of our nation's veterans, including funds to waive copays for treatment and to reduce the backlog of veterans' claims and appeals caused by the pandemic.  
	•	Providing emergency transportation relief. This includes targeted funding for public transportation systems, transit agencies and airports, along with rail funding for Amtrak and support for the aviation manufacturing and airline workforce.  
During this tremendously challenging time, I will continue to work closely with my colleagues in Congress to build a stronger and more equitable country as we recover from this tragic pandemic.
As always, my office is available to help you and your families access important federal services and benefits, like Social Security and Medicare. If you need assistance, please send me an email or call (410) 832-8890 during normal business hours.  
Sincerely,  ￼ John P. Sarbanes Maryland's Third Congressional District
 
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: Vermonters: I'm Fighting for You
Message:
￼
What I'm Fighting for in Washington D.C.
A Livable Wage
  
The American people need a raise NOW. Which is why last month I once again introduced legislation to raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. This is not a radical idea. 60 percent of the American people support raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour. 
￼
  
I fought very hard to get this much needed raise for millions of Americans workers — including around 66,000 right here in Vermont — into the budget reconciliation process. Unfortunately, the Senate Parliamentarian ruled on Thursday night that raising the minimum wage does not have a substantial impact on the federal budget, thus it does not comply with the Byrd Rule and cannot be passed through the reconciliation process. I strongly disagree with this decision, but the fight continues.  
I will be working with my colleagues in the Senate to move forward with an amendment to take deductions away from large, profitable corporations that don’t pay workers at least $15 an hour and to provide small businesses with the incentives they need to raise wages. Taxpayers should not be subsidizing the starvation wages of profitable corporations. On Thursday I held a Budget Committee hearing on this very issue — you can watch the hearing here. 
Hear Vermonters speak of their support for a $15 minimum wage by clicking the video above — you can also find it here. 
The time for talk is over. We must raise the minimum wage to a livable wage and ensure our working class can live with dignity.  
 
$2,000 Federal Stimulus Checks
  
It's very simple: we must keep our promise to the American people and provide $2,000 direct payments in the next federal relief package.  
￼
  
Throughout this health and economic crisis, I’ve heard from thousands of Vermonters who have been unable to pay their rent, mortgage, electric bill or put food on the table. While the federal payments have not been nearly enough, they have provided real help to families in need, which is why I strongly oppose lowering the income eligibility for the next round of direct payments. It would be absurd to deny this relief to millions of Americans who relied on the first two checks to make ends meet. Know that as the Chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, I am working hard to provide the bold emergency relief that working families in Vermont and all across our country need right now. And that means: $2,000 stimulus payments — no decrease to the income eligibility levels.
Watch the video above on my opposition to the income cap proposal — you can also find it here. Read an article on the proposal here. 
 
Reducing Prescription Drug Prices
  
The American people pay, by far, the highest prices in the world for the prescription medications they need. A Congressional Budget Office report released last week found that the Medicare Part D program pays far more than any other federal health program for prescription drugs.
￼
  
On average Medicare pays nearly three times more than Medicaid and about twice as much as the VA for the exact same brand-name drugs. That is outrageous and unacceptable. It’s long past time that Congress take on the greed of the pharmaceutical industry. Congress must require the Secretary of Health and Human Services to negotiate directly with pharmaceutical companies. In doing so, the 40 million Americans who get their prescription drug coverage from Medicare Part D would see substantially reduced drug prices.
Read my full response on the report’s release here and find the CBO report here. Learn about my legislation to lower drug prices here. 
 
Reliable Mail Delivery
  
I joined 33 of my Senate colleagues in demanding answers from Postmaster General Louis DeJoy.  
￼
In the past few months I’ve heard from over 4,000 Vermonters about the harm caused by delayed mail. Many, especially our neighbors in rural areas, depend on the timely delivery of the mail for prescription medications, bill payments, packages, and other essential needs. I know our US Postal employees in Vermont are doing their very best, but need support from USPS leadership. At a time when people are more isolated than ever, we must ensure the U.S. Postal Service is taking every step it can to fulfill its mission of reliable mail delivery. Read the full letter we sent to Postmaster General DeJoy here. 
DeJoy testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Reform on Wednesday on mail delays, operations and plans for the USPS — you can watch the hearing here. 
 
The Vermont Lake Monsters
  
I fought for Vermont to have its own professional baseball team over 30 years ago. As mayor of Burlington I created a task force to attract a double A team, and worked to develop an agreement with the University of Vermont to use Centennial field for baseball games. Since 1983, minor league teams based in Burlington have contributed significantly to our economy.
The decision to eliminate 39 Minor League teams, including the Vermont Lake Monsters will hurt the players, fans, workers, and communities throughout our country. I will do everything I can to encourage Major League Baseball to reverse this disastrous decision.  Find my full statement here, as well as articles on the MLB decision here and here. 
￼
  
 
  
To my fellow Vermonters: I hear you and I am fighting for you. Right now, as we go through the federal budget process and negotiate the next major COVID relief package, we have a real opportunity to pass legislation that will help working families in Vermont and all across our country. Know I am urging my colleagues to do their jobs and to listen to the needs of the American people. I will continue to fight for a strong federal response that matches the scale of this unprecedented health and economic crisis. 
Do not hesitate to contact my office should you need assistance by phone at 802-862-0697 or 1-800-339-9834, or on our website. 
￼
 
How Can We Help? 
My Burlington office has a team of experienced caseworkers who help Vermonters navigate federal agencies every day. If you think my office can help you, please do not hesitate to call 1-800-339-9834 or (802) 862-0697, or click here.  
If you would like to share your thoughts on pending legislation, or if you have an idea that we could address through new legislation, click here.

Burlington

Burlington, VT 05401
